webTitle: Caught  in a web

fields.headline: Caught  in a web
fields.standfirst: The Financial Services Authority is cracking down on internet share scams, reports Tony Levene
fields.trailText: The Financial Services Authority is cracking down on internet share scams, reports Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Internet share dealing has eased the route to riches - or in some cases ruination - for hundreds of thousands of stock market investors. It is simple, cheap and quick.

But it is also a share scamster's delight with email and chatrooms offering an easy way for dishonest directors, brokers, PR people and shareholders to puff prices up - or down - with dubious rumours and downright lies. And they can do all this behind the mask of internet anonymity.

Now City watchdog the Financial Services Authority plans to tackle these and other "market abuses".

Investors should not rest easy, however. The proposed new rules will not come into force until this time next year thanks to the slow progress of the much amended Financial Services and Markets Act. And even when they do go live, it is unclear whether they will be effective in protecting investors - a fear underlined by apologies put out by two sharetipping websites earlier this week.

Both Citytipsters and UKinvest.com recommended buying shares in Industrial Control Services, an electronic equipment maker, believing it would attract a bid. It did - but not at the 30p to 40p level expected by Mark Watson-Mitchell on UKinvest and by the anonymous Citytipsters. Instead, all investors got was 1p a share without any chance to hold out for more. ICS said the alternative was going bust.

The two tipping sites undoubtedly acted in good faith, possibly passing on - as many tipsters do - the whispers of others in broking, investment banking, PR or inside the company itself. There is no legal bar on journalists publicising rumours no matter what the source.

The FSA plans to "keep UK financial markets free of misconduct" with a "non-criminal" code where a lower level of proof will be required than in a criminal court. The non-criminals will be subject to financial penalties or public censure, a style which has long been adopted by the US Securities and Exchanges Commission.

Areas that will come under scrutiny include: Misuse of information - buying or selling shares using inside information Giving false impressions such as posting deliberate misinformation on bulletin boards.

And it will stretch far beyond the professionals to anyone who is a "regular user" - a catchall phrase that could encompass day traders. The FSA already regulates a number of tipsheets including those sold on subscription. But tips from bulletin boards are outside the net - as are buy or sell recommendations from journalists.

Under the proposed new rules, journalists who publish misleading information with a view to influencing the price of shares could be fined or censured. But there will be no rules demanding writers reveal holdings.

Much depends on individual cases - a journalist with 100 shares in a widely held share such as Halifax can do little to move the price. But 100,000 shares in an easy to manipulate penny stock might be different. The FSA says it will rely on the Press Complaints Commission to police the press - but the PCC only applies to mainstream newspapers, not specialist publications or internet sites.

Nor is there any FSA plan to regulate financial PR - often a source of inside information. The watchdog says: "Consumers should always ask who benefits from information. If people think markets are being manipulated, they should report it."

webTitle: Pop review: Kathryn Williams

fields.headline: Playing it safe
fields.standfirst:
Kathryn Williams
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.trailText:
Kathryn Williams
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.body:
There is so much to like about Kathryn Williams. She puts out her own records, happily admits that her goal is to make people cry and when she performs she fulfils all the criteria of a perfect live show. She sings and plays beautifully, laughing at herself on the one occasion when her fingers flutter on her acoustic guitar strings. She smiles admiringly as her friend Laura Reid enriches each song with her exquisite cello lines and grins when the drummer pulls out a box of Tate & Lyle sugar to recreate the shuffling rhythm on Lydia. She seems nervous and embarrassed by the cheers that greet each song and yet, unlike so many other performers, she overcomes this enough to chat amiably with her obviously devoted fans.

She is sweet, charming - nice, reckons the girl sitting next to me. But this isn't enough. There are hints of darkness in Williams's lyrics: "I'm sinking down," she muses on Madmen and Maniacs, from last year's debut album Dog Leap Stairs. "Is your life so exciting you have to tell everyone you meet?" she snidely comments on Soul to Feet, from the Mercury-approved Little Black Numbers. But there's very little darkness in her style. There's no reeling, no unravelling, no stabs at the heart. Nothing volatile. Without that, these songs feel one-dimensional. Williams's gorgeous, ethereal voice floats along a silky, creamy surface, never tearing through to rawer emotions beneath.

The best song she plays in the set, You Tell the Truth As If It Were Lies, hints at how powerful she could be if she let a few devils mingle with her angels. Dedicated to someone she doesn't like, its indigo melodies and assertive cello almost pack a punch. But for the most part, you're carried along in a haze of loveliness that is pleasant but uninvolving. It is admirable that Williams has a style that feels utterly idiosyncratic, but watching her is a safe experience, in a way that watching PJ Harvey, for example, or Cat Power, would never be. But then, it's exactly that element of blandness that makes her a top tip for the Mercury - whatever William Hill think.

webTitle: Frustrated by a wall of silence

fields.headline: Frustrated by a wall of silence
fields.trailText: Case studies.
fields.body:
Patrick Dickinson, 32 is part of the "can pay, can't get" generation of well-paid professionals who, despite having perfect credit ratings, are horrified to find themselves rejected when they apply for financial deals.

On paper, Mr Dickinson looks just the sort of "new economy" customer the new internet-led financial companies would want. He's a computer programmer for a Banbury-based games company, earns between £30-£40,000 and has been with the same bank for 12 years. But when it comes to credit scoring systems, it seems he's a bad egg.

He applied for Egg's market-leading 10.9% credit card, but they turned him down, without offering an explanation. The same happened when he tried to get a credit card from Bank One, now part of the Halifax group. Again, they refused to tell him why.

Like many people declined credit, Mr Dickinson suspected there must be a mix-up with his credit rating. He paid £2 to look at his personal file held at Experian, but discovered it was blemish-free. He could only guess that he had been rejected not because of his credit rating, but because of the credit scoring used by the companies.

"The only thing I can think of is that I have changed address four times in the past three years, and I am not on the electoral register at my current address. This is most annoying as I really hate being in debt, and have always been meticulous in paying bills, debts and so on. Unfortunately I will be moving house again in a few months, so I guess that it will only get worse," he says.

The wall of silence about credit scoring is what infuriated Guardian journalist Stephen Bates when he returned to Britain from a four-year stint as the newspaper's European Affairs Editor in Brussels. He wanted a loan for a home improvement, but was shocked when he was rejected by at least six companies. "By all accounts I ought to be a credit company's dream applicant: well-paid, same employer for 10 years, mortgage for 18 years, never defaulted on a loan or delayed repayment." Yet he was turned down even by companies he had long used, such as Amex. Eventually Amex offered him a loan, but only after angry letters enclosing documents to prove his financial status.

"What I found really aggravating was the contrast between the advertising with all its promises of easy riches and the coldness of our rejection by a succession of telephone operatives ... without any chance of finding out why," he says.

Like Mr Dickinson, Bates also found that his credit rating was clean. He was almost certainly rejected because his name was not on the electoral roll. The roll is compiled by local authorities in October each year and the credit reference agencies fully update the data by the following April. Bates moved in to his home in December 1999, and won't go on to the electoral roll until later this year - so he is likely to continue being rejected until April 2001.

But he at least now has more right to demand why he is being rejected. A new code of conduct came into force in March this year under which lenders must tell applicants the principal cause for their rejection.

What's more, proposals to update the electoral roll on a rolling basis should bring down the delays which have plagued applicants who move into a new home but just miss the October 10 registration deadline.

webTitle: Sofa so good in  TV banking revolution

fields.headline: Sofa so good in  TV banking revolution
fields.standfirst: Couch potatoes could fix up their finances while the adverts are interrupting their favourite soaps, thanks to the advances in digital television, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Couch potatoes could fix up their finances while the adverts are interrupting their favourite soaps, thanks to the advances in digital television, reports Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
It's 7.59pm, the Coronation Street credits are rolling, and The Bill is starting in a minute or two. Traditionally the moment when viewers across the land rush to put the kettle on and make a brew. Now, growing numbers of people are instead grabbing their TV remote control, calling up their bank account on the screen and checking their balance or paying an electricity bill.

TV banking is dramatically changing the way we manage our money _ and the relationship we have with our telly. The number of people who use their TV to do their basic banking is only just approaching six figures, but is expected to explode in the next few years as more and more banks offer this facility to their customers.

HSBC was the first bank to launch a nationally available digital TV banking service. Available via Open, the interactive TV channel on Sky Digital, it was launched 10 months ago but has been fully interactive only since April. It now has more than 90,000 customers.

They are able to keep track of their spending and savings, pay bills, transfer money between their bank and savings accounts, and view their standing orders and direct debits.

On Monday HSBC proudly announced that the service was used to check a balance for the one millionth time.

However, it now has its first serious competition in the form of Abbey National, which this week launched its own digital TV banking service, again available via Open, which means you have to have a Sky Digital set-top box to use it.

Abbey claims its service is "the most advanced" available, and it is being offered to any customer with a card-based current or savings account who registers.

Meanwhile, the Woolwich has revealed its service will be up and running within a couple of months and First Direct is hot on its tail.

While most banks have been concentrating on enabling their customers to manage their finances online via a PC, some experts reckon it is TV banking that will eventually become the main method of banking from home.

Only one in four households has a PC, while there is a TV in 98% of homes and the take-up of digital televi sion is growing rapidly.

Ambrose McGinn at Abbey National says that many people find PCs too complicated and are concerned about the technology. When it comes to their TV, however, "people have been using it for years, they are comfortable with using remote control handsets".

Cable companies and pay TV operators such as Telewest and ONdigital have also been getting in on the act, and a recent survey from market analysts Datamonitor predicted that the number of people across Europe doing their banking via their TV is likely to increase ten-fold over the next four years - from 570,000 this year to 6.1m in 2004.

Using your television to access your bank account couldn't be easier, say Abbey and HSBC. You don't need a separate keypad - you simply use your remote control to key in your passcode and move around the site.

The downside is that, unlike banking by PC, you cannot download or print information.

Abbey's service allows people to view their account balances and recent transactions in "real time", move money instantly between their bank and savings accounts, pay bills, set up, amend and cancel standing orders and regular payments, and request and amend overdraft facilities.

The banks dabbling in TV banking say these sort of services will allow people to do more with their sets than simply watch their favourite programmes, and offer a lifeline to people who cannot afford PCs. But not everyone is convinced that tuning into the internet via your telly will leave the computer redundant.

Writing in the latest edition of Open's newsletter, Paul Davies, executive editor of trade magazine New Media Markets, points out that while logging on to the net on your computer tends to be something of a solitary activity, the TV is very much a "social" medium. "It seems likely that one side-effect of all this will be family rows, not just about which channel to watch but about whether a family member can surf the net when others want to watch Coronation Street," he says.

Unfazed, Abbey has said its aim is to "dominate" the TV banking market. To this end, as well as linking up with Sky Digital, it has entered into partnerships with several other key players. It already has an information-only service up and running with Telewest and has signed deals with two other cable companies, NTL and Cable & Wireless, plus ONdigital.

The Woolwich will launch its TV banking service - yet again available via Open - within the next six or seven weeks. It will be available to customers of its Open Plan product range, and while details have yet to be finalised, it is likely to allow people to view the balance or value of any Woolwich account including savings, mortgages, unit trusts and Isas, move money between accounts, pay bills and check recent transactions.

Of the other high street banks, Barclays is currently undertaking trials with Cable & Wireless, though these only involve the provision of information about its products and services. Barclays says: "We want to explore customer demand before taking it any further."

Lloyds TSB also appears to have a service in the offing - it would only say, somewhat mysteriously, that it "expects to have a partnership by the end of the year". Meanwhile, NatWest says it doesn't have any plans for TV banking.

webTitle: TV banking pioneers who have never looked back.

fields.headline: Switched on
fields.standfirst: Pioneers who have never looked back
fields.trailText: TV banking pioneers who have never looked back.
fields.body:
Stephen Hinchliffe and his wife Patricia were among the first people in the UK to switch on to digital TV banking..

They signed up to HSBC's service right at the beginning, and haven't looked back. HSBC's TV banking facility is available to Sky Digital subscribers via the Open home shopping channel.

Mr Hinchliffe, 53, of Hemsworth, near Pontefract, West Yorkshire, who has been a customer of the bank for 35 years, says: "We had been considering TV banking because my wife is quite severely disabled so it is very convenient in that sense."

They took the plunge and are now regular users. "Initially you could only check balances but now you can actually do transactions via the TV, like setting up direct debit payments and standing orders. The services are increasing all the time." Mr Hinchliffe says he probably uses the service a couple of times a week, mainly to check account balances and make sure that bills have been paid.

"I never go into the branch now - the last time I was in was at Christmas. Before, I went in once or twice a week."

Mr Hinchliffe, who is a carer, says he tends to do his TV banking at night, while his wife often uses the service early in the morning.

One aspect that he says is both a strength and a drawback is that the service's security is very tight, so that if you are entering your passcode and you accidentally press the wrong button on the remote control, "it switches you off immediately and it will not let you enter the system".

However, he says that on balance it is probably quite a good thing that the service is so secure.

webTitle: When lease means loss

fields.headline: When lease means loss
fields.trailText: If you look up "lease" in the dictionary - as in a contractual arrangement on where you live - you'll see that it's related to another nearby word, "leash", as in a device for tying someone or something up.
fields.body:
If you look up "lease" in the dictionary - as in a contractual arrangement on where you live - you'll see that it's related to another nearby word, "leash", as in a device for tying someone or something up.

The connection won't be lost on a number of elderly people in the north-east of England who are having serious problems with soon-to-expire leases on their homes - with their plight having been highlighted in the House of Commons by Cleethorpes MP Shona McIsaac.

While we now tend to think of leasehold properties in terms of flats, there are still around 900,000 houses under long-term leases - typically old-fashioned terraced houses in places such as north-east and north-west England. And many of these, built around the turn of the last century, are reaching the end of their 99-year leases.

This means that even though the occupiers have paid off their mortgages years ago, they are now facing massive bills to buy the freehold and to stay in their own homes.

Ms McIsaac says: "People are being asked to fork out vast sums to buy the freehold of homes that they thought they already owned. Residents are being asked to pay up to £30,000 to purchase the freehold of those houses. In Grimsby and Cleethorpes that is more than the value of the property."

She adds: "It is a scandal that landlords who have contributed nothing for almost 100 years can waltz in and demand from homeowners outrageous sums so that they can stay in their own homes. These landlords and landowners never paid a penny towards their upkeep and improvement over the years, yet they want tens of thousands of pounds from mainly elderly people, often widows, who simply cannot lay their hands on such sums."

Although the MP says that the individuals don't want to be named, her current caseload includes a pensioner who is "frantically trying to raise money from relatives" towards the £10,000 demanded to buy the freehold on her house - she can't get a loan because she is over 80 years old. Another "frail widow" who wants to sell her house and go into residential care also faces a bill of £10,000 to buy out a soon to expire lease.

The problem also affects inheritance, with Ms McIsaac citing the case of a constituent who died in January, leaving his house to his family.

"The family discovered that the lease ran out at the beginning of April. The freeholder refused at first to sell the freehold. When I put pressure on him, he agreed to do so, and wrote to me on March 13 - days before the lease expired - quoting a price of £35,000 if my constituents were to inherit their parents' home. They could not raise the money and have lost their parents' home. The freeholder is laughing all the way to the bank."

The means by which the price tag for buying out a freehold is calculated is an opaque blend of algebra and legalese, intended to reach a figure reflecting the loss of value to the freeholder.

Among the most contested elements of this arcane process is the "marriage value", which estimates how much a property will gain in value when it acquires freehold status - with half of this figure (which can be tens of thousands) being charged to the person buying the freehold.

Tony Essien, senior adviser at the independent lease advisory service, Lease, says that where freeholders appear to be presenting excessive valuations for freeholds, leaseholders should contest the claim, with the result that charges fall considerably. Also, there are protections for anyone who cannot buy afford to buy out the freehold - including the right to a 50-year extension on the lease or becoming a tenant who pays rent.

Neither of these alternatives are perfect: no one wants to start paying a "market rent" years after they've paid off a mortgage on a house and the "free" 50-year lease extension will still incur costs and, under present legislation, means that the leaseholder forfeits the right to buy the freehold at a later date, leaving them stuck as tenants in their own home.

Next month leasehold law is due for another overhaul, with the publication of a White Paper looking at the whole relationship between leaseholder and landlord - including the likely proposal that flatowners in shared dwellings will be able to acquire the new status of "commonhold".

But taking a step back from the detail, there seems to be a more fundamental problem with the whole concept of leasehold, which allows people to buy and sell properties which are still "owned" by an absentee landlord. It's a feudal overhang that just doesn't work with a home-owning democracy, and any attempt to phase it out rather than reform it would seem to be a step in the right direction.

webTitle: Prom review: Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/Adès

fields.headline: Musical memories
fields.standfirst:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/Adès
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/Adès
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Gerald Barry is one of that increasingly rare breed of contemporary composers whose music is instantly identifiable. The opening of his Wiener Blut, a ricocheting line bursting with energy, swathed in tremolos and coloured by unpredictable instrumental doublings, couldn't have been written by anyone else.

The title conjures up memories of Johann Strauss's operettas and waltzes, and Barry has called the work a "harmonic Baedeker for Viennese travellers". But apart from a rhythm borrowed from Die Fledermaus, this 12-minute ensemble piece does not offer a tour through the delights of musical Vienna so much as a cryptic journey through a range of autobiographical references.

Buried in the textures of Wiener Blut are the distilled essences of harmonic figures that Barry has accumulated through his life (his "poignancy grid", he calls it). Few of these are obvious. A snatch of Messiaen flashes by, and there's an unmistakable Stravinskian cadence, but the other memories are woven seamlessly into a virtuoso piece of writing that twists and turns, accumulates tremendous momentum then brakes suddenly and veers off in another direction altogether, or projects itself as swaggering and aggressive only to melt into moments of gentle, jewelled lyricism.

Barry commands this hand-me-down language wonderfully; this music is disconcerting in its originality yet never arcane or iconoclastic, and its physical impact is immense. Like a lot of Barry's music it is also fearsomely difficult to play, but there was never a hint of insecurity in this ebullient London premiere. Wiener Blut was commissioned for this year's Aldeburgh Festival, and it was brought to the late-night Prom by Thomas Adès and the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group.

The rest of the Birmingham programme was given over to Busoni and his two most famous pupils. The teacher himself was represented by his Berceuse Elégiaque, in the reduction by Erwin Stein that rather plays down the work's comforting lushness, while Varèse's Ecuatorial, a raw, unpredictable and extraordinary piece, sat uneasily alongside Kurt Weill's Berliner Requiem.

The Weill, the first of the works in this year's Proms to mark the composer's centenary, had Garry Magee and HK Gruber as soloists. Magee becomes a more and more impressive baritone with every appearance, and was commanding in his small role here. Gruber's crooning, however, is a taste that needs to be acquired. And I haven't got there yet.

webTitle: Brits abroad bask in the profits of euro weakness

fields.headline: Brits abroad bask in the profits of euro weakness
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: British holidaymakers heading for European sun spots received a last minute boost yesterday when Europe's battered single currency tumbled on the foreign exchanges, writes Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
British holidaymakers heading for European sun spots received a last minute boost yesterday when Europe's battered single currency tumbled on the foreign exchanges, writes Charlotte Denny.

The euro fell to a two month low against the pound, pushing down the prices for British tourists in the continent's main holiday destinations of Spain, France and Italy.

The single currency also fell against the dollar, hitting one week lows.

Expectations that the gap between borrowing costs on the continent and in Britain and the United States will continue to widen were behind yesterday's currency gyrations. While analysts are pencilling in higher interest rates from the federal reserve and the Bank of England, the European Central Bank is expected to hold fire for the time being.

"Recent euro zone data, including the money supply data, have eroded the likelihood of a eurozone rate hike in September and kicked the euro while it was already down," said Mike Moran, treasury economist at Standard Chartered in London.

The money supply data followed dovish comments from European Central Bank board member Vitor Constancio, who said on Thursday that the bank could tolerate temporary spikes in inflation above its 2% target.

The euro hit troughs around 61.3 pence, its lowest level since May 25, before recovering slightly to close in London at 61.62p. Against the dollar, the euro fell as far as 92.6 cents, its lowest level since July 20, down about 2% from two week peaks around 94.5 cents set earlier this week. It closed yesterday in London at 92.7 cents.

webTitle: Banks veto plan to save post offices

fields.headline: Banks veto plan to save post offices
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The Government's promise to protect rural post offices was in tatters last night after Britain's leading banks refused to back government plans for a universal bank.
fields.body:
The Government's promise to protect rural post offices was in tatters last night after Britain's leading banks refused to back government plans for a universal bank.

In a letter to ministers obtained by the Guardian, the banks complained that ministers' plans for a post office-based universal bank would carry the stigma of a "poor person's bank" and would be neither "useful or attractive".

The plan was the central plank of the government's strategy to save 18,500 post offices around the country.

The prime minister promised MPs that he would "protect rural post offices in the future" in February.

Ministers are desperately seeking ways to protect post offices which are under threat from the government's policy to pay social security benefits directly into bank accounts from 2003. The Post Office estimates many sub-postmasters will lose up to 40% of their income as a result of the change.

The rejection of the proposed bank for the poor came after post office minister Alan Johnson and treasury minister Melanie Johnson gave the banks the option 10 days ago to opt-out of the scheme.

That move was seen as a snub to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who had unveiled the scheme for the "financially excluded" only a few weeks ago. Bankers were surprised that Mr Byers appeared to have been sidelined.

The Treasury, which appears to have taken over the project, has spent the last 18 months working with the banks to persuade them to launch basic bank accounts, under their own brand names.

In another letter, also seen by the Guardian, ministers offered the banks the Treasury alternative. It is the scheme that the banks are now backing.

However, the ministers' letter said the new accounts would have to be in place by October. "The accounts also need to be widely available and widely accessible in locations which are easy to reach for those who do not currently have bank accounts - for example in poorer neighbourhoods in towns and cities as well as in rural areas."

The British Bankers' Association this week responded by saying that the universal bank would be "immensely complex" and create "serious confusion" among customers.

"My members do not consider the idea of a universal bank to be either useful or attractive. There are better solutions to the problem of financial exclusion that could be considered. If desirable these could be presented under a banner of 'universal banking' without the need for the creation of a new entity," Tim Sweeney, director general of the BBA said in the letter.

"The potential for there to be a stigma for those using what may come to be known as a 'poor person's bank' should not be overlooked."

He said a "more practical and quicker solution" to the problem of providing more people with bank accounts would be to get the post office to put cash machines and card readers into its branches.

The banks also suggest that the post office, along with the benefits agency, should join the Link cash machine network to allow claimants to collect their cash directly.

Yet, despite the banks' blunt opposition to the post office-based bank, the Department of Trade and Industry last night said: "We now want the banks to actually take this project forward. We believe there are considerable advantages to the banks by being involved with the universal bank. They would have the opportunity to be involved in the design of it and it would help them meet their social obligations in a way which their present products clearly do not".

The DTI spokesman added: "The universal bank will have the considerable advantage of being under the post office badge rather than under individual banks' names."

The post office said that the government had to decide how much it wanted to spend on the scheme.

The post office is expecting the banks to contribute most of the £150m annual running costs of the universal bank. It is also expecting the banks to pay for the installation of cash machines at 3,000 post offices, at a cost of £50,000 a machine.

The Treasury last night said it did not regret offering banks the choice. "We all want better services for the financially excluded," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Moving to put customers first

fields.headline: Moving to put customers first
fields.trailText: Internet bank first-e.com has hit back at claims that its chart-topping rates could be at the cost of lower consumer protection.
fields.body:
Internet bank first-e (www.first-e.com) has hit back at claims that its chart-topping rates could be at the cost of lower consumer protection.

The 65,000 customers of the net bank, whose operation centre is in Dublin, cannot complain to the banking ombudsman scheme or qualify for depositor protection because French-owned first-e is not based in the UK.

But setting a standard which others will have to follow, first-e has now set up a customer complaints service backed by an independent consumer council and a maximum £250,000 compensation - compared to £100,000 in the UK scheme.

Savers will also be able to call on the French compensation scheme if first-e flops. This pays up to around £40,000 - more than double the £18,000 UK limit.

And first-e posts the num ber of complaints received on its website as well as clear up times for moans and groans. It received 253 in June - all bar one has been settled.

But first-e will have to look to its laurels if it is to maintain its table-topping rates. It currently pays 6.81% on £1 upwards although this includes a 0.81% bonus which will go on September 30.

Rivals include Nationwide e-savings at 7% from £1 - this is restricted to Nationwide Flex Account holders - and 7% from Abbey National's eSaver, a rate that includes a 1% bonus for six months.

Halifax has a no-strings 6.35% on £1 upwards on its internet only web-saver from next Tuesday, while Egg at 6.3% on £1 or more is slipping down the ratings.

webTitle: Cooling market lets buyers pile on the pressure

fields.headline: Cooling market lets buyers pile on the pressure
fields.standfirst: Elizabeth Langton tells how the agreed price for her house was beaten down at the last minute
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Langton tells how the agreed price for her house was beaten down at the last minute.
fields.body:
I have spent the last four months haggling, hassling and cajoling in an attempt to buy a house. My experience fitted with the findings of building society researchers. Earlier this month they confirmed what estate agents have known for some time - that the heat has gone out of the market.

The high prices in London and other property hot spots at the beginning of this year encouraged sellers. The result: buyers are now in a stronger position to push down prices.

The gazumpers' place is being filled by gazunderers. Gazundering is the practice of putting in an offer below the agreed price when all parties are ready to exchange.

I put my detached two-bed cottage with study room and garage, on the market in April, shortly after spotting my ideal family home just around the corner. Prices where I lived in south London had been going through the roof. Perfectly ordinary semis were on the market for more than £300,000.

We offered £299,000 - the asking price - for the house, which needed extensive work. The offer was accepted. We placed our house with the same agents who were confident they could sell it for £275,000 in no time.

At Easter, the agents were inundated with sellers and for some reason the buyers had disappeared. The agents were reassuring - just a blip we were told.

We dropped the price to £260,000. This led to offers below the asking price. In the end it was a contest between a cash buyer (who made us suspicious by chopping and changing his mind about what he was prepared to pay) and a couple who assured us they were prepared to pay the asking price. They were given the nod.

Finally, we were in a position to exchange contracts - or so we thought. First we discovered our buyers were still awaiting a mortgage offer (they had changed lenders halfway through without telling anyone). When their offer came through, they said they were still awaiting their survey, despite earlier reassurances that they had the report and that it was fine.

Rather late in the day came requests for electrical, gas, drain and heating system surveys and other minor issues were raised. We issued a deadline after knocking some money off the price. Another exchange day was arranged and our vendors rescheduled their removal company.

The appointed hour for the exchange came and went. Then a call from their solicitor revealed they hadn't realised there was extra stamp duty on properties of more than £250,000. They could not afford to buy unless we dropped the price to just under the tax threshold.

We couldn't afford to accept £10,000 less unless the people we were buying from dropped as well. The agents pulled out the stops to persuade our vendors to drop their price by £10,000.

Our vendors were bewildered. Only weeks before, the agents told them buyers would be queuing to buy their home. Now, the message was they'd be lucky to shift it this year without a big price cut.

Had our buyers planned it this way from the start? The agent had recently dealt with a similar case where a first-time buyer forced a much longer chain to knock thousands of pounds off the value of their houses.

The planned reforms to house buying and selling would have prevented a great deal of distress in my case. The seller's information pack would have given interested parties details of my property's condition up front. There would have been less time to quibble further down the line.

The government's main aim is to cut the time between acceptance of the initial offer and exchange of contracts. At present it takes an average of eight weeks before contracts are exchanged - closing this gap will reduce the likelihood of gazumping and gazundering.

In the end the couple we bought from dropped their price to bring the process to a close. By that point we were all so exhausted we would have agreed to anything. Although the reforms won't take all the uncertainty out of home buying and selling - no government can legislate for people changing their minds or unforeseen circumstances - the changes will undoubtedly take some of the stress out of the process.

We were very fond of our house and it was always going to be hard to leave. Now I just can't wait to get out and say goodbye to the whole horrible experience.

webTitle: Halifax keeps on tracking

fields.headline: Halifax keeps on tracking
fields.trailText: The Halifax this week fired the latest shot in the mortgage price war by unveiling a range of base rate tracker home loans it hopes will bring in many more customers and help it hang on to existing ones.
fields.body:
The Halifax this week fired the latest shot in the mortgage price war by unveiling a range of base rate tracker home loans it hopes will bring in many more customers and help it hang on to existing ones.

Britain's biggest mortgage lender certainly can't be accused of doing things by halves - all told, there are now no less than 19 tracker mortgages on offer. There is also a range of new three and five-year fixed rate deals starting at 6.75%.

With a tracker home loan, your monthly mortgage payments are linked to the Bank of England base rate (currently 6%) - when this goes up or down, so does what you pay. The rates on these deals are set a fixed amount above the base rate - typically between 0.75% and 1.5%.

Many people like the clarity and certainty this sort of deal offers - with a tracker, the rate you pay is guaranteed to shadow the movement of the base rate, so lenders can't wriggle out of passing on interest rate cuts. While the Halifax's decision to embrace the tracker concept is to be welcomed, Ray Boulger at mortgage broker John Charcol says that in general, the new product range is not as good as the old one.

The current two-year tracker deals for new customers and existing borrowers moving home - which range from 5.95% (0.05% below base rate) to 6.15% (0.15% above base rate) until October 31 2002 - and the new tracker deals for first-time buyers are less attractive than its previous discount rate deals.

But one product that does win Halifax a gold star is its new five-year tracker, where the current pay rate is 6.25% (0.25% above bank base rate until October 31, 2005) for people who can stump up a deposit of 25%-plus. Mr Boulger says this is "very competitive" and compares well with arguably the best penalty-free five-year discount on the market: Derbyshire building society's loan giving 1.45% off its standard rate for five years, giving a current pay rate of 6%. More details of the deals can be found online at www.halifax.co.uk.

This week also saw First Active launch a tracker mortgage available exclusively through Tesco Personal Finance. It has a 3% discount for six months, giving an initial pay rate of 4.25%, and after that you pay base rate plus 1.25%, guaranteed for the term of the loan.

Tracking also forms part of a new flexible mortgage on offer from Alliance & Leicester. There is a 1.9% discount off its 7.74% standard rate for one year, followed by a tracker rate guaranteed at 0.95% above bank base rate for 10 years.

Meanwhile, Abbey National says that worries about further interest rate rises could prompt many borrowers to think about the security offered by fixed-rate mortgages. This week it launched a loan fixed at 6.65% for three years, available to first-time buyers, home movers and remortgage customers.

webTitle: Secret tips that let you beat the credit guard

fields.headline: Secret tips that let you beat the credit guard
fields.standfirst: If you've got a good job and no debts but have been turned down for a loan with no reason given then you need to read this. Patrick Collinson pulls away the veil over how banks assess you
fields.trailText: If you've got a good job and no debts but have been turned down for a loan with no reason given then you need to read this. Patrick Collinson pulls away the veil over how banks assess you.
fields.body:
Jobs & Money this week lifts the veil of secrecy wrapped around the credit scoring systems used by every major financial institution - and which results in one in four applicants being denied a credit card, personal loan or mortgage.

Credit reference agency files have long been available for the public to check, but they make up only a part of the "scorecard" used to decide if someone is a worthy risk. Equally important are in-house credit scoring systems which point-score on a wide range of factors.

These systems are stamped top secret because banks fear that if they are opened to the public, they will be at risk of abuse and manipulation. But this week a major high street bank - it refused to allow its identity to be disclosed - opened its files to Jobs & Money.

The bank, which has more than 50 credit products in the market, regularly rejects around 25-30% of applicants. Its scoring system reveals that having your name on the electoral roll is crucial; if it's not been there for the past year, you may as well forget trying to obtain one of its alluring low-rate deals.

Moved address more than twice in the last three years? This also puts you in the doghouse. Are you a high-flyer building a career by hopping from one job to another, watching your salary jump up every time? It's good for your bank balance, but not so good for your credit score.

The bank's head of credit scoring says: "The whole thing is driven by mathematics. There is no question that instability in employment and housing is an indication of a higher risk customer. It is not surprising they score at a lower level."

As the case studies reveal, good pay is no guarantee of credit. Credit scoring systems can check only verifiable information held on accessible databases. Give your salary as £100,000 a year on a credit card application and it makes little difference to the assessment. Only in mortgage applications is salary essential.

If rejected, it's wise not to keep on applying elsewhere; the credit reference agencies, while not identifying whether you were accepted or turned down, put a note on your file that you made an application. The bank says that if it sees more than six ticks in that box in the last three to four months, it will automatically refer your case. In the language of the trade, they steer clear of the emotive word rejection. Instead you will be declined.

It's also wise not to respond to a junk mail offer too soon; earlier applicants are more likely to be rejected, says the bank. "The first people to apply are the most desperate," it says. Records show early applicants are more likely to default.

The good news is that if you appeal against a rejection, you are likely to win. The bank finds that outraged rejected applicants usually have a good case, and can provide documents about their financial profile.

The outraged are not normally the former bankrupts, fraudsters or those who know they are already too deeply in debt. They are more likely to be the job and address hoppers (disproportionately represented in the IT and media industries) who have fallen off the electoral roll, but have perfect credit histories.

The electoral roll is the major faultline in credit scoring systems. Local authorities compile the roll, and use residence on October 10 as their base. The banks check personal identities against the roll held at a credit reference agency, but the agencies cannot guarantee to have the full data in place from local authorities until the follow ing April. So someone who moved home in November last year could have to wait until May next year before their credit score improves.

Too often applicants rejected by lenders, apart from feeling humiliated, are left in the dark about any problem. Experian, the largest credit reference agency - it processes 80m credit checks a year - says: "We find it irritating that people are told or implied that a rejection is to do with our files, when it's to do with their credit scoring." Around 1m people a year pay £2 to Experian to personally check their credit file, but only a tiny number are incorrect.

Experian is pushing for wider use of guidelines in the Guide To Credit Scoring 2000 which came into force in March this year but has so far been applied only loosely. Under the guidelines, lenders must tell an applicant the principal reason why they have been declined - but only if the applicant asks.

In the US, credit scoring is a hot political issue, but it rarely hits the headlines in Britain. This is partly because computerised scoring has replaced a worse alternative - when local bank staff might have asked the milkman whether an individual was keeping up with his or her payments.

Malcolm Hurlstone of the Foundation for Credit Counselling says: "Credit scoring is generally less obtrusive in comparison with the old days. Its relative remoteness makes it a pretty painless process."

However, recent developments at Barclays and Abbey National's net subsidiary Cahoot promise to move credit scoring up the agenda. Both are piloting schemes in which the interest rate you obtain for a loan will depend on your credit score.

In the US, where credit scoring has a longer history, each individual has a "Fico" score of up to 900 points, where 640 points is the gateway to borrowing. Under pressure from the California Senate, credit agencies are now releasing details of the previously secret scores to individuals.

One result is that dating agencies are considering adding an individual's credit score to the profile of potential partners, while a website has already sprung up on the internet which gives you advice and counselling if you score 666.

Your Credit Decision Explained and The Guide To Credit Scoring 2000 are available from the Finance and Leasing Association, Imperial House, 15-19 Kingsway, London WC2B 6UN. Tel 020 7836 6511.

For a copy of your credit reference agency file, write to Experian, Customer Help Service, PO Box 8000, Nottingham NG1 5GX or Equifax, Dept 1E, PO Box 3001, Glasgow G81 2DT. Enclose a cheque or postal order for £2.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Gift

fields.headline: Lost and found
fields.standfirst:
The Gift
Tricycle, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Gift
Tricycle, London
***
fields.body:
Roy Williams is a gifted young writer who wrote - and achieved - Lift Off at the Royal Court, a play which dealt startlingly with black machismo and its assimilation by young whites. In this new play he tackles the more familiar topic of the alienating effect of exile and emigration on a whole middle-aged Caribbean generation.

His heroine, Heather, is a successful London lawyer who returns to her native Jamaica after 30 years to bury her teenage son. As far as we can work out from the shadowy details he was the victim of an assault that has disturbing echoes of the Stephen Lawrence case. Heather emerges as an austere achiever who has shed her Caribbean past. But once back home she yearns for some last contact with her dead son. The question Williams poses is whether that can best be achieved by herself; her boozy, spiritualist half-sister Bernice; or by her life-loving daughter Janet.

Williams's main point is that the post-Windrush generation which looked to Britain to fulfil its dreams paid a heavy emotional price. Heather emerges as a cold woman who disapproved of her son's desire to form a rock band as much as she does of her daughter's cohabitation with a restaurant-owning boyfriend. If Williams sees any hope it is in the daughter who manages to combine a relaxed, hedonistic London lifestyle with an intuitive awareness of her antecedents and a life beyond the grave.

I am uneasy at the way Williams plays on the associations of the Lawrence case without exploring any specifics. But he successfully evokes both the ramshackle poverty of Jamaica and its strange sunlit spirituality: you see both why many people felt they had to leave and why they are glad to return. Annie Castledine's production, with Timothy Sutton's almost continuous piano music and designer Liz Cooke's economic evocation of a magic forest, is also potently atmospheric.

All the performances - Doreene Blackstock as Heather, Jax Williams as her mini-skirted daughter, Claire Benedict as her otherworldly half-sister and Nicholas Beveney as Bernice's shadowy admirer - are first-rate. The social details are sometimes vague. But Williams's play, which stems from Birmingham Rep, offers a touchingly poetic picture of exactly what was lost in the economically inevitable process of emigration.

Until August 19. Box office: 020-7328 1000.

webTitle: Company of artillery booms a 48-gun salute for Marshall

fields.headline: Company of artillery booms a 48-gun salute for Marshall
fields.standfirst: The rolls were oversubscribed for the benefit of the late fast bowler's son
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver reports on yesterday's all-star Malcolm Marshall Memorial Match which attracted a crowd of more than 3,000 and raised an estimated £50,000 for his son, Mali.
fields.byline: Paul Weaver  in the City of London
fields.body:
A cricket match in the heart of London is bizarre enough. When there are 48 players, and no one seems sure who has won, it becomes a little surreal. It did not matter, though. The Malcolm Marshall Memorial Match attracted a crowd of more than 3,000 and raised an estimated £50,000 for his son, Mali.

The Honourable Artillery Company, where the match was played, was established under royal charter by Henry VIII in 1537 and is the oldest regiment in the British army. On state occasions such as the Queen's birthday, the regiment fires gun salutes at the Tower of London, and it would not have been inappropriate if they had boomed out again yesterday for the former West Indies fast bowler and coach, who died in November aged 41.

Ron Atkinson, glancing at the 25-pounders on the boundary, quipped: "Do you think they are expecting crowd trouble?"

Marshall's widow Connie, Mali's mother, said: "It is a sunny, Malcolm Marshall day, a wonderful day for a wonderful man. And the fact that so many cricketers have turned out for him is a great tribute."

Glenn McGrath was so keen to play that he phoned the organiser David English. "But I've already got 47 players," he was told. "Then make me the 48th," replied the Australia fast bowler.

Colin Croft was miffed when he could not get a game. "But I wanted to be here anyway. Malcolm was effervescent and one of the best performers I've seen. He was always charging in. His arm came over very quickly and he did more with it than the rest of us."

Michael Holding did get a game and even gave a chilling reprise of the Oval '76 when he glided in off his full run, although this time he did not release the ball. "It doesn't matter," said someone. "I would pay good money just to see him run in. The ball doesn't matter."

Joel Garner, a former Barbados and West Indies team-mate, said: "He was a good friend; one of the best I had. We were like family. His great strength as a bowler was his ability to adapt to any conditions."

Former opponents had more rueful memories. Mike Gatting, who must have thought he had faced Holding and Garner for the last time, recalled the time Marshall broke his nose in Kingston in 1986.

"He was just about the best fast bowler I ever saw. And he was such an intelligent bowler. He bowled very fast, swung it both ways, and wanted to keep the ball all day. He was a dream to captain and I just wish I had done it more than once. That was when we had the MCC bicentennial match at Lord's, and on a flat pitch he gave everyone problems."

The Hampshire captain Robin Smith, once a team-mate at Southampton, said: "We are all here for Mali today. Malcolm's last series against England was in 1991 in England and when I had scored 97 he bowled me a leg-stump half-volley which I put away for four. Malcolm normally gave nothing away, but I know he gave me that important four that day."

The former England opener Graeme Fowler said: "He was just about the best there was. The only other to compare with him was Dennis Lillee. Both of them had such great control. He always seemed to hit me on the forearm. If you succeeded against him you knew you had earned your runs."

Another former opener, David Smith, used to love taking on the quick bowlers but he found it difficult being macho with "Maco". He said: "I tried to hook him once and ended up on my backside."

Yesterday there were wonderful cameos from Viv Richards, Gordon Greenidge, Shane Warne, Allan Lamb and Gatting among others. But somehow the memory of perhaps the greatest fast bowler was all-important. The Malcolm Marshall team beat the International PCA Bunbury XI. But it did not matter, really.

webTitle: The spike in Hollywood's side

fields.headline: The spike in Hollywood's side
fields.standfirst: The maverick director has been shooting his mouth off again. His latest targets are the US gun lobby and the makers of The Patriot. He explains why to David Eimer
fields.trailText: The maverick director has been shooting his mouth off again. His latest targets are the US gun lobby and the makers of The Patriot. He explains why to David Eimer.
fields.body:
Spike Lee has never been shy when it comes to sounding off about his fellow film-makers. In the past, he's attacked Quentin Tarantino over his use of the word "nigger" in his films and even had a go at George Lucas over the hapless Jar-Jar Binks's faux-Jamaican accent in the last Star Wars movie.

But Lee has reserved some of his most vehement comments of late for The Patriot, in which Mel Gibson saves America from the dastardly Brits. In a letter to The Hollywood Reporter earlier this month, Lee blasted the film's portrayal of the American revolution as "pure, blatant Hollywood propaganda". A couple of weeks on and he's still fuming over it, to the point that he's even prepared to stick up for the British.

"It make the redcoats look like Nazis," exclaims Lee. "I think that once again it's the same old Hollywood, where they omit stuff or just don't deal with it. They say that the film wasn't about slavery, but you knowÉ"

One scene, where a condescending plantation owner talks to his freed slave, was particularly painful for Lee. "Throughout the whole movie the guy's calling him Ônigger' and then he says, ÔOh, it's an honour to serve with you.' That's Hollywood bullshit. I mean, he has a chance to be free, would he stay and keep fighting? And where are the native Americans in that movie? Those guys were there from the beginning, they were there before Columbus."

Lee's comments have also re-ignited his smouldering dispute with Charlton Heston, who's now best known in the States for being the chairman of the National Rifle Association (NRA), a powerful organisation that fiercely defends the right of Americans to bear arms. In a letter to the LA Times on July 15, Heston said that Lee should be grateful that the US achieved independence from Britain.

"No wonder he's the spokesman for the NRA," he laughs. "That's just ignorant, you don't even respond to something like that. He still thinks he's Moses, or Ben Hur." It's a more measured response than Lee's suggestion last year that Heston should be shot, after they clashed on gun control. "When I said that, that was in jest so I'm not even going there," says a suddenly muted Lee.

Firing off letters to all and sundry doesn't seem to have interfered with his work rate. The 43-year-old turns out more films than most writer/directors, and his last, 1999's Summer Of Sam, was one of his most ambitious yet. A sprawling, fictionalised account of the events of the summer of 1977 in New York, when serial killer David Berkowitz (the Son Of Sam) was terrorising the city, it stars Mira Sorvino, John Leguizamo and Adrien Brody as a wannabe English punk.

It's a time the Brooklyn-raised Lee remembers well. "That summer I was 20 and home from my sophomore year at Morehouse College in Atlanta. I didn't have a job and was going around New York and shooting with a Super-8 camera," he recalls. The subsequent footage became part of his student film Last Hustle In Brooklyn. "That was my first film. It was a bunch of images shot over the summer of 1977 and cut to disco music."

He doesn't seem too bothered by the fact that his movies are rarely big commercial hits. "It's disappointing for, like, the first week but that doesn't negate what I feel about the films or the importance of the films," insists Lee. webTitle: Look who's talking

fields.headline: Look who's talking
fields.standfirst: Natural performer Nathan Lane eclipses his stage and screen successes with his latest roles: an evil lizard-like alien and a neurotic New York cat
fields.trailText: Natural performer Nathan Lane eclipses his stage and screen successes with his latest roles: an evil lizard-like alien and a neurotic New York cat.
fields.body:
It comes to something when a latter-day Broadway legend is best known to cinemagoers under the age of 10. A Tony-award winner for his performance in A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forumä Nathan Lane's vocal chords have registered with youngsters the world over for his cheeky meerkat Timon in Disney's animated sensation The Lion King. New Jersey-born, the 44-year-old Lane - who has made sporadic screen turns in the likes of Frankie And Johnny, The Birdcage, Mouse Hunt and Kenneth Branaghês recent Love's Labour's Lost - has turned voice-work from a sideline into a full-time profession. This month hears his contribution to the live-action/computer-generated blend Stuart Little, as well as sci-fi extravaganza Titan AE.

Did you enjoy voicing Snowbell on Stuart Little?

Yeah. People have gotten a kick out of it... Snowbell's this neurotic New York house cat. He feels threatened when Stuart is adopted. Suddenly his owner is a mouse, and it's very humiliating for him. They spent agonising hours filming cats walking around. My part was to come in when all the dirty work was done and look at footage of cats and try to ad-lib.

You've also worked on Titan AE?

Yeah, with Matt Damon and Drew Barrymore. It's a science-fiction animated film. There's computer stuff in it. I'm a villain - the sleazy, lizard alien character called Preed, who's not to be trusted. He's funny and then turns ugly.

Do you enjoy voice work more than appearing on screen?

Y'know, The Lion King was hugely successful and actually brought a lot of attention to me. For a cartoon, it made a lot of money. But I read reviews for Stuart Little and they say it's the best thing I've ever done - and you want to hang yourself! I've been an actor for 25 years and now I'm Mel Blanc. It's great when people have loved something so much. I'm usually the voice of irony and dissension in these family films. It's fun. We start with a script and then we improvise, and you don't have to shave.

Were you a performer from a very early age?

Yes. I would get up at family gatherings and do impressions. I was like a bad lounge act, aged three. My family are unintentionally entertaining, but there are not a lot of performers in my family.

Do you have a stand-up background?

Yes. When I first moved to New York, and had been a struggling actor for a few years. I used to deliver singing telegrams. One time at a wedding there was an accordion player on stage and he handed me the mike and I sang for the bride and groom. Then I started to make fun of the accordion player, who was annoying. They were laughing, and I continued to talk about my sad life as a struggling actor - and at the end, people threw money. So I thought maybe I should try this. Eventually I put an act together with another struggling actor. We opened for rock acts like Al Jarreau and Air Supply. It was great training, though I had no desire to be a stand-up.

What happened after that?

Eventually I moved back to New York. I did a short-lived TV series - the only kind I do - in 1981, called One Of The Boys, with Dana Carvey, Mickey Rooney and Scatman Crothers. Then did my first Broadway show with George C Scott - a Noel Coward play - and that got me back into the theatre.

Any recent screen appearances?

I did a movie with Alan Rudolph called Trixie, with Emily Watson and Nick Nolte. It's a private eye comedy. I play Kirk Stans - a Casino lounge act who drinks too much.

webTitle: Isn't larceny grand?

fields.headline: Isn't larceny grand?
fields.standfirst: Jerry Bruckheimer and Nicolas Cage always make a winning combination. Joe Queenan clocks the latest fast-cars-big-stars-big-budget blockbuster
fields.trailText: Jerry Bruckheimer and Nicolas Cage always make a winning combination. Joe Queenan clocks the latest fast-cars-big-stars-big-budget blockbuster.
fields.body:
Two formats that have long dominated the cinematic imagination are the Last Caper Film and the Last Gunfight Film. In the former (The Lavender Hill Mob, Oceans 11, Assault On A Queen, the next five Burt Reynolds movies), an affable scoundrel starting to get a bit long in the tooth assembles a gang of his old cronies and tries to pull off one last big score.

Usually, a large part of the film is devoted to the leader's desperate attempts to induce his cohorts to come out of retirement; there is invariably a disbelieving wife, a sullen girlfriend, an incredulous employer or an irate mother standing in the way. But in the end, the ringleader makes his case, and the game is afoot.

The Last Gunfight Film (Shane, The Unforgiven, The Wild Bunch, The Patriot) usually involves an ageing gunslinger who is persuaded to emerge from retirement because of a personal obligation, a mysterious vendetta or an unusual amount of villainy at the state, county or municipal level. Frequently the hero himself has a number of personality deficiencies, but these tend to be overshadowed by the utter moral disfigurement of his adversaries. The hero is, in the words of the Immortal Bard, a man more sinned against than sinning. Though sometimes not by a very wide margin.

Gone In 60 Seconds is a highly effective, though mildly ridiculous, hybrid of these two beloved genres. Giovanni Ribisi, who has been in so many bad movies that it was inevitable he should eventually be in a good one, plays a young, industrious car thief whose grandstanding tendencies have just landed him in hot water. Personally committed to stealing 50 cars for a psychotic Anglo-Italian mobster based in the suburbs of Los Angeles, he has totally muffed the assignment and now faces certain death.

Ribisi, in point of fact, is doomed because his psychotic employer cannot bear the thought of not delivering the 50 vehicles to his South American customers at the stipulated time. Seemingly, it is a central tenet of the unwritten South American criminal code that stolen cars not delivered on time are worse than no stolen cars at all. Thus, if the psychotic middle-man cannot come up with the cars by 8am on Friday morning, he will be forever discredited in the eyes of his nefarious customers, and very likely forced to become a full-time woodworker, a talent that to date has only been his hobby. Like I said, the movie is mildly ridiculous.

Into this imbroglio steps the engaging Nicolas Cage, a recently retired car thief par excellence who was, in his heyday, the Paganini of southern Californian automotive redeployment. Cage has taken early retirement at the behest of his long-suffering mother, who worries that her younger son, Ribisi, will be so envious of Cage's grand larceny skills that he will eventually go into the same line of work. Which he does. Now Cage learns from an old confederate, played by the serviceable Will Patton, that unless he shakes off the mothballs and steals the 50 cars within the next four days, his brother will be cruelly dispatched by a slowly descending trash compactor.

Cage reluctantly agrees to steal the cars, immediately running afoul of his old nemesis Delroy Lindo, the hard-working cop who has been trying to put him in the slammer for years. A good portion of the film is now taken up by what are best described as genre compulsories: the scene where Cage tries to persuade reliable old coot Robert Duvall to serve as the sergeant-at-arms on this operation; the scene where Cage hooks up with his old flame, Angelina Jolie, who still wonders why her ex-lover bagged the car-theft game; a number of scenes where Cage goes head to head with Lindo. These stock sequences have the same seductive appeal as rock'n'roll power chords: the fact that you can see them coming from a mile away doesn't make them any less satisfactory.

In fact, it makes them more so.

No Last Gunfight film would be complete without the scene where the sheriff tells the gunslinger that this particular town isn't big enough for both of them.

Several years ago, I wrote a story for Movieline about extremely unlikely movie heroes. These included Kevin Costner as a charming kidnapper in A Perfect World, Al Pacino as a congenial drug dealer and murderer in Carlito's Way and Jean Reno as a thoroughly loveable hit man in The Professional. In Gone In 60 Seconds Cage fits very much into this same category. On the surface, car thieves would not seem to have that much appeal to the general movie-going public, as most people have cars and would prefer that they not get stolen. But Cage ultimately emerges as an extremely charismatic and even admirable figure because of the delicate moral ambiguities that suffuse this prototypical Jerry Bruckheimer production (it's all right to steal 50 cars if a horrible foreigner is threatening to murder your little brother, but it would probably not be all right to steal 50 cars if the bad man had only threatened to work him over a little).

Needless to say, Gone In 60 Seconds has some wonderful car-chase sequences and a number of good fist-fights. With the exception of the ornamental Angelina Jolie and the thoroughly unscary villain played by Christopher Eccleston, the cast is superb in the way that supporting casts in caper movies tend to be. Gone In 60 Seconds is by far the silliest motion picture of the summer season, but it is by no means the least entertaining. If films about professional car thieves who specialise in heisting vehicles favoured by upper-middle-class suburbanites are your cup of tea, I cannot recommend this movie too highly.

 Gone In 60 Seconds is out on Friday.

webTitle: Ziege to add quality to Mersey

fields.headline: Ziege to add quality to Mersey
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier confidently expects to take his Liverpool transfer spending to more than £50m this weekend by signing Middlesbrough's German international wing-back Christian Ziege.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier confidently expects to take his Liverpool transfer spending to more than £50m this weekend by signing Middlesbrough's German international wing-back Christian Ziege.

After weeks of speculation, Ziege is poised to complete a £5.5m move to the Merseyside club. "I would like to join Liverpool," he said yesterday. "They are one of the biggest club names in world football and the prospect of playing for them in next season's Uefa Cup excites me."

Though Boro's manager Bryan Robson has insisted he has no desire to see Ziege leave Teesside, the player has a contractual clause giving him the right to talk with anyone lodging a formal offer of more than £5m - something Liverpool did last weekend.

The proposed move has upset Boro supporters, who have inundated local media and the Riverside switchboard with their complaints. "We understand their frustration," Viv Anderson, Robson's assistant, said yesterday. "We are frustrated ourselves."

Robson is in Spain trying to conclude a £12m deal for the Barcelona striker Dani. Boro are also pursuing the 30-year-old Croatia striker Alen Boksic, who would cost about £2.5m from Lazio. Boro have also opened talks for Lens's Cameroon striker Joseph-Desire Job although the French club's asking price of £4m may be a problem.

If Ziege joins his fellow countrymen Dietmar Hamann and Markus Babbel at Anfield, it will push Houllier's spending on new players to around £51m since he succeeded his one-time managerial partner Roy Evans less than two years ago.

Houllier may well recoup around £2.5m before the new Premiership season by offloading the young midfielder David Thompson to Coventry.

Liverpool's club captain Jamie Redknapp is recovering in a Colorado clinic after undergoing yet more surgery on his badly damaged knee.

Although the midfielder will not be able to to resume even light training until November, he is now hopeful of resurrecting his career. "The surgeon is delighted with the way things have gone," said Houllier.

The former Borussia Dortmund coach Michael Skibbe has been appointed assistant coach of the German national team. He will be Rudi Völler's deputy until June 2001 and then work under Christoph Daum, who is currently with Bayer Leverkusen.

Alan Shearer has run into another injury problem. The striker was in action for only 22 minutes of Newcastle's two-match trip to the United States because of knee trouble.

Bobby Robson yesterday insisted it was a "minor" recurrence of the tendinitis that flared up during Euro 2000, but he added that the player was surprised it had returned after three weeks' rest.

Shearer sat out Newcastle's second game, a 2-2 draw with Columbus Crew when the £7m Carl Cort scored both goals.

Newcastle's £3.5m Argentine midfielder Christian Bassedas is likely to miss the start of the season in three weeks. He is to have an x-ray today after fears he has broken a foot bone.

Peter Reid has made his fourth summer signing for Sunderland, buying the 6ft 5in Slovakia defender Stanislav Varga for £875,000 from Slovan Bratislava, subject to a work permit.

Ade Akinbiyi has completed his protracted £5m move from Wolves to Leicester, a record for the Premiership club. Crystal Palace have signed Neil Ruddock from West Ham United for an undislosed fee and taken the 19-year-old Finland striker Mikael Forssell back on loan from Chelsea for next season.

webTitle: Victory reprieves Brazil coach

fields.headline: Victory reprieves Brazil coach
fields.standfirst: The World Cup qualifier against Argentina was make or break for Luxemburgo
fields.trailText: Brazil regained their pride with a comprehensive 3-1 defeat of Argentina, a game that was make or break for coach Wanderley Luxemburgo.
fields.body:
Brazil regained their pride with a comprehensive 3-1 defeat of Argentina in a vastly entertaining match that should give the coach Wanderley Luxemburgo a respite from calls for his dismissal.

Luxemburgo's job had been on the line after a humiliating defeat by Paraguay last week left Brazil languishing in fifth place in South America's single qualifying group. But having made six changes to the side that lost to the Paraguayans, he was vindicated almost immediately when the 22-year-old Alex headed home in the sixth minute. Two goals from Vampeta completed a cathartic night.

"Defeat is part of the competition," said a relieved Luxemburgo after the match. "It never terrified me that we lost against Paraguay. We just need to be calm, keep our feet on the ground. We showed that we respect Argentina but don't fear them.

"The victory was important because Argentina have a very strong team."

The win may have extended Luxemburgo's tenure in his job but it did not entirely win over the 80,000-capacity crowd at the Morumbi stadium. The fans' simmering antipathy bubbled to the surface when they shouted "idiot" after he substituted Alex with the defensive midfielder Cesar Sampaio.

Luxemburgo's overly formal style and poor interpersonal skills have always attracted criticism. When the team started to play badly he became the focus for national frustration. webTitle: Mabbutt heads old pros on new panel

fields.headline: Mabbutt heads old pros on new panel
fields.trailText: The former Tottenham Hotspur captain Gary Mabbutt is one of several former professional footballers who have been nominated to sit on a new disciplinary panel to examine video evidence of controversial incidents.
fields.body:
The former Tottenham Hotspur captain Gary Mabbutt is one of several former professional footballers who have been nominated to sit on a new disciplinary panel to examine video evidence of controversial incidents.

The Professional Footballers' Association has written to the Football Association nominating Mabbutt along with Brian McClair, Steve Ogrizovic, John Barnes and Brian Marwood.

Garth Crooks has also been nominated but his appointment could cause problems given the former Tottenham striker's involvement with Match of the Day. The FA has the right to reject any of the names and may feel that there is a conflict of interest with Crooks, particularly if he highlights an incident on Match of the Day and is then asked to adjudicate on it days later.

The League Managers' Association has nominated four former managers to the FA, as has the Referees' Association. The setting up of disciplinary panels was announced by the FA on Wednesday as part of a package of stern measures to stamp out bad behaviour by players and club officials.

A pool of panel members will be available to the FA but only three will sit on any one incident. The panel will only be allowed to adjudicate on incidents not seen by the referee but caught on camera, or in cases of mistaken identity.

Gordon Taylor, the PFA's chief executive, said care had been taken to ensure that its nominees had good disciplinary records during their playing careers.

He added: "Obviously you would not choose a convicted criminal to sit on a jury. This is going to be football's equivalent of a jury. We are confident that the players we have nominated have the respect of their peers. There will be a better chance of justice being seen to be done when there's a more rounded view of particular incidents with the opinions of those who have played being taken on board."

Meanwhile, the Manchester United captain Roy Keane admitted yesterday he had been "bang out of order" in leading a posse of players haranguing the referee Andy d'Urso last season. "You have to hold your hands up," he said. "When you're wrong, you're wrong. I was wrong and I think the team were wrong."

webTitle: Foreign influx to go unchecked

fields.headline: Foreign influx to go unchecked
fields.standfirst: The government refuses to seek an exemption for football from EU labour laws
fields.trailText: The government has announced that there will be no restrictions introduced to limit the number of foreign players in the domestic game.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan received the news he had been dreading last night when he learned there was no chance of restrictions being introduced to limit the number of foreign players in the domestic game.

English football will continue to be saturated by overseas players after the government effectively ended any hope of a quota being implemented, stating it would be "extremely unpopular with fans and clubs".

Despite England's dismal showing in the European Championship - and the Professional Footballers' Association echoing Keegan's reservations about the lack of opportunities for home-grown talent - the department for education and employment is unwilling to pursue a change in European law that would permit such a move.

Under the present system, with the Treaty of Rome implementing equality of opportunity and the free movement of labour throughout the European Union, the Football Association is powerless to impose its own quota.

It has reached the point where Keegan said recently that future England coaches would have to pick most of their players from the lower divisions.

Any alteration to the statute would require the unanimous agreement of every EU nation and, although the government has indicated it will contribute to any talks, it is unwilling to pursue the matter itself.

"Given that free movement of labour throughout the European Economic Area is viewed as one of the cardinal principles of the treaty, we think it unlikely that sport would be given an exemption," a department spokesman said yesterday.

England's failures in Euro 2000 prompted renewed calls throughout the game for restrictions on foreign players, with the Newcastle and former England manager Bobby Robson and the Wales and Manchester United winger Ryan Giggs among those going on record to bemoan the numbers flooding the game.

"It is very disappointing and frustrating that the government has come to this decision," Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the PFA, said yesterday.

"It seems this is a country willing to spend millions of pounds trying to stage the World Cup but is unwilling to help provide a team capable of winning it.

"To say it would be extremely unpopular among supporters is simply not true. All our surveys indicate that football fans appreciate the need for a better balance. At the moment young English players are being squeezed out and now it can only get worse."

Privately, however, senior figures at the FA had resigned themselves to the government's decision long before the official announcement yesterday.

"It is a matter of European law and there is nothing that can be done about the situation, nothing at all," said the FA spokesman Steve Double.

To alleviate the problem the FA is hoping to cut the quota of non-EU players allowed in the English game. Officials at Lancaster Gate propose that the current regulation allowing teams to field up to three non-EU players in each game should be revised so that Premiership clubs would be allowed to sign only two non-EU players, First Division clubs would be allowed only one and lower-division clubs none.

The Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson is among those pressing for such a move.

"It's our intention to hold further talks with the government because we believe there is a case for restrictions," said Double.

"Everyone within football agrees that top-quality players add to our game. The concern is over the players who do not necessarily meet those standards. The system we are putting forward would allow clubs to choose the highest standard of player possible."
