webTitle: Hurst loses his shirt to gain £180,000

fields.headline: Hurst loses his shirt to gain £180,000
fields.trailText: Sir Geoff Hurst, well remunerated this year when England lost the 2006 World Cup, is to cash in on his contribution to England's World Cup triumph. He is to sell most of his memorabilia - including the cap he won and the shirt he wore when he scored a hat-trick in the 1966 World Cup final - at a Christie's auction in September which is expected to raise more than £180,000.
fields.body:
Sir Geoff Hurst, well remunerated this year when England lost the 2006 World Cup, is to cash in on his contribution to England's World Cup triumph. He is to sell most of his memorabilia - including the cap he won and the shirt he wore when he scored a hat-trick in the 1966 World Cup final - at a Christie's auction in September which is expected to raise more than £180,000.

Christie's expects the red long-sleeved England No10 shirt that Hurst wore in the final to go for more than £20,000. His tasselled blue England cap, representing all three of his 1966 World Cup appearances, in the quarter-final, semi-final and final, should fetch more than £15,000. His 1964 FA Cup winner's medal, to be sold with an autographed programme and ticket stub, should set you back about £9,000.

Hurst is not broke, but at 58 he has decided that the collection will benefit his family more through being sold than if it were kept.

"It was always my intention to leave the entire collection to my children," he said. "But I have three daughters. How do you fairly divide up this sort of collection between them?

"I've also lost a significant part of the collection in two burglaries and as a consequence of this everything is now locked away and no one ever sees it.

"I'm as patriotic as the next Englishman and will always cherish my memories and the friendships I made in my playing days, but at this stage of my life I would rather have some control over the distribution of my medals and trophies and know that my family will benefit."

The collection has been divided into 129 lots. Hurst will donate the proceeds of 18 of the lots to two charities: the Brain and Spine Foundation and the Bobby Moore Imperial Cancer Research Fund.

He will be selling off 26 England caps, which must represent almost all of his collection. He played for England 49 times but the FA does not actually award a cap for each international.

Hurst made his England debut in a 1-0 win over West Germany at Wembley in February 1966. The World Cup final, against West Germany at Wembley five months later, was only his eighth international appearance. His last England game was also against West Germany, in a European championship quarter-final in 1972. England lost that game 3-1 at Wembley; Hurst was substituted and then left out of the return leg in Berlin.

Some of his memorabilia will not be sold off. His daughters Claire, Joanne and Charlotte and their children will keep a number of items. And Hurst himself is holding on to his World Cup winner's medal.

"I have no immediate plans for the medal," he said. "It's not in the collection because I have a gut feeling it's not the right thing to do or the right time to do it."

The Hurst collection

World Cup final No10 shirt £20,000-£30,000

World Cup finals cap £15,000-£20,000

News of the World man-of-the-match trophy £10,000-£15,000

1964 FA Cup winner's medal £9,000

1965 Cup Winners Cup winner's medal £8,000-£12,000

Football autographed by England's 1966 squad £500-£800

Menus from dinner on 30th anniversary of 1966 win £200-£500

webTitle: Graham still in the frame and spending for Spurs

fields.headline: Graham still in the frame and spending for Spurs
fields.trailText: We'll believe future success for Spurs when we see it. But if anyone can do it, George Graham can, with or without a Zimmer frame.
fields.body:
According to rumours, the manager of Tottenham Hotspur is conducting pre-season training from a wheelchair and, on his better days, with the help of a Zimmer frame. Not the sort of news to ensure swift business in the club ticket office.

Questions have been asked about how a publicly quoted Premier League club with top-five ambitions and stroppy shareholders can possibly be in the hands of a man confined to his desk rather than working shoulder-to-shoulder with high-earning and underachieving footballers. But George Graham, now in his 56th year, was in sparkling form yesterday when I caught up with him at Tottenham's training ground, their first day back after a three-match trip to Sweden and Finland.

"I don't need a Zimmer frame and I don't rattle with tablets," he said. "Some people in the media would like to see the back of me, but I'm afraid they'll be disappointed."

Graham, a fastidious man in all respects who has always prided himself on his fitness and his appearance, was struck down with a severe arthritic condition towards the end of last season and confined to a hospital bed for a short while.

"I've always kept myself in good shape by training with the players, playing tennis and golf and going for a run on my days off," he said. "Then this illness just hit me completely out of the blue. There was no warning."

Tottenham's director of football David Pleat and first-team coach Stewart Houston coaxed the players through the last throes of a disappointing campaign.

Graham added: "I've heard people say that Stewart was going to be doing all the hard graft with the players and that I was going to spend my time in a suit pushing paperclips about, but it's nonsense. I admit that I won't be taking part in the five-a-sides for a while, and that I can't play tennis as vigorously as I'd like, but I'm in my tracksuit and I'm coaching the players.

"I think you'll find that I'm one of the few managers in the Premier League who will be training with the team as closely as I'll be doing."

I'll never forget visiting Graham almost five years ago to the day, shortly after he was banned from football for 12 months over that "unsolicited gift" affair. His enormous, airy London apart- ment was spotless, orderly and opulent. His collection of malt-whisky bottles was arranged according to size and shape; his Japanese garden was straight out of a glossy magazine.

This desire for control and organisation had an immediate impact when he became Tottenham's manager after two championships with Arsenal and his time at Leeds. During the reign of his predecessor Christian Gross, the Mercs and Jags in the training-ground car park were left in haphazard fashion. Within a couple of days of Graham's arrival they were lined up as if in a car showroom. Graham acted like a powerful magnet, pulling the lumps of metal into one direction.

He had the same effect on the players. Mid-table obscurity in May was unsatisfactory. Indeed, Tottenham haven't finished in the top three since the 1980s and the Worthington Cup success two seasons ago was only their second trophy in 15 years.

Will the £11m Sergei Rebrov, the left-sided defender Ben Thatcher and his former Wimbledon colleague Neil Sullivan make this year any different? "We've got some way to go before we can match Manchester United's strength, but I feel far more optimistic now than I did this time last year," said Graham, in spite of doubts over the future of David "Two Mercs" Ginola.

"There's a lot of negative talk attached to this club which is unjustified. We haven't achieved what we set out to achieve, but we're a big club with big ideas. We have a stronger squad, we've shown we're prepared to spend money and there could be more new faces coming in."

Spurs fans will have heard it all before, of course, and we'll believe future success when we see it. But if anyone can do it, George Graham can, with or without a Zimmer frame.

webTitle: England order a rest for the best

fields.headline: England order a rest for the best
fields.standfirst: Fletcher edict means top players will miss climax of county season
fields.trailText: The EWCB could stand charged with devaluing domestic cricket if it goes ahead with plans to withdraw some international players from the climax to the county season.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board could stand charged with devaluing domestic cricket if it goes ahead with plans to withdraw some international players from the climax to the county season.

Lancashire are just one county disappointed by the decision of the England coach Duncan Fletcher that all players involved in both Tests and one-day internationals next winter will not be involved in any more cricket this season after the final Test of the summer, due to finish on September 5.

The one-day tour party for the ICC Trophy in Kenya and the one-day series in Pakistan that precedes the Test series will be announced around that time. A further tour to Sri Lanka, including a one-day series and three Tests, will start in late January.

There is, however, a human side to Fletcher's decision. The season does not finish until September 17, leaving little more than a week of domestic bliss before the first wave leaves for Kenya on September 26, not to return until December 12.

"The coach has decided that players who are awarded both Test and one-day international contracts for the winter tours will be rested," explained Andrew Walpole, England's media relations officer. "This will enable these players to spend time with their families and friends after the demands of the summer season, whom they will not otherwise see until shortly before Christmas."

But he is disappointed that leading players would not be available to their counties once the international commitments this summer had finished.

Lancashire may well lose Andrew Flintoff, although Mike Atherton, whose one-day career at international level appears over, and Chris Schofield will still be available for crucial matches in the climax to the season.

"We certainly thought all players would be released and I suppose it is another step in the direction of devaluing domestic cricket because the international season will have finished," Cumbes said. "It may be that they will look at the situation again but if not then we will just have to bite on the bullet if it is thought to be in the best interest of the top players and the England team."

Fletcher's decision would rule players out of the last two rounds of the County Championship and the National League finale. This will come as a blow to those sides who already cede players to the international season but are used to having them available at the conclusion of the Tests.

It could mean that the championship leaders Surrey will face their run-in without Alec Stewart and Graham Thorpe, and their nearest rivals Lancashire, whom they play in the last match, will be without Flintoff. Yorkshire, in third place, will be without Darren Gough, Craig White and possibly Michael Vaughan.

Chris Hassell, Yorkshire's chief executive, said: "It's disappointing. We have to ask why we play the championship? It almost brings it into disrepute if you take the best players away in the run-in when all is at stake.

"From the players' viewpoint they would not be too pleased. Darren Gough, for example would be bursting to play. We don't object to contracts because the welfare of England is uppermost but how far do you take it? The championship at that stage is important to England as well. We have to accept it, grin and bear it but it is most unsatisfactory."

webTitle: Chanderpaul's hand rules him out of Test

fields.headline: Chanderpaul's hand rules him out of Test
fields.trailText: Shivnarine Chanderpaul has been ruled out of next week's third Test against England at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Shivnarine Chanderpaul has been ruled out of next week's third Test against England at Old Trafford. The batsman, who missed the entire triangular one-day series with a tear in the tendon in his right hand, has been asked to rest for another two weeks, according to the West Indies team manager Ricky Skerritt.

"The news is not good," Skerritt said. "A scan taken has shown the tear hasn't healed properly and the specialist he saw has asked him to rest for at least two weeks."

Chanderpaul is West Indies' most influential batsman after Brian Lara, and is averaging 40.03 in his 44 Tests with his unflappable batting. He has been in tremendous form on the current tour, accumulating 401 runs with two hundreds before being sidelined with the injury.

West Indies are likely to turn to the 21-year-old Ramnaresh Sarwan, a Guyanan like Chanderpaul. Sarwan, when 15, became the youngest player to appear in first-class cricket in the West Indies, and averages 55.50 in his two Tests against Pakistan. "We'll try to fit Sarwan in the batting order," Skerritt said. "But no decision has been made yet."

Two police officers from India's Central Bureau of Investigation flew to Britain yesterday to interview the London-based Indian bookmaker Sanjay Chawla as part of their match-rigging investigation .

Chawla has previously denied any involvement in the scandal that broke in April when the then South African captain Hansie Cronje and three team-mates were charged with cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy while touring India.

webTitle: Chance chat over dinner led Blair to order u-turn on private beds

fields.headline: Chance chat over dinner led Blair to order u-turn on private beds
fields.standfirst: Private healthcare concordat was Blair initiative
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair took Cherie for dinner at the fashionable River Cafe restaurant in west London it was coincidence that a Daily Express associate editor was eating with his girlfriend at a table nearby. Their subsequent conversation set in train radical changes to NHS policy on the health private sector, writes David Hencke.
fields.byline: David Hencke, Westminster correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
When Tony Blair took Cherie for dinner at the fashionable River Cafe restaurant in west London earlier this year, it was coincidence that a Daily Express associate editor, Stephen Pollard, was eating with his girlfriend at a table nearby.

On the way out, the prime minister called the other couple over for coffee, and they began talking animatedly about the NHS bed crisis.

During the conversation Mr Blair mentioned a chap, whose name he could not remember, who had challenged him on Newsnight in February over people left on trolleys in NHS hospitals.

Mr Blair was seeking confirmation from an old colleague (Mr Pollard had been a Labour researcher when the PM had been an opposition MP) that he had not been fed a line by the private sector. The unknown man turned out to be Tim Evans, external affairs director of the Independent Healthcare Association - effectively the most powerful lobby for the 460,000 beds and 211 hospitals and nursing homes in the private sector.

Mr Evans had in essence caught out the prime minister by getting him to agree to use spare capacity in private hospitals to help out the NHS.

After the TV programme, Mr Blair went over to Mr Evans and questioned him. Mr Evans, a fast-talking postgraduate who previously worked at the free market Adam Smith Institute, gave an instant run-down of the country's private facilities, pointing out 800 high dependency beds and operating theatre facilities that were underused. He also mentioned he knew Mr Pollard, and that the NHS executive had sent out a circular making it all but impossible for the NHS to use private beds.

Mr Blair went away and did some checks. The story stood up, and it helped persuade the prime minister that he should take personal charge of the whole NHS initiative.

He then discovered that his former health secretary, Frank Dobson, had shifted the NHS's position from neutrality toward using the private sector when necessary, to one of being positively hostile.

The NHS executive annual letter sanctioned by Mr Dobson and sent to all chief executives and GPs on September 9, 1997 read: "Health authorities, GPs and NHS trusts should explore the scope to make maximum cost-effective use of local NHS capacity before contemplating recourse to private sector hospital provision. Where care is nonetheless commissioned from private hospitals, the reasons must be reported to the regional office."

The circular had made hospital trusts nervous at using beds in nearby private hospitals in the winter beds crisis. It also led to a heated but fruitless exchange between the private sector and Robert Hill, the Downing Street policy adviser, weeks before Mr Blair's appearance on Newsnight.

Within days of the River Cafe conversation, Mr Blair is understood to have ordered Alan Milburn, the health secretary, to repeal the offending letter. But that was not all. Letters were sent out to a range of leading doctors, health care companies and drug firms to come for talks at No 10 - ostensibly with the Downing Street policy unit, though most visitors were ushered straight into the PM's office.

What emerged was an instruction from Downing Street for a concordat with the private sector to be negotiated by senior civil servants at the Department of Health, who months before had dismissed the idea. The fruits of the deal were published yesterday.

The Conservatives, who condemned the NHS initiative as another spin exercise, are privately livid. Mr Blair has effectively stolen part of William Hague's common sense revolution, which would have harnessed the private sector for NHS patients.

The Tories are left promoting private health insurance - and behind the scenes the private sector is full of praise for Mr Blair.

webTitle: The week on the net

fields.headline: The week on the net
fields.trailText: Things on the web are definitely not what they used to be: tighter restrictions are starting to bite, with more court cases and further legal restrictions pending against alleged transgressors of the new e-commerce hierarchy. Last week, Napster (the MP3 music download site) was dragged into further litigation with the music industry, while scour.com, a free film site, was served with a writ by the Motion Picture Association of America for alleged copyright infringement. Sega is also preparing to take legal action against free download sites.
fields.body:
Things on the web are definitely not what they used to be: tighter restrictions are starting to bite, with more court cases and further legal restrictions pending against alleged transgressors of the new e-commerce hierarchy. Last week, Napster (the MP3 music download site) was dragged into further litigation with the music industry, while scour.com, a free film site, was served with a writ by the Motion Picture Association of America for alleged copyright infringement. Sega is also preparing to take legal action against free download sites.

Even those once-elusive hackers are ending up before the beak. Jon Johansen, the Norwegian teen idol of the hacking fraternity, was recently interrogated by Norwegian authorities and may soon have to testify in a US court case over a DVD-descrambling program he wrote. So revered is Johansen there is a webpage devoted to him.

Not even the first instalment of Stephen King's latest e-book can cheer things up. Although the book went live at www.stephenking.com on Monday, the author is waiting to see how sales develop before he bothers to finish it. King's sales ploy works thus: you can download the novel for free but you must send a dollar to King once you have read it. If fewer than 75% of readers cough up, however, King will not pen The End. Some of his more hardcore (and weirdest) fans could get very upset with the non-payers. Keep the sandbags handy. One success story has been the Channel 4 website with its new series Big Brother, a show which monitors contestants in a locked and secret location around the clock for nine weeks through webcams and CCTV. The site registered 100,000 visitors per hour on the first day and then crashed. Across the pond, things are much the same, with Big Brother and its sister programme, Survivor, proving equally huge. The same goes for those websites for addicts (survivorsucks.com and BigBrotherBlows.com) who hate the show but cannot quite live without it. Sadly, the owners of the shows could live without the websites, threatening legal action over illegal feeds. If it all sounds a tad too depressing, then turn to www.kama-sooty.co.uk, where (yep, you guessed it), Sooty, Sweep and Soo are pictured in kama sutra positions. Those who had a fond affection for Sweep should avoid this hugely popular site: revelations about what the cuddly ones have been getting up to with the lovely Soo may force you to write him out of the will. It remains unclear if their current handler intends to sue. Or should that be Soo?

fields.headline: Search Engine
fields.trailText: They are words that dare not speak their name in America, especially among the thrusting young bucks of dot.com land. But failure and pessimism are enjoying a renaissance not seen since the Dark Ages. New webzine failuremag.com takes an in-depth (and tongue-in-cheek) look at this nasty notion, listing events and business deals that infamously went awry. Last week's edition looked at Kellogg's doomed venture to sell cereal and milk in the same packet. Tasty. The site also sports a nifty catalogue of failure, dubbed the Flophouse, and even has its own souvenir shop - failure T-shirts, mugs etc. Better still, failuremag's philosophy seeks to turn the notion of success on its head, by reinterpreting triumphs, such as the Frankish victory over the Arabs at the Battle of Poitiers in AD732, which, it claims, may have set the Renaissance back about 750 years.

Follow failuremag by poring over www.BubbleEconomy.com, a cynical but intelligent site warning optimists (day traders and small investors) about just how big and scary the bubble has blown. Sticking rigidly to its philosophy and motto, "Prepare for the Pop", it provides a rundown of the latest mergers, buyouts and inflated stocks to give some "perspective on how manic the mania" has become. With sections such as "worthless press release of the day", "investment potholes" and "advice to avoid", the site is worth a look, if only to make you think twice about investing. One bright spark aiming to tweak the twin nasal hair of doom and gloom is exploiting the new entertainment medium to boost the old one. Yes, you guessed it, the village fete has gone online at www.welfordfete.org. Quaint little Welford, five miles from Stratford-upon-Avon, is there in all its web glory informing visitors of its impending fete on August bank holiday, complete with maypole, traditional tombolas, traction engines, military vehicles and face painting. A word of warning: there is no bouncy castle.

Seen any good websites lately? If so write to the.editor@theguardian.com"

webTitle: Salmond bows out with an independent air

fields.headline: Salmond bows out with an independent air
fields.trailText:
The outgoing Scottish Nationalist leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday predicted independence for Scotland
           before the 300th anniversary of the Act of Union with England in 2007 - but warned that Tony Blair may
           burn out long before then.
fields.body:
The outgoing Scottish Nationalist leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday predicted independence for Scotland before the 300th anniversary of the Act of Union with England in 2007 - but warned that Tony Blair may burn out long before then.

In a farewell Westminster press conference, the 45-year-old MP insisted he was stepping down because he was leaving the SNP in a very strong position - ahead of Labour in some polls - and 10 years was long enough for a party leader.

Mr Salmond predicted that the pace of demand for full independence from England has grown - not weakened, as Labour predicted - in the year since Scotland got its devolved parliament in Edinburgh.

But he coupled his personal optimism with a warning to the prime minister, to "chill out or get out". Unless Mr Blair "re-evaluates the way he approaches politics" and starts to ignore his pollster Philip Gould's focus groups he would not stay the course, Mr Salmond predicted.

"Tony Blair is looking dreadful, he's had just six years [as Labour leader], he won't last 10 years," he said. "The message coming back [from Mr Blair's pollsters] is that people don't like you and think you are useless. He seems to be affected by it and worried by it. He should rely on it less and look to the larger game," Mr Salmond told reporters.

His upbeat mood rests on taking a party which had three Westminster MPs and 14% of the vote when he succeeded Gordon Wilson in 1990 to 22% and six MPs in 1997 - followed by 29% and 35 MSPs elected in Edinburgh last year. "A pretty good legacy to hand over," he said.

"It's a matter of pride. If the SNP had been doing badly I would not have stood down," added Mr Salmond who refused to back either of the contestants for his post, fellow MP John Swinney and the more radical MSP Alex Neil.

But the thrust of his remarks came close to endorsing Mr Swinney whose gradualist approach is closer to his own. He noted that those who thought the Scottish parliament had done well and those who were disappointed both believe it should have greater powers.

He concluded: "Devolution has whetted the appetite for more powers and done so earlier than I would have expected".

The MP for Banff and Buchan since 1987 argued that "independence was a process not an event" and that he had made the SNP "a social democratic party in the European mainstream" with broad national appeal - one which Asian Scots, businessmen and even ex-Labour trade unionists could feel comfortable with.

"I think Scotland will become independent before the [1707] Treaty of Union celebrates its 300th anniversary. The SNP has a very good chance of winning the next [Scottish] elections [in 2003] and, if we win, of winning the referendum shortly afterwards," he predicted.

webTitle: Labour stakes credibility on 5-year NHS revolution

fields.headline: Labour stakes credibility on 5-year NHS revolution
fields.standfirst: July 28 2000: MIlburn unveils the NHS National Plan
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair yesterday staked the political credibility of a second Labour term in government on a five-year
           plan to slash NHS waiting times and create a patient-friendly health service to suit the consumerist
           values of the 21st century.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday staked the political credibility of a second Labour term in government on a five-year plan to slash NHS waiting times and create a patient-friendly health service to suit the consumerist values of the 21st century.

He promised to recruit 7,500 more consultants by 2005, along with 2,000 extra GPs, more than 20,000 extra nurses and at least 6,750 more therapists and other health professionals.

The national plan for health in England will create 7,000 extra NHS beds by 2004, including the first increase in numbers of general and acute wards for nearly 30 years. Modernisation of primary care will include the creation of 500 one-stop centres, combining GPs, dentists, opticians and other health care and social care professionals under one roof.

The investment will be supported by a 35% real terms increase in NHS resources over four years - double the historic trend of growth in health spending. Ministers said lack of money was no longer the problem and the key tests of delivery would now be how fast they can recruit trained staff and how well they can retain them.

The plan is specific enough in its objectives to create many hostages to Labour's fortune if the NHS does not deliver.

Mr Blair told MPs: "By 2005 the maximum waiting time for an outpatient will be three months and for an in-patient six months, rather than the present 18 months."

Average waiting times would be cut from seven to five weeks for outpatients and from three months to seven weeks for operations. The eventual objective "is to get the maximum waiting time for any stage of treatment down to three months by the end of 2008". Other targets include a commitment that by 2002 all patients will be able to see a primary care professional within 24 hours and a GP within two days.

Alan Milburn , the health secretary, said the 144-page national plan was "the most fundamental and far-reaching reform programme", addressing every one of the problems facing the NHS. "From the state of the wards to the doctor's contract, not one issue has been ducked."

The proposals include steps to break down the boundaries between the health professions, expanding the responsibilities of nurses, midwives and therapists.

Changes for NHS doctors will include a new consultants' contract linked to annual appraisal of their work. Newly qualified consultants will be obliged to work exclusively for the NHS for seven years, but after that they will be allowed to undertake private practice in their own time.

There will be a nationwide clean-up campaign of wards and six-monthly undercover inspections of hospital cleanliness. Hospitals will be set tough performance targets linked to extra cash and those who fail will be taken over and run by a management hit squad.

Early reaction from the NHS professions, managers and patients suggested there would be strong support for the general direction of reform, but months of in-fighting over the detail.

The plan included a preface signed by 25 leaders of organisations on which its delivery will depend, welcoming its "direction of travel". They included representatives of the British Medical Association, Royal College of Nursing and the NHS Confederation, representing the managers.

But Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA consultants committee, said proposals for changing the consultants contract showed "profound lack of understanding of the work they do". After two years of discussion, the government's only new idea was "an ill-conceived, vindictive attack on new consultants' freedom to work outside the NHS".

There was also bitter disappointment among organisations representing older people about the government's decision to reject the royal commission's recommendation that the NHS should pay for personal care in residential homes. Although the government will increase spending on care for older people by pounds 1.4bn, services such as bathing and changing dressings will continue to attract means-tested charges.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said the plan was full of half-truths. "This was a wonderful opportunity for Tony Blair to move from political to clinical priorities. Unforgivably, he has put his own political survival before the survival of patients."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing congratulated the government on "a survival plan that puts patients first and tackles the hardest issues facing the health service".

"We're optimistic because every good idea in the plan is already happening somewhere in the health service. These ideas work and with the right support and opportunities, nurses and doctors will turn them into a reality for all patients."

The president of the Royal College of Physicians, Professor Sir George Alberti, said the plan was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity At last we have government recognition of the shortage of doctors and beds in England and a commitment to tackle these problems".

webTitle: Concorde crash death toll rises to 114

fields.headline: Concorde crash death toll rises to 114
fields.trailText: French investigators have discovered the body of a fifth victim buried under the rubble of a hotel that was destroyed when an Air France Concorde crashed earlier this week, raising the death toll to 114, the French transport ministry said today.
fields.body:
French investigators have discovered the body of a fifth victim buried under the rubble of a hotel that was destroyed when an Air France Concorde crashed earlier this week, raising the death toll to 114, the French transport ministry said today.

The body of the victim has not been identified and the gender was not known. Four other people died on the ground, all of them employees of the hotel. All 109 people on board the supersonic jet died.

The plane crashed on Tuesday shortly after taking off from Charles de Gaulle airport.

webTitle: Ives: Symphony No 4

fields.headline: Ives: Symphony No 4
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Ives' Symphony No 4
fields.body:
Though this work was not performed in a complete version until almost 50 years after most of it was written, Charles Ives's Fourth was the first symphonic masterpiece by an American composer.

It was the summation of everything he had been striving for through the previous 20 years some of the material in it dates back to his student days at Yale in the 1890s. In that crowded, all-American musical world Ives's radical experiments finally came to fruition. The use of several ensembles playing together in different keys and different tempi created vast musical vistas made up of intricately meshed contrapuntal lines. Hymn tunes and songs were integrated, not as quotations but as raw material to be transformed and fragmented in a multitude of ways. The way in which the Fourth Symphony is constructed owes very little to traditional 19th-century norms, but it is truly symphonic and truly original, and that radical originality cast a spell over subsequent generations of American composers even though they were unable to hear it in the concert hall.

Though the first two of the four movements were performed as early as 1927, the daunting scale of the symphony - scored for chorus, solo piano and organ as well as full orchestra - and the sheer difficulty of mastering all its polyrhythmic complexities, as well as the chaotic state of the manuscript itself, deterred conductors from attempting the premiere of the full score until Leopold Stokowski took it on in 1965.

Stokowski's subsequent recording (Sony Classical) remains one of the best in the catalogue: rugged and uncompromising if a bit rough around the edges, and communicating all the power and massiveness of what was then a virtually unknown work. But his version is now more than 30 years old, and the Fourth Symphony demands the best possible recording to unravel all its layers. There's a very decent account by Christoph von Dohnanyi with the Cleveland Orchestra, which has just been reissued by Decca on a double-CD set that includes all the Ives symphonies as well as the two orchestral sets, but the version by Michael Tilson Thomas and the Chicago Symphony just outpoints it. Coupled with the First Symphony, Thomas's recording is the first to use the critical edition of the score of the Fourth published in 1989, which painstakingly sorted out all Ives's revisions, while it also has real energy and excitement about it. Ives's greatest work still needs that kind of missionary zeal.

Key recording: Tilson Thomas, Sony Classical 44939

webTitle: Irish police chiefs in talks over arms smuggling bid

fields.headline: Irish police chiefs in talks over arms smuggling bid
fields.trailText: Ireland's top two policemen had talks in Dublin today about a bid by dissident hardline Irish republicans opposed to the Northern  Ireland peace process to smuggle in arms from Croatia.
fields.body:
Ireland's top two policemen had talks in Dublin today about a bid by dissident hardline Irish republicans opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process to smuggle in arms from Croatia.

Garda Siochana commissioner Pat Byrne and Royal Ulster Constabulary chief Sir Ronnie Flanagan met following confirmation that a weapons consignment bound for breakaway terrorist factions had been intercepted in the Adriatic coastal city of Split.

An undisclosed number of men were arrested by the Croatian authorities, and another man was in Irish police custody in Monaghan, close to the border with Northern Ireland.

The arms haul included rocket launchers, anti-tank machine guns, ammunition, plastic explosive and detonating cord and equipment. Similar weapons were discovered in the Irish Republic in October 1999, indicating that earlier shipments from Croatia may have reached Ireland.

The weapons in the latest find are thought to have been en route to a group linked to both the Real IRA and Continuity IRA breakaway republican paramilitary groups.

The Real IRA, who are officially observing the ceasefire, were responsible for the bomb attack in Omagh, County Tyrone, two years ago that left 29 people dead and more than 200 injured. Their allies in Continuity IRA, the alleged military wing of Republican Sinn Fein, who split from the mainline party over its increasingly political stance in 1986, have been thought to be behind a series of other incidents.

Irish police special branch officers went to Split soon after the weapons find and arrests - which followed months of activity by detectives in Croatia - to aid investigations by their eastern European counterparts, and tonight further arrests in Ireland were expected.

Cash for the arms is reckoned to have been raised through smuggling cigarettes and other goods by gangs on both sides of the Irish border. The weapons found in Split were estimated to be worth hundreds of thousands of pounds.

webTitle: Transfers, Transfers, and More transfers

fields.headline: Transfers, Transfers, and More transfers
fields.trailText: DOUBLE TROUBLE
fields.body:
DOUBLE TROUBLE

He was Emmanuel Petit. Yes, Arsenal have agreed to sell their pony-tailed hunk to Barcelona, along with Marc Overmars (guess he'll never get a nickname now) for a fee believed to be in the region of £25m or .393 MegaEuros. The news was broken by Overmars on his website ( www.icons.com) this morning, before jetting out to Spain where he is expected to be unveiled like some kind of nun tomorrow morning. Mysteriously, however, He Was's site ( www.emmanuelpetit.com) was telling a very different story.

"I certainly intend to make history at the Nou Camp. It's been a fantastic three years for me at Highbury, now for the next chapter in my career," said Overmars in the way only footballers can. Meanwhile He Was's site revealed: "I sincerely enjoyed American Beauty, and was very happy that it was awarded so many Oscars in Hollywood."

Overmars, who believed he had cost £25m by himself, went on: "Although the fee has nothing to do with me, all the same it is flattering to be the subject of such a high fee, which I believe is the highest in Dutch football history." But while he was saying this, He Was could only implore his readers to "Treat yourself to my official site t-shirt." What does he (was) mean by this? We demand answers!

The Fiver is of the mind that Arsene's Arsenal Wenger has done another piece of smooth piece of business in shipping on two players who, as much as we admire them on their day, are injury-prone and hardly seemed to be bursting with commitment last season. What's more Wenger has made a 200% profit on the pair he brought in for under £10m three years ago. Now he's got another £25m to spend - anyone for Steve McManaman?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

I'M SO INTER YOU

Robbie Keane packed up his toothbrush, his hair gel, and a copy of "How to do somersaults in Italian" this morning and headed off to the airport. His destination: Milan, for a meeting with Internazionale officials over a £12m transfer. The point: not entirely sure, unless Robbie actually enjoys sitting on benches for six months before being played out of position for one game and then farmed out to a smaller Serie A side before being sold back to England at a reduced rate. Which he might.

The talented 20-year-old striker, whom the Imperial Lord Ferg would pay £500,000 for, has had Inter drooling on their loafers recently. The deadline for Champions League registration is August 3 and Inter rate Keane as a better buy than Lazio's chubby greaser Marcelo Salas. So managing director Gabriele Oriali has been on the case this week trying to push through a deal, even if it involved interrupting Cov chairman Bryan Richardson's holiday. "We are aware that Mr Richardson is on holiday," Oriali told a right-lurching redtop, "but there is such a thing as a telephone."

Richardson must have decided it was good to talk, because Keane appeared to be on his way out of Highfield Road today. "Robbie came into the training ground this morning," a club spokesman said, "But he left early to speak to his agent and is now going to Italy to talk with Inter Milan." In which case it looks like Robbie will be plying his trade at the San Siro next season, along with Ronaldo, Vieri, Sukur, Recoba, Zamorano, Mutu, Baggio, and Pirlo. Good luck.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"There has to come a point where we have to say enough is enough. Either you want to come and play for us or you want to stay where you are." While the rest of the world goes transfer bonkers, John Gregory issues yet more ultimatums to players who don't fancy a move to Villa. Today, it's David Ginola's turn.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DIDDLED BY DIDIER

For the past year special agent 00-Didier Deschamps has been living a strange double life. During his day-job he did little more than sit in the Chelsea midfield, with his "look at me" strut, doing sweet rien. But when country called, 00-Didier suddenly became midfield général No.1, complete with crunching tackles and super human stamina. Something was obviously not right in SW6, and it clearly wasn't just the presence of Dennis Wise (or his secret bar of Kryptonite).

So it wasn't the biggest surprise in the world ever when Valencia announced today that they had ensnared Deschamps in a £2.3m deal. But was Chelsea chief executive Colin Hutchinson happy or sad to see the back of the Frenchman? We're still not sure. Chelsea were "sorry to see him go" Hutch said. They had done so "reluctantly" he said. And Deschamps had - Hutch insisted - left for personal reasons. "It certainly wasn't that he didn't like Chelsea or that he didn't like English football," he said. Of course it wasn't, and it would be most unfair for the Fiver to bring up Deschamp's recent interview with L'Equipe where he claimed: "I feel frustrated by Chelsea's way of playing and English football in general."

Hutchinson went on to claim that the move was "a fair deal for Chelsea". A fair deal for Chelsea? Last year they bought Deschamps for £3.5m - which means they've made a not-insubstantial £1.2m loss in 12 months. Not bad for a player you were reluctant to sell. Then again, these things are relative - especially when you've just sold Chris Sutton for £4m less than you paid for him

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

You've had your lot for today.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Argentine international Fernando Redondo has signed for AC Milan in a £11m deal. But confusion exists about whether he actually wanted a move or not. According to Real Madrid the transfer came about "as a result of the express desire of the player". But during a dramatic press conference earlier today, Redondo denied he had ever pined for a move.

Reading from a prepared script, the 31 year-old said: "I refuse to allow this stain on my name and my image. It really hurts that Real have tried to confuse the fans by claiming it was my 'express desire' to leave. That is not true and I refuse to allow my honour to be put in doubt."

Many people believe Real president Florentino Perez decided to cash in on Redondo because he supported his rival Lorenzo Sanz in the recent presidential elections. But Redondo needed a police escort to shield him from angry Real fans after returning to the Madrid to collect his things - after Spanish daily Marca revealed the Argentinean had actually signed the contract first.

Fifa have yet to decide whether South Africa will be allowed to take their failed 2006 World Cup bid to arbitration - despite yesterday's claims that the decision by Fifa development division director Walter Gagg that "the decision was final".

Wes Brown and Jesper Blomqvist will return from injury either during Manchester United's friendly against York City at Bootham Crescent tomorrow or during Sunday's trip to Shrewsbury.

Jamie Redknapp's knee operation in Colorado on Wednesday has been declared a success by Liverpool - but he is still likely to be out until the new year.

Belgian international defender Joos Valgaeren was today unveiled as Celtic manager Martin O'Neill's second signing for the club after a £3.8m move from Dutch outfit Roda JC. The 24-year-old passed his medical and put pen to paper on a five-year contract. He now looks set to make his debut in their Premier League opener at Dundee United on Sunday having trained with his new team-mates this morning.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

British Eurosport: Football: Live (9pm) A football match. Live. Between Sporting Lisbon and Parma. Should be quite good then. We think.

Sky Sports 1: International Football (2am) If you really want to see the official film of the 1970 World Cup Final again, now's your chance.

webTitle: Race row as rightwinger joins Tory home affairs team

fields.headline: Race row as rightwinger joins Tory home affairs team
fields.standfirst:
MP once advocated voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday prompted a new row over race relations when he gave a job on the Tory shadow home affairs team to a rightwing MP who once advocated the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday prompted a new row over race relations when he gave a job on the Tory shadow home affairs team to a rightwing MP who once advocated the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people.

In a move which was condemned by Labour and the Liberal Democrats, the former Monday Club member John Bercow was given a key slot on the frontbench working alongside Ann Widdecombe.

As a rightwinger in the 1980s Mr Bercow argued for the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people, the repeal of the Race Relations Act and the abolition of the commission for racial equality.

His promotion overshadowed the appointment of Steve Norris as a Tory vice-chairman in charge of recruiting more people from Britain's ethnic minorities.

His appointment was designed to appeal to voters on the centre ground who were encouraged by his moderate language on race relations during the London mayoral election.

Mr Hague's new home affairs spokesman, who will have a say in the Tories' race relations policies, was secretary to the immigration and repatriation committee of the Monday Club in the early 1980s and wrote up the minutes of a committee meeting which called for voluntary repatriation.

He wrote: "It was formally agreed that the policy of the committee should be: an end to New Commonwealth and Pakistan immigration, a properly financed system of voluntary repatriation, the repeal of the Race Relations Act and the abolition of the commission for racial equality. Particular emphasis on repatriation."

The appointment of the rightwinger was condemned last night by Labour and the Liberal Democrats. Simon Hughes, the Lib Dem home affairs spokesman, said last night: "John Bercow's appointment to look after the civil liberties of the nation is dangerous and very worrying. A Tory home affairs team led by Ann Widdecombe and with John Bercow following behind is hardly the inheritance of the One Nation tradition."

Mr Bercow last night stood by his comments, saying that he believed at the time that the scale of immigration was "difficult to accommodate". However, he insisted that he no longer supported any of the arguments outlined in his memorandum.

Pointing out that he had only been a member of the Monday Club for 18 months between 1981 and 1983, Mr Bercow said that it was "breathtaking tripe and stupid" to link him with outdated views.

"I was a member of the Monday Club which I left many years ago," he said.

"Senior members of the Labour frontbench were also card-carrying members of CND until recently."

Mr Bercow, an admirer of Enoch Powell, said that he now opposed voluntary repatriation and supported the Race Relations Act and the commission for racial equality. "I believe that in a fair society if you start identifying volunteers to leave that can turn nasty," he said.

Mr Norris, in his new job, will take over responsibility for the Tory culture unit, designed to reach out to members of ethnic minorities.

"Any party that wants to be seen as a truly national party has got to appeal to 100% of the population, be they straight, gay, black or white," he said. "William Hague feels that I can articulate that."

Mr Norris, who will play a central role in the Tories' general election campaign, will have to work with Tim Collins, another vice chairman, who attempted to block him standing as the Tory candidate for London mayor.

webTitle: A slap in the face for opponents of corporal punishment?

fields.headline: A slap in the face for opponents of corporal punishment?
fields.standfirst: The conviction of headteacher Marjorie Evans for slapping a 10-year-old boy highlights our double-standards when it comes to hitting children, writes Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor.
fields.trailText: Friday, 1.30pm:A headteacher's conviction for slapping a pupil highlights our double-standards when it comes to hitting children, writes Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor.
fields.body:
"He was giving you a torrid time that morning and I'm quite satisfied that despite your years of training you simply snapped and lost your temper." The magistrate who sentenced headteacher Marjorie Evans to a three-month suspended sentence (plus £2,250 costs) today told her she had failed the 10-year-old boy whom she slapped and "failed your honourable profession".

Unless she commits another offence, which seems unlikely, Ms Evans will not go to jail. But she will probably never teach again. At first glance, her conviction seems to illustrate the sea-change in attitudes towards corporal punishment, which was abolished in the state sector 14 years ago - although teachers at private schools were still allowed to administer canings until last year. But what Marjorie Evans did was nothing to do with corporal punishment. According to the defence, she restrained the boy when he tried to punch and headbutt her; according to the prosecution, she lost her temper and lashed out.

In short, she found herself in the same situation as almost any parent when they are faced with an unruly and uncooperative charge. Whether she hit the child or not, many of the parents at the school support her. She has received hundreds of cards from well-wishers.

Her sympathisers know that the frustrations of controlling badly-behaved children can be enormous. Readers of DH Lawrence's The Rainbow may recall the vivid scene when the young, inexperienced student teacher Ursula beats one of her pupils in a desperate attempt to subdue him. It works. The students, muted by fear, are never the same again.

A recent survey showed that more than half of all parents believe schools should bring back the cane. Moves to make it illegal for parents to hit their children have revealed a worrying double-standard: they do not believe smacking children works, but nor do they think it should be banned. It's all about the definition of violence. Smacking? That's nothing. Slapping? Understandable. Caning? If it's supervised and controlled... Hitting? That's a different matter.

And that's what makes it so difficult to define criminal assault - and so easy to convict those accused of it. Like the Tony Martin case, in which self-defence also played a key part in the defence, this one may run and run. It won't stop until we work out whether a teacher's momentary loss of control constitutes violence, punishment or a forgivable lapse.

webTitle: Robbie Keane leaves for Italy

fields.headline: Robbie Keane leaves for Italy
fields.trailText: Robbie Keane will fly to Italy tomorrow to open talks with Inter Milan about a £12m move.
fields.body:
Robbie Keane will fly to Italy tomorrow to open talks with Inter Milan about a £12m move.

Coventry confirmed today that talks with the Serie A side over the 20-year-old Republic of Ireland striker were at an advanced stage and a fee was close to being agreed.

A Coventry spokesman said: "Robbie came into the training ground this morning but left early to speak to his agent and is now going to Italy to talk with Inter Milan."

Sky Blues manager Gordon Strachan admitted Inter's interest in the former Wolves star for the first time this morning, and stressed he would do everything possible to keep him. "There has been contact made, but at the moment we don't really know how far things are going" he added.

But Inter's managing director Gabriele Oriali is already in the process of finalising a deal with Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson, who is on a golfing holiday in the United States.

webTitle: Deschamps to join Valencia

fields.headline: Deschamps to join Valencia
fields.trailText: Chelsea's French international midfielder Didier Deschamps has joined last season's European Cup finalists Valencia.
fields.body:
Chelsea's French international midfielder Didier Deschamps has joined last season's European Cup finalists Valencia.

A spokesman for the Spanish side confirmed today that he will complete a £2.3m move on Monday.

The Frenchcaptain asked the Blues for a move after to failing to settle comfortably into English football. Managing director Colin Hutchison said he sanctioned the sale of Deschamps with regret because he believed the Frenchman still had plenty to offer Chelsea as a player or, in future, as a coach.

Hutchinson said: "Didier is a great professional and still a very good player as he proved in Euro 2000. Perhaps because the length of time he spent in Italy, he didn't adapt to the English game as well as he would have liked last season, but I still believe, if he had stayed at Chelsea, he would have done better in the coming season.

"He sat down with me three months before the end of the season and explained his reasons, which were personal. It certainly wasn't that he didn't like Chelsea or that he didn't like English football.

"But he said, if the right opportunity came, would we allow him to go. Reluctantly, I agreed to that."

Valencia have taken advantage of Deschamp's uncertainty to bring him to Spain. Runners-up in last season's Champions League, the club are back in the competition next season after finishing third in the Primera Liga, and were eager to replace some of the stars who have left this summer.

Claudio Lopez has moved to Lazio in a mega-bucks deal and young midfielder Gerard looks destined for Barcelona. Deschamps will link up with Slovenian midfield star Zlatko Zahovic, who has joined Valencia from Olympiakos.

Chelsea also revealed tha they had agreed the £800,000 sale of Dan Petrescu to Southampton, but the deal collapsed when the Romanian international failed to agree personal terms.

Hutchinson said: "He's a Chelsea player and under contract to Chelsea, but we've made it clear by accepting an offer from Southampton that, provided, we can do a deal with the club, we are prepared to let Dan go."

webTitle: Film

fields.headline: Film
fields.trailText:
1. Dancer in the Dark
Lars Von Trier's mischievous, showy Palme d'Or winner, a fantasy drama about a partially blind factory worker, played by Bjork, who takes refuge in her own musical dream world.
fields.body:
1. Dancer in the Dark
Lars Von Trier's mischievous, showy Palme d'Or winner, a fantasy drama about a partially blind factory worker, played by Bjork, who takes refuge in her own musical dream world.

2. In the Mood for Love
Substantial, deeply felt film from Wong Kar-Wei, a wonderfully performed and nuanced tale of unconsummated love set in 60s Hong Kong. Maggie Cheung and Tony Leung saturate the screen with delicate erotic yearning.

3. The House of Mirth
Terence Davies' adaptation of the Edith Wharton novel, far removed from this director's usual idiom, starring Gillian Anderson and Dan Aykroyd.

4. Nurse Betty
Neil LaBute's Walter Mitty-esque black comedy starring Renee Zellweger as a nurse who, traumatised by the murder of her husband, heads west to work in the fictional hospital in her favourite soap.

5. Titus
Julie Taymor's audacious and confident reading of one of Shakespeare's bloodiest and most bizarre plays.

6. Anatomie
Horror from new-wave German film-maker Stefan Ruzowitsky. Franka Polente (from Run Lola Run) plays a medical student told to dissect the corpse of a young man she had met the previous day.

7. The King is Alive
Directed by Kristian Levring, the fourth in the Dogme series of neo-realist film-making is a variant on King Lear.

8. Timecode 2000
A British film shot in something approaching the spirit of Dogme from Mike Figgis, a split-screen experiment with four continuous, simultaneous takes about characters whose lives interleave and intermix.

9. Amores Perros
Mexican award-winner at Cannes consisting of three interlocking stories told with brutal intelligence.

10. Faithless
Liv Ullman directs, from a script by Ingmar Bergman, a film that investigates the agonies of a dying marriage.

webTitle: Maze emptied as terrorist prisoners walk free

fields.headline: Maze emptied as terrorist prisoners walk free
fields.trailText: The Maze prison was almost empty tonight - just 15 inmates were left inside the 800 cells. By the end of the year most will have been released or transferred elsewhere and the top security prison finally shut down.
fields.body:
The Maze prison was almost empty tonight - just 15 inmates were left inside the 800 cells. By the end of the year most will have been released or transferred elsewhere and the top security prison finally shut down.

The H Blocks emptied in just three hours today as the government freed the last big batch of 78 prisoners under the early release terms of the Good Friday Agreement. A further seven were let out of Maghaberry Prison a few miles away across County Antrim and one from Magilligan Jail in County Londonderry.

In all, 428 terrorists, including 143 serving life sentences, had been released since the scheme began 22 months ago. Mass killers and bombers, many responsible for the worst atrocities during 30 years of violence in the province, walked free today to be welcomed by cheering supporters.

IRA men, UDA and UFF men, men from the UVF, LVF and INLA, they all walked. The prison service made sure the releases were phased and that republicans and loyalists did not bump into each other in the car parks of the high security prison. Indeed, they ensured rival loyalists were kept well apart from each other.

It was a day of contrasts, restraint from loyalists and celebration by republicans. The UVF were the first men out and were nearly missed by their supporters. They scurried away without comment, most hiding their faces from the cameras, and were met by small groups of men also sheltering behind baseball caps, scarves and dark glasses.

IRA men walked out smiling as they were greeted by jubilant wives, mothers, children and supporters. Champagne corks popped, party streamers were thrown and confetti sprinkled on the men as they emerged through the turnstiles of the grey corrugated iron fences. It was more akin to a wedding than a prison release. The IRA's commanding officer in the prison, Jim McVeigh, was the only prisoner to speak during the releases. He said his men left the Maze "proud republicans, unbowed and unbroken".

As several dozen men waited around the prison turnstiles before their release, the inmates emerged unexpectedly through an almost invisible door in the fencing and were halfway to their waiting cars before their supporters realised they were out and started cheering. The cars sped off in convoy, only to get stuck in a traffic jam in the narrow country lane outside.

UFF and UDA supporters, carrying flags emblazoned with the message "Simply the Best" were kept in a separate car park on the other side of a 10 foot high fence. The rival groups eyed each other suspiciously but did not speak.

Former UVF commander Johnny Adair, himself freed early from the Maze a few months ago, greeted the emerging prisoners. "My friends and comrades are home to their families," he said. "I hope it is the end of the conflict, end of the Maze - no more suffering, no more pain and no more young men having to go back to jail."

Recognising the hurt felt by the victims of terrorist violence there were no triumphal speeches on any side. Both republicans and loyalists said the prisoners were also victims. William Smith, ex-loyalist prisoner and prisons spokesman for the Progressive Unionist Party, which represents the UVF, said: "We acknowledge the release of prisoners today will not be welcomed by everyone and we understand and sympathise with that view. It is not our intention to glorify this occasion."

Looking at the prison he added: "These barbed wire fences and gun towers tell a very grim and brutal story that many in our society choose to ignore. Only those who have experienced that grey and gruesome world of confinement can truly understand the hardships and suffering it can bring."

Gerry Kelly, the Sinn Fein member of the Northern Ireland Assembly who as an IRA man was jailed for the Old Bailey bombing and who escaped from the Maze in 1983, said: "All the prisoners here are victims." Mr Kelly shook the hands of each of the 46 IRA men released. He said that republicans, including prisoners, were committed to a political strategy rather than arms conflict. "I was in jail and I am no threat to anybody," he said.

But protestant victims of republican violence in South Armagh took their protests to the releases to the prison gates. William Frazer, of Families Acting for Innocent Relatives, erected a large map of South Armagh outside the prison gates dotted with hundreds of coloured markers representing IRA victims murdered in the region.

"We have prisoners getting out here today who are serial killers, who believe they have the right to murder people in the name of their cause," said Mr Frazer, who lost his father, two uncles, two cousins and many friends in the conflict.

Within months, with the freeing or transfer of the handful of remaining inmates, the Maze will be closed. It will bring down the curtain on a chapter of Northern Ireland's history during which the prison often dominated events in the outside world.

All the main terrorist groups still have the odd member behind the Maze bars. Three of the eight H Blocks in the 800 cell prison are already closed. The prison service is understood to be planning to talk to the remaining inmates to see whether they can be housed in a single block and a further four closed down.

Inmates would still need to be segregated. Three of those who remain are INLA men who murdered the LVF leader Billy Wright inside the jail in December 1997. Two more are LVF murderers who would have been free today had they not been charged with attempting to murder a man in their home town while on 48 hours pre-release parole earlier this month.

webTitle: Furious Redondo joins Milan for £11m

fields.headline: Furious Redondo joins Milan for £11m
fields.trailText: AC Milan have signed Real Madrid midfielder Fernando Redondo for £11m, according to the Spanish club's website.
fields.body:
AC Milan have signed Real Madrid midfielder Fernando Redondo for £11m, according to the Spanish club's website.

"Real Madrid would like to officially announce the agreement reached today between Fernando Redondo and AC Milan," read a statement issued on the Real website (http://www.realmadrid.es/es/home.htm)

"This transfer has come about as a result of the expressed desire of the player and Real Madrid will receive £11.25 million."

But the 31 year-old Argentinean international hit back at Real's claims during a dramatic press conference earlier today. Reading from a prepared script, Redondo said: "I refuse to allow this stain on my name and my image."

"I want to give you the facts. The only details I knew about this transfer I read in the newspapers. Nobody from Real Madrid contacted me to tell me what was happening until Wednesday night.

"Then I was told that Milans offer was very interesting for the club and a fee had been agreed. I was told that this information had already been passed to my agent. I phoned him and he confirmed that he had spoken to Milan and that the deal was agreed.

"I understood the situation but it was not my decision to leave. The club wanted me to go and I was in an impossible situation.

"It really hurts that Real have tried to confuse the fans by claiming it was my "expressed desire" to leave. That is not true and I refuse to allow my honour to be put in doubt. This has been done to stain my name and my image."

Earlier this week, Redondo had insisted he wanted to remain at Madrid: "I have a contract until 2003 and I'm not thinking of changing club," he said. "If there is anything more to this, I don't know about it - and I'd prefer not to know."

"The fact that I have been at this club for six years says a lot. I have so many ties here - and not only professional ones - so I can't even think about going to Italy. I want to stay. If it depended on me alone, of course I would stay."

And Real manager Vicente del Bosque had also made it crystal clear that he wanted Redondo to stay. On Wednesday he rejected Milan's £10.5m bid for the player, and told reporters: "There are always rumours during the summer but I am in no doubt that my relationship with Redondo is going to continue," he said.

"Nobody is irreplaceable, but I will always have Fernando. The player is smiling, he seems very content and he is working very well. He is a great professional."

But Real's new president Florentino Perez was desperate to cash in on the 31-year-old, who - perhaps tellingly - backed his defeated rival Lorenzo Sanz in the recent presidential race, and negotiations appear to have gone on without Redondo or Del Bosque's consent.

Fans were quick to show their disgust as news of the transfer filtered out. Earlier today over 150 supporters gathered outside the Bernabeu to protest, carrying banners reading "Redondo is untouchable," "We won't swap Figo for Redondo", "Redondo is Madrid" and "Learn Florentino, no one sells Redondo."

webTitle: The war on drugs

fields.headline: The war on drugs
fields.standfirst: The government has announced plans to spend an extra £3.5bn on its 'war against drugs'. Sarah Hall explains why
fields.trailText: The government has announced plans to spend £3.5bn on its "war against drugs". We explain why.
fields.body:
Why are drugs in the news again?
The government today announced that it would be channelling "substantial" extra funding in its "war against drugs" - with a further £3.5bn to be spent over the next four years.

This sum is in addition to the £1.4bn of government money set aside each year, and £237m put into the fight when the former West Yorkshire chief constable Keith Hellawell was appointed drugs tsar in 1998.

How will this new sum be broken down?
A total of £700m will be spent this year; £870m in 2001-2; £931m in 2002-3; and £996m in 2003-4 - in real terms a 10% increase each year.

The money will be divided up into treating addicts, educating young people into the dangers of addiction, working in the community and reducing availability - in part by tackling the supply from abroad.

Critics had feared the majority would be spent on tackling drugs abroad - following Tony Blair's renewed call last weekend for increased worldwide cooperation on the problem at the G8 summit.

The amount spent on prevention in this country will double by the end of the four years to £120m, while funding for treatment - seen as a high priority by the government - will increase by almost 60% to £401m.

Why is tackling drugs being given such prominence?
Abuse of illegal drugs is responsible for between 1,000 and 3,000 deaths a year. It is a significant cause of up to a third of all crimes. And it also costs Britain more than £4bn each year in crime, sickness and absenteeism.

Moreover, drug abuse is burgeoning in some areas: The last British crime survey, covering 1996-8, revealed a threefold increase in the use of cocaine, a class-A drug, among those aged 15-29 - and the drugs tsar has recently spoken of this problem spiralling as the drug becomes more accessible - and cheaper than the current £50 a gram.

"In the next two years, we are going to see a further increase. It's becoming cheaper and more socially acceptable," he said. "Clearly this is bad news for someone like me in this job."

Political commentators also argue that Labour, having won the election on a tough law-and-order ticket, has to be seen to be tough on drugs since they are so closely linked to crime. As well as a third of all recorded property crime being linked to drugs, in some areas a quarter of all offenders arrested by police have tested positive for heroin, with one in 10 being on cocaine or crack.

Drug abuse also places a huge burden on the welfare state and is intrinsically linked to social problems such as homelessness. Recent studies show that more than half of all the homeless population use drugs regularly.

But surely not all drugs are so harmful?
Controversy still rages over the health risks posed by smoking the Class B drug cannabis, with the cabinet enforcer Mo Mowlam - announcing today's new funding alongside Mr Hellawell - recently admitting to inhaling the drug as a student. The drugs tsar himself privately favouring depenalisation - whereby offenders would face only a fine and not a prison sentence.

Earlier this year, an independent report by the Police Federation - viewed as tantamount to a royal commission - called for a relaxation of the drugs laws to stop ecstasy and cannabis users being jailed. Just this month, a key government advisor, the Labour peer Lord Haskins, said cannabis should be legalised and harder drugs made more readily available on prescription as part of medical programmes to treat addicts.

But government policy remains intrangible, with the home secretary, Jack Straw, taking a tough line on illegal substances, and refusing to countenance any relaxation of the laws governing hard drugs. He is also opposed to the decriminalisation of cannabis - let alone its legalisation.

However, it is expected the thrust of the new money will be spent on tackling the availability class A drugs such as cocaine and heroin.

And how do they intend to do this?
By working with customs and excise to curb the flood of drugs from the likes of Pakistan, Columbia, the Balkans and Bulgaria, and by setting stringent targets : according to the Mr Hellawell's aims, the availability of drugs on the streets should be reduced by 25% by 2005, and 50% by 2008.

webTitle: Style: Louisa Young on the return of all things matronly and middle-aged

fields.headline: Something frumpy this way comes
fields.standfirst: It is the only thing left in the wardrobe that hasn't been revived a million times already. But does it work as a fashion statement?  Louisa Young on the return of all things matronly and middle-aged
fields.trailText: It is the only thing left in the wardrobe that hasn't been revived a million times already. But does it work as a fashion statement? Louisa Young on the return of all things matronly and middle-aged
fields.body:
A shapely and beautiful friend of mine, aged thirtysomething plus tax, as they say in Tennessee, occasionally displays a narrow section of smooth brown tummy between top and waistband. Not a lot, not on purpose, it just happens sometimes. The other day, a woman she didn't know said, apropos of this stripe: "Ooh, you are brave."

In other words: "Dress your age, you show-off. How dare you, at your age, go around being unselfconscious and showing us all up with your pretty tummy, and you a mother, well, I'm jealous as hell and I'll make you feel bad about it, that's for sure."

Well, for once, we really could dress our age. For the first time in a while, there are clothes not only available but highly fashionable that are right and proper. I'm talking about that thing Prada started. Little tweed suits, floppy bow blouses, proper hair-dos, the slightly sexy secretary look, brooches, of all the grannyish accessories, on the catwalk at Armani. In recent Versace ads, headscarves and little dogs, no less! What could be more perfect for a lady of a certain age? We can all stroll forth, adorned in dignity as befits our status in life, and fashionable, too.

But there's a big problem here that Prada seem not to have taken into account. It's to do with age, and motherliness, and all that. It's this: if a woman over, oh, 25 puts on those little suits and blouses and court heels, she looks like a middle-aged lady. If a woman verging on what used to be called middle-aged - 39 plus tax, say - puts them on, she looks like an old lady. And not just any old lady, but an old lady from when the 39 plus tax lady was young. Quite possibly, her own mother.

I don't mind dressing my age, as long as it's my age circa 2000, not my age circa 1952. In 1952, women my age were, unless they had worked very hard at making other arrangements, past it. Totally. Women my age now are Queens of the World and can wear whatever the hell they like. We have, as they say, come a long way, baby, and putting on clothing from way back when is not in our interests, sartorially, aesthetically or politically. I don't care what fashion says: if I am to look like anyone's mother, I want to look like my daughter's mother, not my own in a time warp.

Even way back then, the only people who looked nice in those little suits were Audrey Hepburn and Ava Gardner. They were probably about 22 at the time, slender as elves, leggy, and just waiting for Cary Grant to take their specs off and say: "Why but Miss Thing, you're beautiful!"

Anyone other than a beautiful, timid virgin in her first job and working for Cary Grant is not going to look good in these clothes. Anyone who has a bosom is going to look like Margaret Dumont; anyone with legs shorter than Cyd Charisse is going to look like a stylish pouffe from some taupe-obsessed modern furniture shop.

If all my comparisons are with film stars of yesterdecade, it's completely logical. This look has not come around since then, purely and simply because on 99% of women it is not a good look. Until now, designers and their high street imitators have realised this and moved straight on through the wardrobe of history to something more profitable. But there comes a time when, in her neverending swirl through the outfits of the past, fashion could not resist picking up something patently hopeless and trying again with it. Especially now, when the pace of revivals has picked up to such a degree that the same look is tapping on your shoulder almost before you have seen it disappear behind you in a puff of unregretted ostrich feather.

This Moneypenny thing, this sexy but businesslike buttoned-up lady look, has to be worth a go simply because it is the only thing left in the wardrobe that hasn't been revived 18 times already. And maybe, fashion whispers to herself hopefully, we will have forgotten that it only ever looked nice on young girls who were about to break out of it, who, with Cary Grant's help, were about to get a pair of capri pants, a beret, a jazz soundtrack and a life.

But - I don't think we have forgotten. And if we have, we are soon enough reminded. If it trickles down to Kookai, a few young lovelies will give it a go, if it's cheap enough, and they will realise that - well, no. And the facelifted fortysomething plus tax ladies who can afford the high-fashion originals? Are they voluntarily going to undermine their cosmetic surgery with a piece of supremely expensive high fashion tweed that adds 15 years to their looks? Hmm ... hard one, that.
