webTitle: High fashion ... or high street?

fields.headline: High fashion ... or high street?
fields.standfirst: Could you spot the difference?  Top drawer designers are worried that you won't.  Hadley Freeman reports on a retailing rumpus
fields.trailText: Could you spot the difference? Top drawer designers are worried that you won't. Hadley Freeman reports on a retailing rumpus
fields.body:
There was no doubt about it: there was something familiar about that basket. When an employee of the fashionable bag designer Lulu Guinness walked into high street retailer Accessorize one afternoon last February, she was "horrified" to see for sale two styles of wicker baskets distinctly reminiscent of ones designed earlier that year by her boss. The Accessorize ones, however, were retailing at a tenth of the price.

"This is beginning to happen more and more on the high street," says Charlotte Macfarlane, managing director of Lulu Guinness. "These days we are having to concentrate much more on defending our copyright and we are considering taking out insurance against further legal action."

What a sign of the times. Once the line between high fashion designers and high street retailers was marked by more than the difference in the price tags. But in the past decade, high street retailers have realised that even those without bloated bank accounts like to keep abreast of high fashion trends. Having perceived this noticeable gap in the market, they have since been mining a very rich seam by offering similar, but much cheaper, copies of high fashion clothes. What is seen on the catwalks this season is becoming a reliable indicator of what will be on the high street next month, minus a couple of zeros from the price. In Italy, copies of Prada bags and JP Tods totes are sold from blankets on the pavement, only to be shoved into a carrier bag if a police car is heard nearby; here copies (albeit not as blatant) are sold on the high street.

Guinness, however, was more fortunate. After her complaint in February, Accessorize launched an internal investigation, before finally conceding the similarities on June 28. An out of court settlement was reached in which Accessorize paid all the legal costs incurred, as well as handing over the two styles of basket. Lulu Guinness Ltd, in suitably dramatic fashion, burned the offending items.

"The artwork on the basket was perhaps similar," admits Nicky Pike, managing director of Accessorize. "But it is quite a common weave."

In an ironic twist to the saga, last Saturday a different Lulu Guinness basket, which retails for £120, appeared in a newspaper supplement, photographed, in apparent ignorance of the recent affray, next to a twin version from Tesco, priced at £8. "Yes, we are considering further action," Macfarlane sighs, rather wearily. "That's all we can say at the moment."

Lindsey Robinson, marketing manager of Tesco Clothing, however, was surprised at the suggestion of a potential problem. "Everyone takes inspiration from high fashion designers," she points out.

Fashion inevitably takes influences from predecessors and contemporaries. But where does inspiration end and downright plagiarism begin? This question is increasingly plaguing the once happily distant relationship between high fashion designers and high street retailers. This season's offerings from the latter are so similar to those of the former that their audacity can be breathtaking. Morgan has produced a pattern similar to the familiar Burberry print (which is, in fact, a registered trademark); LK Bennett is offering its own version of last season's shoe sensation, Marc Jacobs' stitched pump; Office, with commendable speed, has already produced 1940s-style pumps in the style of the new Pradas (and at a sixth of the price), almost before the Prada versions are on the shelves.

"Obviously, as a high street retailer, it would be suicidal to ignore what the leading design houses are doing," says Lynsey Hand, ladies buyer at Office. "Basically, we take note of the main fashion themes, then we come up with our own ideas around those."

The high street has democratised the whole concept of fashion: to be able to dress in desirable clothes similar to those seen in fashion magazines is no longer the privilege of the phenomenally well-heeled. High fashion has now, through the high street filter, become more relevant to more people. So shouldn't designers simply smile benignly at their aspiring retail companions and see this mimicry as a compliment?

"It's not a compliment when it harms our business," Macfarlane retorts. "Of course I can see the point of high street copies - not everyone can afford full-price Prada or Gucci - but the high street has to realise that designers have businesses to run."

Pat Marsh, chairman of Philip Treacy, agrees. "In terms of size, we are a David in an industry of Goliath manufacturers and we can ill-afford to see Philip's unique talent plagiarised. In our view, any such act is no different from a famous artist having his paintings copied without permission, reproduced and sold for profit."

"Lulu is a directional designer and people do take inspiration from her," Macfarlane continues. "But the Accessorize baskets were too close. The high street is there to provide the essence of fashion - it should not go as far as blatant copying."

High street retailers respond that they are at the mercy of both customer demand and their suppliers. "Fifty per cent of our products are bought from manufacturers and developers in the UK and far east, and these baskets came from the far east," Pike explains. "In fact, the same baskets are available in at least three other high street retailers. We really were an innocent infringer."

It is not only the high street that occasionally gets into trouble. In 1993, London-based design team Antoni and Alison received an out of court settlement from Giorgio Armani who, they alleged, had produced a T-shirt bearing a logo too close to their own. In 1994, Ralph Lauren paid £250,000 in damages to Yves Saint Laurent for copyright infringement of a black tuxedo evening sheath.

But thanks to the increasingly sophisticated copies available, the high street is stronger than ever. Even celebrities and the proudly high-maintenance It girls can be spotted picking up cut-price Chloe aviator sunglasses at Oxford Circus. So it is unsurprising that designers are glancing anxiously towards these less costly interpretations of their clothes.

Lynsey Hand at Office nevertheless feels such concern is needless. "Top designers use the top factories - which we cannot afford - to produce their designs. Certainly no designers have complained to us. Our shoes, in the flesh, are quite different and I'm sure the big designers know that."

Treacy and Guinness disagree. "It hurts our relationship with our stockists," Macfarlane explains. "They are inevitably unhappy that copies of our products are available just down the road at lower prices."

There is one designer, however, whose view differs. At a recent lecture in London, Tom Ford was asked how he felt about high street versions of his lavish clothes. With characteristic financial pragmatism, Ford replied: "I love it - and I want to hire those designers."

An out of court settlement was reached in which Accessorize paid all the legal costs incurred, as well as handing over the two styles of basket. Lulu Guinness Ltd, in suitably dramatic fashion, burned the offending items. "The artwork on the basket was perhaps similar," admits Nicky Pike, managing director of Accessorize. "But it is quite a common weave." In an ironic twist to the saga, last Saturday a different Lulu Guinness basket, which retails for £120, appeared in a newspaper supplement, photographed, in apparent ignorance of the recent affray, next to a twin version from Tesco, priced at £8. "Yes, we are considering further action," Macfarlane sighs, rather wearily. "That's all we can say at the moment." Lindsey Robinson, marketing manager of Tesco Clothing, however, was surprised at the suggestion of a potential problem. "Everyone takes inspiration from high fashion designers," she points out. Fashion inevitably takes influences from predecessors and contemporaries. But where does inspiration end and downright plagiarism begin? This question is increasingly plaguing the once happily distant relationship between high fashion designers and high street retailers. This season's offerings from the latter are so similar to those of the former that their audacity can be breathtaking. Morgan has produced a pattern similar to the familiar Burberry print (which is, in fact, a registered trademark); LK Bennett is offering its own version of last season's shoe sensation, Marc Jacobs' stitched pump; Office, with commendable speed, has already produced 1940s-style pumps in the style of the new Pradas (and at a sixth of the price), almost before the Prada versions are on the shelves. "Obviously, as a high street retailer, it would be suicidal to ignore what the leading design houses are doing," says Lynsey Hand, ladies buyer at Office. "Basically, we take note of the main fashion themes, then we come up with our own ideas around those." The high street has democratised the whole concept of fashion: to be able to dress in desirable clothes similar to those seen in fashion magazines is no longer the privilege of the phenomenally well-heeled. High fashion has now, through the high street filter, become more relevant to more people. So shouldn't designers simply smile benignly at their aspiring retail companions and see this mimicry as a compliment? "It's not a compliment when it harms our business," Macfarlane retorts. "Of course I can see the point of high street copies - not everyone can afford full-price Prada or Gucci - but the high street has to realise that designers have businesses to run." Pat Marsh, chairman of Philip Treacy, agrees. "In terms of size, we are a David in an industry of Goliath manufacturers and we can ill-afford to see Philip's unique talent plagiarised. In our view, any such act is no different from a famous artist having his paintings copied without permission, reproduced and sold for profit." "Lulu is a directional designer and people do take inspiration from her," Macfarlane continues. "But the Accessorize baskets were too close. The high street is there to provide the essence of fashion - it should not go as far as blatant copying." High street retailers respond that they are at the mercy of both customer demand and their suppliers. "Fifty per cent of our products are bought from manufacturers and developers in the UK and far east, and these baskets came from the far east," Pike explains. "In fact, the same baskets are available in at least three other high street retailers. We really were an innocent infringer." It is not only the high street that occasionally gets into trouble. In 1993, London-based design team Antoni and Alison received an out of court settlement from Giorgio Armani who, they alleged, had produced a T-shirt bearing a logo too close to their own. In 1994, Ralph Lauren paid £250,000 in damages to Yves Saint Laurent for copyright infringement of a black tuxedo evening sheath. But thanks to the increasingly sophisticated copies available, the high street is stronger than ever. Even celebrities and the proudly high-maintenance It girls can be spotted picking up cut-price Chloe aviator sunglasses at Oxford Circus. So it is unsurprising that designers are glancing anxiously towards these less costly interpretations of their clothes. Lynsey Hand at Office nevertheless feels such concern is needless. "Top designers use the top factories - which we cannot afford - to produce their designs. Certainly no designers have complained to us. Our shoes, in the flesh, are quite different and I'm sure the big designers know that." Treacy and Guinness disagree. "It hurts our relationship with our stockists," Macfarlane explains. "They are inevitably unhappy that copies of our products are available just down the road at lower prices." There is one designer, however, whose view differs. At a recent lecture in London, Tom Ford was asked how he felt about high street versions of his lavish clothes. With characteristic financial pragmatism, Ford replied: "I love it - and I want to hire those designers."

webTitle: 'No decision' on speeding prosecution for Straw's driver

fields.headline: 'No decision' on speeding prosecution for Straw's driver
fields.trailText: Police investigating an alleged speeding incident involving the official car of the home secretary, Jack Straw, denied today that they have decided not to prosecute his driver. No decision has been made, detectives insisted.
fields.body:
Police investigating an alleged speeding incident involving the official car of the home secretary, Jack Straw, denied today that they have decided not to prosecute his driver. No decision has been made, detectives insisted.

Traffic officers stopped Mr Straw's car on the M5 near Taunton, Somerset, on July 9 as the home secretary was being driven to a meeting with the prime minister, Tony Blair.

Today Avon and Somerset police spokesman Inspector Keith Jones said that the fate of Mr Straw's special branch driver had not been decided.

"Inquiries are still continuing and no decision has been made," he said. A file prepared by officers was being passed to the crown prosecution service for its consideration today, he added.

Police stopped Mr Straw's armoured Jaguar as he headed for the Labour party's national policy forum in Exeter. It was reportedly travelling at 103mph - 33mph above the speed limit - when it was pulled over.

A Home Office spokeswoman said today: "If Avon and Somerset police say no decision has been made, then no decision has been made."

webTitle: JFK airport gunman surrenders

fields.headline: JFK airport gunman surrenders
fields.body:
A stand-off at New York's John F Kennedy International Airport has ended after the gunman gave himself up.

The gunman had earlier freed the pilot and co-pilot of a jet he had taken hostage.

The pilot had emerged with a list of demands, including the man's wish to speak with someone from the Argentine Consulate, according to New York Police Chief Thomas Fahey.

It is not clear if his demands have been met.

Witnesses say the gunman had earlier told a flight attendant to shut the door to the jet before dozens of passengers rushed out of the plane.

The man held a gun to the pilot's head but did nothing to stop the exodus.

Dave Schlesinger, a passenger, saw the commotion as a police officer aimed his own weapon at the cockpit door.

"I didn't know what was going on until I saw that Swat (police commando) team member with a shotgun. Then I knew it was serious," Schlesinger said.

Police say the gunman entered the plane as passengers were boarding a flight to Las Vegas.

Witnesses say the flight had been delayed by fog for about an hour but was ready to take off when the man flashed a gun at airline workers, walked down the jet way, onto the plane and into the cockpit.

It was then that the passengers panicked and ran for the door. At least 40 or 50 escaped.

webTitle: Obituary: Ahmad Shamlu

fields.headline: Obituary: Ahmad Shamlu
fields.standfirst: Towering figure of Iranian poetry and an intellectual symbol of the fight against oppression in his country
fields.trailText: With the death of Ahmad Shamlu, at the age of 74, Iran has not only lost its greatest contemporary poet but also its most potent symbol of intellectual conscience againt tyranny and repression.
fields.body:
With the death of Ahmad Shamlu, at the age of 74, Iran has not only lost its greatest contemporary poet but also its most potent symbol of intellectual conscience againt tyranny and repression. Across more than half a century, he produced some of the finest, most memorable poems in recent Iranian history, and played an important role in the modernisation of Persian poetry, developing new techniques that gave greater flight to his imagination.

He was also a professional journalist, earning most of his living by editing literary and political magazines. He was a critic, scholar, translator, scriptwriter and - with his beautiful voice - a gifted reciter of poetry. As a lifelong campaigner for freedom of expression, he was several times jailed by the Shah's regime and vilified by the subsequent Islamic government.

Shamlu published nearly 20 collections of poetry. His work set him apart, even in a country with a rich poetic heritage, where poetry is widely read, memorised and used in daily conversation.

Born in Tehran, his life and work reflected Iran's turbulent history from the second world war to the Islamic revolution of the late 1970s. He grew up in various cities, as his family followed the postings of his army officer father. He did not finish high school, he explained later, because he was thirsty to read and understand - and he was getting nothing from school. From an early age, he was an avid reader and a concerned observer of the misery and suffering around him.

The allied occupation of Iran, towards the end of the second world war, inspired Shamlu's first patriotic po ems. At 18, he was held in an allied prison for a year, for distributing anti-occupation pamphlets. Shortly after his release, he was arrested again - together with his father - by the separatist local government of Azerbaijan. They were left waiting for execution in front of a firing squad for hours before being freed.

After the war, like many young Iranian intellectuals, Shamlu joined the Tudeh (communist) party, and his poetry of this period reflected his politics. His first collection of poems, The Forgotten Songs, was published in 1947, when he was 22; it was followed, in 1951, by Manifesto. After Mohammed Mussadeq's nationalist and liberal government was overthrown in 1953 by an Anglo-American backed coup, Shamlu was again imprisoned. Once released, he left the Tudeh party and never again joined a political organisation.

Shamlu's style of poetry was influenced by two sources. He was fascinated by Nima Yushij, generally regarded as the father of Iran's "new poetry", and by a variety of foreign poets: the French Paul Eluard and Louis Aragon, the Russian Vladimir Mayakovsky, the American Langston Hughes and, above all, the Spaniard Federico Garcia Lorca.

The publication of The Fresh Air (1957) established him as a prominent poet. His verse was full of hope and he saw himself as the heart of the revolution: "Come/ my companion/ with your pains/ and trickle the poison of your pains/ into the wound of my heart/ I am the common pain/ cry me out".

In the wake of Mussadeq's overthrow, however, political repression gradually created despair and pessimism among Iranian intellectuals, a mood reflected in Shamlu's works of the period: Aida In Mirror (1964), Aida: The Tree, The Dagger And A Memory, and Phoenix In The Rain (1966).

Aida was the name of Shamlu's second wife, who he met in the early 1960s and who remained his companion for the rest of his life. In these collections, love became his main preoccupation, replacing his belief in the masses. Jesus, and the indifference of the people towards his suffering, was also a new theme for his poetry.

In Abraham In The Fire (1973), Shamlu's pessimism reached a new height, when he beautifully portrayed a lifeless Iranian society: "There is no door/ There is no road/ There is no night/ There is no moon/ Neither day/ Nor sun/ We are standing outside time/ With a bitter dagger/ Stuck in our spine/ No one talks to anyone/ For silence is speaking in a thousand tongues."

Harassed by the authorities, and unable to tolerate the oppressive atmosphere of Iran, Shamlu left for the United States in 1977, and later moved to Britain to edit Iranshahr, a popular, anti-Shah, Persian-language newspaper. When he returned home after the Shah was overthrown, he found the Islamic regime just as hostile. He warned in the first issue of his new weekly, Ketab-e Jumeh, that black days were ahead and, in his powerful poem, In This Dead-End, he depicted the atmosphere of fear and repression in post-revolutionary Iran.

Shamlu published a few other collections of poems before the regime banned his work. But he continued to publish abroad, particularly in Sweden, where The Unrewarded Eulogies appeared in 1992. The ban was partially lifted a few years ago and he published a new collection, On the Threshold (1997).

In the last two decades, Shamlu begun an encyclopaedic project, The Book Of The Street, on Iranian folklore, popular traditions and customs. He translated European literature into Persian and published a new version of work by Iran's most famous classical poet, Hafez. He wrote screenplays and short stories for children, and recorded cassettes of western and Iranian poetry.

Shamlu's main concern in his work remained suffering and injustice. His simple style, powerful imagination and command of Persian attracted general readers as well as the literary elite. In 1991, he was awarded the Freedom of Expression prize by Human Rights Watch for his efforts to fight oppression and promote human rights.

He leaves his wife, Aida Sarkisian, and four children from a previous marriage.

 Ahmad Shamlu, poet, born December 12 1925; died June 24 2000

In this dead end They smell your mouth To find out if you have told someone: I love you! They smell your heart! Such a strange time it is, my dear; And they punish Love At thoroughfares By flogging.

We must hide our Love in dark closets. In this crooked dead end of a bitter cold They keep their fire alive By burning our songs and poems; Do not place your life in peril by your thoughts! Such a strange time it is, my dear! He who knocks on your door in the middle of the night, His mission is to break your Lamp!

We must hide our Lights in dark closets!

Behold! butchers are on guard at thoroughfares With their bloodstained cleavers and chopping-boards; Such a strange time it is, my dear! They cut off the smiles from lips, And the songs from throats!

We must hide our Emotions in dark closets!

They barbecue canaries On a fire of jasmines and lilacs! Such a strange time it is, my dear! Intoxicated by victory, Satan is enjoying a feast at our mourning table!

We must hide our God in dark closets!

In the early days of the Islamic revolution, young men and women were sent into the streets to enforce the moral code of the shari'a or religious law, in some cases acting violently and excessively. They "smelled the mouth" if they suspected someone of drinking alcohol, which could be followed by a lashing, and they wiped lipstick from women's mouths, sometimes even cutting the lips with a razor - from Modern Persian Poetry, edited by Mahmud Kianush, Rockingham Press, 1996

webTitle: Mum's the word for the families of Atherton and Stewart

fields.headline: Mum's the word for the families of Atherton and Stewart
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle reports on top-secret plans to mark the 100th Test appearances of Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart at Old Trafford (even their families have been sworn to secrecy), and reveals why Michael Slater won't be playing for Rest of the World tomorrow after all
fields.trailText: Surprise! Old Trafford plans tribute to Atherton and Stewart
fields.body:
Surprise! Old Trafford plans tribute to Atherton and Stewart

How will the 100th Test appearances of Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart in next week's third Test against West Indies be officially acknowledged? "Highly confidential" plans for a special presentation ceremony at Old Trafford are being finalised by Lancashire and the ECB. But the two central characters are being kept deliberately in the dark, and even their families have been sworn to secrecy.

The ECB confirms that there will be a "short, simple presentation" to the two ex-captains out on the field at some stage on the first day, August 3. There will be separate presentations to each player from Lord MacLaurin, the ECB chairman, and officials of Lancashire, and an opportunity for a full house to salute Atherton and Stewart's achievement in becoming only the sixth and seventh England players to reach the 100-Test mark.

Don't expect anything on the scale of, say, a 100th-birthday celebration. There will be a minimum of fuss: the ECB says speeches are unlikely, and the rest of the England side will not be joining the two centurions out in front of the pavilion - though they will surely lead the applause from the balcony.

The formalities will be brief and low-key - more like the presentation of a first Test cap, not a 100th. "We're keeping the details quiet," says the ECB, "so that it'll be a nice surprise for them." For Atherton, of course, there's the added buzz of playing his 100th Test on his home ground.

The tribute is an initiative of Lancashire's, and precise details will not be finalised until a committee meeting on Monday, when decisions on gifts, the ceremony's timing - it will be held either before start of play, or during the lunch interval - and personnel will be made. However the officials doing the honours for Atherton and Stewart are expected to include Sir Patrick Russell, Lancashire president, and Jack Simmons, the former club captain who is now chairman.

It has also emerged that both players' parents have accepted invitations from Lancashire to witness the milestone. Alan and Wendy Atherton will be joined by Micky and Sheila Stewart. All can be relied upon to observe the club's firm request not to spoil the surprise for their offspring: discretion, after all, comes naturally to a headmaster (Atherton senior) and a former England coach (Stewart senior), especially where their famous sons are concerned.

Stricken Slater pulls out of the big game

Tomorrow's big exhibition match at The Oval should have provided Michael Slater with a rare opportunity to show the Australian selectors that he can play international one-day cricket. But Slater has had to pull out for "medical reasons".

Slater, whose clean hitting has been spurned by Australia's one-day side for the past three years, was due to open the batting with the Rest of the World captain Alec Stewart against an Asia XI led by Sachin Tendulkar . They would have squared up to a world-class attack featuring Wasim Akram, Javagal Srinath, Saqlain Mushtaq and Anil Kumble. The 50-over game, played to ODI rules and televised around the world, could have been the perfect stage for Slater to produce something special.

Now his health has given way at just the wrong moment. He could not be contacted for comment but Surrey's spokesman, Toby Codrington, explains: "Michael can't play for medical reasons. I believe he had a small fit of some kind. There are rumours it was a heart murmur. It may well be a stress thing." Codrington adds: "He's been told to take it easy, but he's OK." Slater, 30, has been replaced by Essex and former Australia batsman Stuart Law.

The health blip has not interfered with Slater's duties as a Channel 4 commentator but will be a considerable disappointment nonetheless. His 42nd and last appearance for Australia's one-day side was back in May 1997, in the second Texaco Trophy match against England at The Oval. Batting in the middle order, he was run out for one, leaving him with an unflattering one-day international average of 24.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com.

He could not be contacted for comment but Surrey's spokesman, Toby Codrington, explains: "Michael can't play for medical reasons. I believe he had a small fit of some kind. There are rumours it was a heart murmur. It may well be a stress thing." Codrington adds: "He's been told to take it easy, but he's OK." Slater, 30, has been replaced by Essex and former Australia batsman Stuart Law. The health blip has not interfered with Slater's duties as a Channel 4 commentator but will be a considerable disappointment nonetheless. His 42nd and last appearance for Australia's one-day side was back in May 1997, in the second Texaco Trophy match against England at The Oval. Batting in the middle order, he was run out for one, leaving him with an unflattering one-day international average of 24. webTitle: Granada close to ITV coup

fields.headline: Granada close to ITV coup
fields.trailText: Granada Media was last night close to finalising a deal which would see it emerge as the dominant player in the ITV network.
fields.body:
Granada Media was last night close to finalising a deal which would see it emerge as the dominant player in the ITV network. The company could announce an agreement as early as this morning which will see it buying the Meridian and Anglia franchises owned by Lord Hollick's United News & Media.

There was speculation that Granada was working on a deal to acquire all three of United's licences, including HTV, but it would be required to sell one on to satisfy demands made by the regulators. The likely outcome is that HTV, the Welsh franchise, will end up in the hands of Carlton Communications, leaving the lion's share of ITV controlled by two companies.

The agreement will be a triumph for Charles Allen, the Granada Media chief executive who had to fight back after an attempt by his two ITV rivals to merge - a deal which would have left Granada as the minority player.

Mr Allen has long maintained that there will eventually be a single company running ITV and has made no secret of his ambitions to be at the helm.

Granada already owns the Yorkshire, Tyne Tees, LWT and Granada franchises as well as being the ITV network's most prolific programme maker. Its productions include Coronation Street, Emmerdale and Cold Feet.

Carlton owns the London Weekday, West Country and Central licences.

United raised the "for sale" sign over its ITV interests after its hoped-for £10bn merger with Carlton ran foul of competition authorities. The deal was approved only on condition that United dispose of its Meridian licence on the south coast which accounted for half the group's revenues from ITV.

Carlton subsequently pulled out of the deal leaving Lord Hollick, who is a Labour peer, with few options.

Shares in United closed 15p lower at 945p yesterday as investors resigned themselves to the prospect that there would not be a takeover premium for the entire group.

Granada Media was trading 15p lower at 585p and Carlton was up 5p at 823.5p.

There was also a question mark still hanging over the 35% stake in Channel 5 owned by United.

A deal is expected to be agreed to sell the share in that broadcaster to pan-European television group RTL, which already owns the remaining 65%.

Under takeover panel rules Granada has until Friday of next week to declare its hand after it was given the green light to bid for either United or Carlton by trade secretary Stephen Byers two weeks ago.

Broadcasting regulations mean that no single company is allowed to control more than 15% of the total television audience share but that limit is expected to be swept aside by the communications white paper due for publication in the autumn. A single ITV could then become a possibility once legislation is passed after the general election.

The sale of United's TV assets will throw the focus on the remainder of the trimmed-down media concern.

There have long been suggestions that the Daily Express and Sunday Express newspapers would find no shortage of buyers if Lord Hollick decided to sell.

webTitle: London drivers face £5 congestion charge

fields.headline: London drivers face £5 congestion charge
fields.trailText: Drivers will be charged £5 a day for entering central London under proposals put forward today by the capital's mayor, Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
Drivers will be charged £5 a day for entering central London under proposals put forward today by the capital's mayor, Ken Livingstone.

Mr Livingstone wants the charge to apply throughout the working day, from 7am to 7pm Monday to Friday. Heavy goods vehicles would be charged £15.

He wants to see a fine of at least £100 for anyone avoiding the charge.

Disabled motorists and emergency vehicles would be exempt, and central London residents would pay less.

It is estimated that the scheme would raise more than £200m to be ploughed into improvements in public transport in the capital.

Today Mr Livingstone launched a public consultation exercise asking for the views of 300 key groups in the capital. They include London boroughs, the capital's MPs and MEPs, the business sector, bus operators, taxi and motoring groups.

He also appealed on the internet for the views of ordinary Londoners on the so-called "congestion charge".

Mr Livingstone's initial proposal is for a charging zone north and south of the Thames bounded by Marylebone Road, Euston Road, Pentonville Road, Tower Bridge, Elephant and Castle, Vauxhall Bridge and Hyde Park Corner.

The mayor said: "A city the size of London can only function efficiently on the basis of a fast, safe and efficient public transport system.

"But underinvestment in transport by central governments has plunged London into a vicious circle of an overcrowded tube, unreliable and slow buses and grossly congested roads.

"Traffic speeds have fallen to less than 10mph in central London. This undermines economic efficiency and sharply reduces the quality of life of Londoners."

According to the government's Road Charging Options for London report, such a scheme - based on vehicle registration numbers and backed by digital detection cameras - would reduce traffic by around 12% and would provide an 80% chance of catching non-payers.

Drivers would pay the charge on the day or in advance through local garages, newsagents and shops, by post, telephone or over the internet.

The Conservatives claimed that the scheme would bring chaos to the capital and would punish families and small businesses. Shadow transport minister Bernard Jenkin said it would be "ineffective, unfair and unworkable".

He said: "Tony Blair gave Ken Livingstone this power and he must be regretting it now." He called on the government to veto any such scheme. But a spokesman for the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions said: "It is a matter for the mayor."

The power for Mr Livingstone to establish the scheme is enshrined in the Greater London Authority Act of last year which set up the capital's mayor and assembly.

It requires that for the first 10 years of congestion charging, the money raised should be put back into transport in London. Local authorities around the country may follow the capital's example.

The London scheme is opposed by several local authorities in the capital. The leader of Tory-controlled Wandsworth council, Edward Lister, said it could become "a new Berlin wall cutting the borough in half and dividing communities".

Wandsworth council estimates that the scheme would cost £1,800 a year to anyone whose livelihood depends on taking their car into central London.

Mr Livingstone's plans received a better reception from business leaders, although the London Chamber of Commerce said private-sector support would depend on the scheme meeting key tests. These include improvements in the public transport network before congestion charging is introduced.

It also wants private motorists targeted, and not business vehicles, and it wants charges to be focused on peak periods and traffic bottlenecks.

The London Chamber of Commerce chief executive, Simon Sperryn, said congestion charges would be Mr Livingstone's "biggest challenge" since his election as mayor. "Get them right and we have an opportunity to solve one of London's biggest bugbears," he said. "But get it wrong and he risks a very public embarrassment and potentially a good deal of harm to the London economy."

webTitle: Economy set to meet euro test, say MPs

fields.headline: Economy set to meet euro test, say MPs
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Britain is on course to converge with the European economy, the key test set out in Tony Blair's latest leaked memo, according to three separate reports to be published over the next four days, including a report today from the Treasury select committee.
fields.body:
Britain is on course to converge with the European economy, the key test set out in Tony Blair's latest leaked memo, according to three separate reports to be published over the next four days, including a report today from the Treasury select committee.

In his leaked memo on Europe, denounced by William Hague yesterday, Mr Blair asserts the political case for joining the euro is overwhelming, but goes on: "The economics has to be right and at present it is not."

The Labour controlled Treasury select committee will argue today that Britain is moving to convergence, but suggest that the high exchange rate remains a problem.

Forecasters Ernst & Young will on Monday claim: "With Europe's short-term interest rates nudging 5%, just below those in Britain, it is possible to envisage sterling's entry into the Emu if Labour wins the next election.

"Britain's attachment to the American economic cycle may be history. On the basis of available data, it now appears to be tracking the European cycle much more closely."

The National Institute of Social and Economic Research, in a report published today, also points to convergence and says: "Our analysis suggests membership of Emu will be favourable for economy, but it would be foolish to argue that it is bound to lead to a further reduction of unemployment."

The analysis will be welcome to Mr Blair who has managed to settle the differences between Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson over strategy. Mr Mandelson has accepted that the government should not change strategy before the election.

The leaked Blair memo - which said the political case for the euro was "overwhelmingly in favour" but the economic criteria had not been met - was written in April, not December, as the Times reported, Downing St spokesman Godric Smith said yesterday. He added that a section of the memo had been omitted.

"The date is wrong. The documents are actually from April, the same period as the others, so someone for whatever reason is misleading the papers and trying to present these memos as coming from a period that they were not from," Mr Smith said.

Of the recent spate of leaked documents, Philip Gould wrote several at his north London home and copies are believed to have been taken from his bins.

Professional muckraker Benjamin Pell - known as Benji the Binman - was asked to target Mr Gould's bins earlier this year in a bid to obtain his notes and has close contacts with News International and other media groups.

Readers of virtually every national newspaper will at some point have read a story inspired or informed by his rummagings.

From the Sun and the Mirror via the Express, Daily Mail, Mail on Sunday, the Times, Independent, Guardian (although this paper has never bought documents from Mr Pell), Sunday Times and Sunday Telegraph - to name but a few - his handiwork has appeared in print.

webTitle: Baying for blood is no cure for NHS

fields.headline: Baying for blood is no cure for NHS
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the NHS

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Tony Blair launched his government's plan for the reform of the NHS yesterday to a barrage of noise in the Commons. It was the House at its very worst, and that's saying plenty. Don't these idiots realise how they sound?
fields.body:
Tony Blair launched his government's plan for the reform of the NHS yesterday to a barrage of noise in the Commons. It was the House at its very worst, and that's saying plenty. Don't these idiots realise how they sound?

Do they imagine that someone waiting for a hip operation, and watching the Parliamentary channel, is going to say, "hmm, this government has let me down. But thank goodness there's a loud and abusive phalanx of well-to-do, baying Tories in £25 silk ties who'll express frustration on my behalf"?

A 22-year-old supply teacher in a sink school would be startled to get such a reaction, but then his or her brief purgatory doesn't appear on television.

Almost everything the prime minister said was greeted by a mounting wall of sound. "The absurd demarcations between staff that keep patients waiting," he said, and the Tories made their gorilla-trying-to-stifle-a-burp noise.

"The role of nurses will be radically enlarged and the old barriers to modern working removed," he said, and Mr Eric Forth yelled "Bring back matron!" (I expect he didn't mean in hospitals, but in the Commons itself. "Now, Master Eric, you've been a very naughty boy. I prescribe an enema...")

Just when it seemed that nothing would silence them, he announced that 400,000 patients a year would get the benefit from new equipment to diagnose and treat cancer. Even this lot found it hard to jeer at that, even if they didn't believe it.

And, to be fair, who can believe it? We have heard so many earnest statements of intent from the despatch box, so many aggressive promises, seen the scaffolding raised for so many castles in Spain.

As William Hague pointed out a few moments later, quoting Philip Gould, "his advisor summed it up so well, 'Tony Blair has not delivered. He promised to save the NHS, but he has failed.'

"There are more targets when current targets have not been met, more pledges when current pledges have not been met!" Labour members jeered dementedly.

At this point, Mr Michael Martin, one of the deputy speakers, decided it was time for a campaign broadcast. Mr Martin may be unknown outside his native Glasgow, but he is the strong favourite among Labour MPs at least to be the next speaker.

We strained to hear what he was saying to the government benches. "Thurrs fah too much shootin' hurr. Hubble members shoo cum down," he remarked, or something along those lines.

The prime minister replied and the Tories barracked him back. "O'durr, o'durr, o'durr," said Mr Martin to the Tories, no doubt delighted at this chance to demonstrate his impartiality. "Wurr tockin' aboot the health suvvice, so we shoo' watch oor bluid pressure," he added.

But the Tories grew angrier and angrier, and Mr Martin became more heated. My old friend Mickey Fabricant went an extraordinary brick colour. I feared for his heart and I feared for his wig. "Not one answer!" he bellowed, suggesting that the prime minister had failed to respond to Mr Hague's points."Not ONE answer!" he continued. NOT one answer! NOT one ANSWER!" he screamed again.

"Ah wurrah, widdna, a canna, ah wurrgghhh, gronff, wurk," commented Mr Martin, his Glaswegian accent totally overtaking his powers of coherent speech.

"They never cared about the health service! They never did!" said the prime minister. "Not one answer!" said Mr Fabricant. "Thurr hubble ge'mun shoo shurp," said Mr Martin.

So, the House disgraced itself yet again, but at least we may have found a new speaker.

webTitle: Ministers try to transform 1940s system into modern, patient-centred care

fields.headline: Ministers try to transform 1940s system into modern, patient-centred care
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: In 1948, every dropped bedpan was to reverberate around Whitehall, according to Nye Bevan, the then health secretary. Yesterday, the NHS plan shifted that central accountability away from the government's corridors of power and out into hospital wards, GPs' surgeries, local authorities' chambers and even the patient's home.
fields.body:
The vision: a health service designed around the patient

In 1948, every dropped bedpan was to reverberate around Whitehall, according to Nye Bevan, the then health secretary. Yesterday, the NHS plan shifted that central accountability away from the government's corridors of power and out into hospital wards, GPs' surgeries, local authorities' chambers and even the patient's home.

Setting out its vision, the government said its plan was to build a health service for the 21st century, one that was designed around the needs of the patient. It wanted a "leaner more focused centre with the secretary of state devolving powers", and aimed to offer fast and convenient care delivered to a consistently high standard, with services that were tailored to people's individual needs.

"Our vision is of an NHS where staff are not rushed off their feet and constantly exhausted; where careers are developed not stagnant; where staff are paid properly for good performance; and where child care is provided in every hospital," said the NHS plan.

"Ours is a vision of a renewed public service ethos, a system that values the dedication of staff and believes that trust is still the glue that binds the NHS together."

The top-down, dropped bedpan model "failed to provide the local innovation, and the responsiveness to deliver sustained improvements in patient care".

The government admitted that it would take time to realise its vision, but said that over the next 10 years the NHS must be redesigned to be patient centred. It said that the task for the plan was to show how to bridge the gulf between the reality of the NHS today and the vision of what it should be like tomorrow.

What's wrong with the NHS?

In his introduction to the report, the secretary of state for health, Alan Milburn, said that today's NHS was not sufficiently designed around the convenience and concerns of the patient.

"The NHS provides many patients with a good and reliable service. But it is simply not responsive enough to their needs," he said. "Patients have to wait too long for treatment. Records get lost. Wards are not clean. Standards are too variable. Old-fashioned demarcations between staff, restricted opening and operating times, outdated systems, unnecessarily complex procedures and a lack of training all combine to create a culture where the convenience of the patient can come a poor second to the convenience of the system."

The report said that the NHS was a 1940s system operating in a 21st century world. It criticised old-fashioned demarcations between staff which meant some patients saw a procession of health professionals to whom they often had to recount the same details. Information was not shared and investigations were often repeated.

The report said the fault line between health and social care which had existed since the service was created in 1948 had inhibited the development of services shaped around the needs of patients.

It criticised the NHS for doing too little to prevent ill health in the first place. "The health gap between the better off and the worst off in society has widened in the last 50 years. The gap between health need and health services remains stubbornly wide."

The relationship between service and patient was too hierarchical and paternalistic. The NHS was also criticised for inadequate levels of modern equipment, and IT investment had been "too slow and too patchy".

What will happen in the future?

The public's main concern about the NHS was waiting times, and the plan said that these would be cut.

"The traditional waiting list for surgery will become a thing of the past. There will be waits of weeks rather than months. The uncertainty of not knowing when your operation will happen will be replaced by the certainty of a booked date."

The government said that, by the end of 2005, waiting lists for hospital appointments and admission would be abolished and replaced with booking systems. The maximum waiting time for an out-patient appointment would be three months, and for in-patients, six months. It was hoped that by 2008 the maximum wait for treatment would be cut to three months and 75% of operations would be carried out on a day-care basis. By 2004 patients would be able to have a GP appointment within 48 hours.

As a result of the plan, there will be 7000 extra NHS beds by 2004 along with a substantial investment in NHS buildings. Between now and 2004 there will be 7,000 more consultants, 2,000 more GPs, 20,000 more nurses, and over 6,500 more therapists and other health professionals.

Patients

The plan said that too many patients felt talked at, rather than listened to, and that this had to change.

A patient would have the right to fair access and high standards wherever they lived. They would have greater power and possession of their illness, their choice would be strengthened and they would have more rights. Eventually they would have smart cards containing medical records. These electronic patient records would enable nurses, therapists and doctors to maintain continuity of care and knowledge of patients.

Appointments would be pre-booked to suit the patient, and tests and diagnosis would be carried out on the same day. Patients would have proper redress when operations were cancelled and would have access to patients advocates and advisers, a service that would be set up in every hospital.

By 2001, the patients' charter would be replaced by the NHS charter, which clarified the NHS commitment to patients and their rights.

Better, faster services

The plan said that waiting times in accident and emergency departments would be drastically reduced; no one should wait more than four hours and most should be seen within 75 minutes. The proposal meant big changes to the way casualty departments worked, and patients with minor injuries would often be treated by nurse practitioners.

The role of NHS Direct would increase to try to unplug choked areas of the system, particularly accident and emergency departments. The plan said: "By 2004 a single call to NHS Direct will be a one-stop gateway to out of hours healthcare, passing on calls, where necessary."

The government promised better out of hours pharmacy services and to make available a wider range of over the counter medicines.

Newer, cleaner hospitals and better food

The government promised to build a new generation of state of the art hospitals with more intimate ward bays or rooms rather than the old style Nightingale wards. Eventually each patient would have their own television and telephone.

Over £30m would be allocated immediately to hospital trusts to improve hospital cleaning, and a nationwide clean-up campaign would start immediately. All patient areas, visitor toilets, outpatients and accident and emergency units would be thoroughly cleaned and maintained. Each hospital would have an unannounced inspection of its cleanliness in the next six months, and the results would be made public.

The plan said that the NHS provided more than 300m meals each year and the food was "variable in quality, is not provided in a way which is sufficiently responsive to patients, and too much of it is wasted as a result".

By 2001, there would be a 24-hour NHS catering service with a new menu designed by leading chefs. Half of all hospitals would have new "ward housekeepers" in place by 2004 who would ensure the quality of meals and that patients were able to eat them. An extra £10m would be provided for improvements in hospital food.

Better pay

Improvements would be made in pay for NHS staff, the plan said. There would be more help with accommodation costs, and the concept of staff hotels would be evaluated.

The national recruitment campaign would be extended, and the way NHS employers treated their staff would be linked to the financial resources they received. Every NHS Trust would receive £25,000 to be spent on improving the working environment for staff, and childcare provision would also be increased.

Changing role of health department

The role of the department would change so that it would champion the interests of patients by applying both pressure and support.

By 2004, there would be a new relationship between the government and the NHS and devolution would have taken hold. The same year, the share of NHS spend on management costs would be cut so that a higher share of every pound went into frontline patient care.

Consultants

A move from a consultant-led to a consultant-delivered service would provide a clear career structure for doctors. Contracts would be overhauled; the issue of consultants' private practice would be addressed and performances would be reviewed; and two-thirds of consultants would get a superannuable bonus. The financial reward to new consultants would be increased, but they would not be allowed to take up private work for seven years.

Nurses

Nurses would be empowered to undertake a wider range of clinical tasks, including the right to make and receive referrals, admit and discharge patients, order investigations and diagnostic tests and run clinics and prescribe drugs.

By 2001, 23,000 nurses would be able to prescribe a limited range of medicines. Staff would be given training if they wanted to take on new roles. Support staff would each have access to £150 from a learning account.

Cancer

The plan stated that the provision of extra investment, improved prevention and changed ways of working would mean that cancer services would improve. It would invest an extra £570m by 2003-04. The breast screening programme would be extended from ages 50-64 to ages 65-70. Cervical cancer screening would be upgraded, and there would be an expansion in cancer screening drugs. An end would be brought to the postcode lottery in the prescribing of cancer drugs.

Coronary heart disease

A £230m investment by 2003-04 would be accompanied by the establishment of rapid access chest pain clinics across the country. Clot-busting drugs would be available within an hour of calling for professional help, and ambulance response times would be improved.

New equipment

New equipment would also be introduced: 50 magnetic resonance imaging cancer scanners; 200 CT cancer scanners; 80 liquid cytology units to improve cervical cancer screening; 450 new and replacement kidney dialysis machines and 3000 automated defibrillators, which would be placed in public places. Up to date information technology systems would be introduced for which the NHS Plan would provide an extra £250m by 2003-04.

Modernisation and scrutiny

A modernisation agency would be created to help local clinicians and managers redesign local services around the needs and convenience of patients.

The NHS would be made subject to independent scrutiny, and local government would also be given power of scrutiny.

Concordat with the private sector

The government plan outlined a concordat for the relationship between the NHS and the private sector, which it said would not compromise the principle underpinning the plan. It said: "Under our proposals a patient would remain an NHS patient even if they were being treated in the private sector."

Improving health and reducing inequality

The report said that the gap between health needs and health services remained stubbornly wide. The plan aimed to tackle the specific needs of differnt groups as well as disadvantage in all forms. The government would set a target to narrow the gap in infant and early childhood mortality and morbidity between socio-economic groups. By 2002 it would develop a new health poverty index. The plan said that the "inverse care law" still applied to too many parts of the country. There would be a new way of distributing resources to address iniquities in poorer areas.

Reducing smoking and eating fruit

For the first time, a quitting service would be provided on the NHS, with nicotine replacement therapy available on prescription from GPs.

A new national school fruit scheme would be introduced, whereby every child in nursery aged four to six would be entitled to a free piece of fruit each school day. This would coincide with a programme to get the public to eat five pieces of fruit or vegetables a day.

Mental health

Extra investment would bring 500 more secure beds and 1,000 new graduate primary care mental health workers, as well as 500 more community health staff.

The plan would also see early intervention to reduce the period of untreated psychosis in young people, with 50 teams established over the next three years.

The plan said: "By 2004 all young people who experience a first episode of psychosis, such as schizophrenia, will receive the early and intensive support they need."

Support for carers

By 2004, there would be 7,000 more staff recruited to provide relief to carers and reduce the risk of social isolation.

New health targets

 Maximum waiting time for an operation to fall from 18 months to six months by 2005 and to three months by 2008

 Maximum waiting time for outpatient appointments to fall to three months by 2005

 Maximum waiting time at accident and emergency to fall to four hours by 2004. Average should fall to 75 minutes

webTitle: Labour stakes credibility on 5-year NHS revolution

fields.headline: Labour stakes credibility on 5-year NHS revolution
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour in power

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday staked the political credibility of a second Labour term in government on a five-year plan to slash NHS waiting times and create a patient-friendly health service to suit the consumerist values of the 21st century.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday staked the political credibility of a second Labour term in government on a five-year plan to slash NHS waiting times and create a patient-friendly health service to suit the consumerist values of the 21st century.

He promised to recruit 7,500 more consultants by 2005, along with 2,000 extra GPs, more than 20,000 extra nurses and at least 6,750 more therapists and other health professionals.

The national plan for health in England will create 7,000 extra NHS beds by 2004, including the first increase in numbers of general and acute wards for nearly 30 years. Modernisation of primary care will include the creation of 500 one-stop centres, combining GPs, dentists, opticians and other health care and social care professionals under one roof.

The investment will be supported by a 35% real terms increase in NHS resources over four years - double the historic trend of growth in health spending. Ministers said lack of money was no longer the problem and the key tests of delivery would now be how fast they can recruit trained staff and how well they can retain them.

The plan is specific enough in its objectives to create many hostages to Labour's fortune if the NHS does not deliver.

Mr Blair told MPs: "By 2005 the maximum waiting time for an outpatient will be three months and for an in-patient six months, rather than the present 18 months."

Average waiting times would be cut from seven to five weeks for outpatients and from three months to seven weeks for operations. The eventual objective "is to get the maximum waiting time for any stage of treatment down to three months by the end of 2008". Other targets include a commitment that by 2002 all patients will be able to see a primary care professional within 24 hours and a GP within two days.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said the 144-page national plan was "the most fundamental and far-reaching reform programme", addressing every one of the problems facing the NHS. "From the state of the wards to the doctor's contract, not one issue has been ducked."

The proposals include steps to break down the boundaries between the health professions, expanding the responsibilities of nurses, midwives and therapists.

Changes for NHS doctors will include a new consultants' contract linked to annual appraisal of their work. Newly qualified consultants will be obliged to work exclusively for the NHS for seven years, but after that they will be allowed to undertake private practice in their own time.

There will be a nationwide clean-up campaign of wards and six-monthly undercover inspections of hospital cleanliness. Hospitals will be set tough performance targets linked to extra cash and those who fail will be taken over and run by a management hit squad.

Early reaction from the NHS professions, managers and patients suggested there would be strong support for the general direction of reform, but months of in-fighting over the detail.

The plan included a preface signed by 25 leaders of organisations on which its delivery will depend, welcoming its "direction of travel". They included representatives of the British Medical Association, Royal College of Nursing and the NHS Confederation, representing the managers.

But Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA consultants committee, said proposals for changing the consultants contract showed "profound lack of understanding of the work they do". After two years of discussion, the government's only new idea was "an ill-conceived, vindictive attack on new consultants' freedom to work outside the NHS".

There was also bitter disappointment among organisations representing older people about the government's decision to reject the royal commission's recommendation that the NHS should pay for personal care in residential homes. Although the government will increase spending on care for older people by £1.4bn, services such as bathing and changing dressings will continue to attract means-tested charges.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said the plan was full of half-truths. "This was a wonderful opportunity for Tony Blair to move from political to clinical priorities. Unforgivably, he has put his own political survival before the survival of patients."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing congratulated the government on "a survival plan that puts patients first and tackles the hardest issues facing the health service".

"We're optimistic because every good idea in the plan is already happening somewhere in the health service. These ideas work and with the right support and opportunities, nurses and doctors will turn them into a reality for all patients."

The president of the Royal College of Physicians, Professor Sir George Alberti, said the plan was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity... At last we have government recognition of the shortage of doctors and beds in England and a commitment to tackle these problems".

Reforms at a glance

 7,000 extra beds

 100 hospital projects

 7,500 more consultants

 2,000 new GPs

 20,000 more nurses

 Over 6,500 health professionals

 The creation of an NHS modernisation agency

 The creation of a national performance fund worth £500m

 Closer ties between health and social services with a £900m investment in intermediate care

 New consultants' contracts

 New GPs' contracts

 New roles for nurses, midwives and therapists

 Better pay

 Better training

 Patients' choice will be strengthened and they will have more rights

 Redress if operations are cancelled

 Patients' representatives on trust boards

 Electronic patient records and smart cards for patients

 Reduced waiting times for beds, operations and in accident and emergency

 Waiting lists eventually abolished and replaced by a booking system

 Reducing inequality of health provision

 Increasing cancer screening

 Investment in research

 Ending the postal lottery that controls access to cancer treatment

 Expanding out of hours pharmacy service

 Increasing the number of over the counter drugs

 Nicotine replacement therapy on prescription

 Cleaner hospitals

 More private rooms

 Higher standards of care for older people

webTitle: When waiting turns to anger in A&E

fields.headline: When waiting turns to anger in A&E
fields.standfirst:
Computers can reduce patients' frustration

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: It is the waiting that gets them. Dozens of people in rows, sitting around for hours to be told by a doctor that really there is very little wrong with them: the ankle they thought was broken is simply a sprain; the cut on the finger that does not need stitches but a plaster. It is a bit of a relief, but it is also a waste of time - for patient and doctor alike.
fields.body:
It is the waiting that gets them. Dozens of people in rows, sitting around for hours to be told by a doctor that really there is very little wrong with them: the ankle they thought was broken is simply a sprain; the cut on the finger that does not need stitches but a plaster. It is a bit of a relief, but it is also a waste of time - for patient and doctor alike.

On Friday night in the Medway Maritime hospital in Gillingham, Kent, the high temperature outside the automatic doors of the accident and emergency department is reflected in the fractious tempers of those waiting inside. Much like any casualty department, this one operates a system where those with minor injuries must wait.

The two flashing red LED signs spell it out: "Welcome to Medway A&E. The current waiting time for category green patients is 2-3 hours. Patients are seen in order of priority and not in order of arrival. We are sorry for any delay."

For the patients whose patience has run out, they cannot understand what takes so long. Nursing minor cuts, swollen ankles, bruises, scrapes, torn ligaments and other everyday ailments, they cannot see what more serious injuries and illnesses are being attended to as a matter of priority.

Behind the doors of the trolley area - the main reception for patients with major injury, trauma and illness - an elderly man is fitting uncontrollably and as yet, the staff do not know why. A prisoner from one of her majesty's local hostelries is chained to his bed under the watch of two prison officers. A woman is strapped down on to a trolley in case she has suffered a spinal injury. And a very sick baby is crying uncontrollably for an unknown reason.

Out in reception, Shelley Smithson, 24, and her dad have been waiting four hours. She has been sent by her GP with a suspected appendicitis and is confused by the need to be assessed by a triage nurse because - in spite of information technology - there is no NHS computer link to her doctor's notes.

Looking at the others waiting, her dad, who does not want to be named, says: "Half of these people don't need to be here to start with. There are people who should be going to their GP, not coming here."

And that is one of the problems of today's A&E service.

It needs to provide everything to all people. From the road traffic accident victim to the woman who calls an ambulance for a cut on her finger. To every casualty department, there are no inappropriate attenders - everyone is welcome, it is just that it might take time to treat some of them.

In a report on modernisation of A&E submitted in April to Alan Milburn, the health secretary, an A&E consultant at Norfolk and Norwich hospital, Mike Lambert, said there should be more consistency in emergency medicine, and a re-education of the public. He suggested people needed to be trained out of their automatic instinct to head straight to casualty.

"We have to improve patients' knowledge of how the system works. I believe that in five to 10 years time, people will use a combination of NHS Direct and the ambulance service to determine their needs," said Mr Lambert.

It is something the government has taken on board. By 2004 it aims to cut average waits to 75 minutes by introducing new working practices.

At Medway, the staff know the system needs to be improved, and welcome change. Peter McKenna, the senior nurse manager, said: "Across the country people keep coming through the doors. I think what we need now is almost a clarification of what the government or the people wants us to do. I don't think it has ever been stated.

webTitle: Councils liable for teachers failing to educate adequately, Lords rules

fields.headline: Councils liable for teachers failing to educate adequately, Lords rules
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Law lords ruled yesterday that councils could be held responsible for the failure of their teachers to provide adequate education, in a judgment that may open the floodgates for similar claims.
fields.body:
Law lords ruled yesterday that councils could be held responsible for the failure of their teachers to provide adequate education, in a judgment that may open the floodgates for similar claims.

The House of Lords re-awarded £45,650 damages to Pamela Phelps, 26 for the west London borough of Hillingdon's failure to diagnose her dyslexia. They overturned an earlier ruling by the court of appeal, taking away the damages, in 1998.

Three others, Rhiannon Anderton, 21, from Mold in Clwyd, Marcus Jarvis, 20, and "G", 16, who has muscular dystrophy, from Bromley in Kent, all had their claims reinstated and now have the opportunity to seek compensation.

Earlier court decisions had ruled that local education authorities did not owe a duty of care to children with learning difficulties, even if they had been treated negligently, and it was therefore impossible for councils to be sued for damages. The law lords disagreed.

Seven law lords agreed that the issue of whether teachers owed a duty of care to all their pupils, and not just those with special needs, was more controversial.

But Lord Nicholls said: "I can see no escape from the conclusion that teachers do, indeed, owe such duties.

"The principal objection raised to this conclusion is the spectre of a rash of gold digging actions brought on behalf of under-achieving children by discontented parents, perhaps years after the events complained of.

"I am not persuaded by these fears. I do not think they provide sufficient reason for treating work in the classroom as territory which the courts must never enter."

Jack Rabinowicz, the solicitor for Ms Anderton and Mrs Phelps said: "This is a fundamental statement by the English courts that if mistakes do take place in the education system then teachers and local education authorities can be held liable."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said the ruling was "another big step down the slippery path of the suing society".

He added: "Where will it all end? Will teachers have the right to sue disruptive pupils and their parents for damages? Will schools and teachers have the right to sue the government for failing to provide them with adequate resources to meet all the demands that are now being made upon them?"

Graham Lane, Labour education group leader on the Local government association, said: "If you sue, you take money out of the authority for today's children - that really is unjust."

Mrs Phelps said last night that when her dyslexia was discovered, two weeks before she was due to take her GCSEs, teachers at the Mellow Lane School in Hillingdon had not wanted her to sit the exams. She left the school and paid for private tuition. In 1990 she began her legal fight.

Mrs Phelps said that she would spend the damages on getting the education that was denied her and put the rest towards schooling her two sons.

Ms Anderton, also dyslexic, said that she would be fighting for compensation from Mold LEA for the bullying she had suffered until she was 13, when she was forced to leave Argoed high school.

The LEA refused to send her to the Ravenscroft school for dyslexics. When Ms Anderton's family appealed to the Welsh Office, the government allowed her to go there.

Lawyers for Marcus Jarvis welcomed the ruling. Mr Jarvis had no formal education after the age of 12 and ended up serving a five year jail sentence for robbery.

He had tried to sue Hampshire county council for giving him "a rotten deal", but the court of appeal had said that he had no right to sue the authority.

webTitle: The best Diane Lane scene: The perfect storm

fields.headline: The best Diane Lane scene: The perfect storm
fields.trailText: Gloucester, Mass. Swordfisherman Bobby Shatford (Mark Wahlberg) has returned from an unsuccessful month at sea. Now preparing to go back out after barely 48 hours on land, he explains the situation to his girlfriend Chris Cotter (Diane Lane), who is terrified of the dangers involved.
fields.body:
Gloucester, Mass. Swordfisherman Bobby Shatford (Mark Wahlberg) has returned from an unsuccessful month at sea. Now preparing to go back out after barely 48 hours on land, he explains the situation to his girlfriend Chris Cotter (Diane Lane), who is terrified of the dangers involved.

"Go back to what you did before," she pleads. "Pack cod. Repair tackle."

She embraces him.

"I'm sick of that," he replies.

"It's safe, and it pays."

"Not enough."

He holds Chris's face in his hands.

"Just one more time, I promise. I have to try it again - we need the money."

"Money," Chris sighs. "It's always about the money."

"I've got a divorce lawyer, and I've got a..."

Chris finishes his sentence for him.

"Mountain of debt."

"Hey! And there's your two kids, you've got to get them back."

She looks up at Bobby.

"Do you think you'll love them?"

"They're yours, aren't they?"

The couple embrace again.

See also: Rumblefish, The Outsiders, The Cotton Club, Chaplin

Don't see also: Judge Dredd

Pointless trivia: Diane Lane has a permanently dilated left pupil, the result of a tennis ball striking her in the eye when she was a child.
