webTitle: The war that won't die

fields.headline: The war that won't die
fields.standfirst: Sixty years after it ended, film-makers are still fighting the Spanish civil war. David Archibald on the evolution of a national obsession - and the battle for truth
fields.trailText: Sixty years after it ended, film-makers are still fighting the Spanish civil war. David Archibald on the evolution of a national obsession - and the battle for truth
fields.body:
When a fire bomb ripped through the Balmes cinema in Barcelona on July 11 1974, the screening of Carlos Saura's La Prima Angelica (Cousin Angelica) was brought abruptly to a halt. The violent response to Angelica, one of the first films to represent the country's bitter civil war from a republican perspective, emphasised the political importance of cinema that deals with contested historical periods. The civil war may have ended officially in 1939, but fascist fire bombs suggested that the battle for Spain's fractured past was set to continue.

The release of Jose Luis Cuerda's La Lengua de las Mariposas (Butterfly's Tongue) once again brings the Spanish civil war into the cinema. Set in Galicia in the months preceding Franco's fascist uprising in July 1936, it traces the relationship between a seven-year-old boy and his anarchist-leaning teacher.

The film is indicative of Spanish cinema's concern with the country's recent past; of the nearly 300 historical films produced in Spain since the 1970s, more than half are set during the second republic, the civil war and under Franco. A period of 40-odd years, from 1931 to 1975, has become a rich historical seam for Spanish film-makers to mine as Spain struggles to come to terms with a past that had previously been refracted through a right-wing lens.

Under the dictatorship of General Francisco Franco, Spanish cinema was utilised as a myth-making machine to spin stories about the past. Cinema became a propaganda tool as the government turned out cine cruzada, or civil-war films, which venerated the Church, the family and the fascist state. The only cinematic version of history permitted, cine cruzada is best exemplified by the 1941 film Raza (Race), a triumphalist account of the war based on a script by the victorious dictator himself. It encapsulates the attitude of those in power: they had won the war, now they needed to win the history.

Even foreign films favourable to a republican viewpoint, such as the 1943 version of Ernest Hemingway's novel For Whom the Bell Tolls, were refused distribution. Facing the sharp scissors of the censor, oppositional film-makers who remained in the country utilised allusion, metaphor and symbolism in an attempt to raise alternative historical accounts of the past.

But from within these artistic strictures emerged two of the most acclaimed films to touch on the conflict: Saura's 1965 film La Caza (The Hunt) and Victor Erice's classic expressionist work from 1973, El Espiritu de la Colmena (Spirit of the Beehive). Set in the period following the conflict, both films deny easy interpretation, but many of those Spaniards fortunate enough to have seen them in cinemas at the time viewed them as harsh condemnations of the regime.

A recurring theme in Saura's work is the problems associated with re-capturing a long-suppressed past through recourse to memory. This is evident in Cousin Angelica which recalls the war from the perspective of a child of republican parents. Similarly, Saura's 1970 film, El Jardin de las Delicias (The Garden of Delights), relates the story of an amnesiac businessman whose peseta-chasing family attempt to force him to recollect his financial transactions. After years of cinematic distortion of history, Saura's films raise crucial questions about the vital necessity of remembering the past; yet, simultaneously, they point to the inherent fallibility of human memory itself.

After Franco's death in 1975 and the subsequent relaxation of censorship laws, cinematic representations of the war changed beyond all recognition. Over the following two and a half decades, events that were previously referred to obliquely took centre-stage in Spanish cinema.

In the years immediately following the dictator's demise, some film-makers turned towards documentary in a direct attempt to recuperate this repressed historical period. In 1977 La vieja memoria (The Old Memory) was released - an experimental documentary directed by Jaime Camino that utilises eyewitness testimonies from a wide range of veterans of the conflict. It seeks the "truth" of the past, but a different type of "truth" from the monolithic accounts characteristic of Francoist cinema. By presenting conflicting, subjective versions of the same period, The Old Memory moves from a documentary style to a more open-ended narrative that invites a plurality of response.

The same year saw another landmark documentary, Por Que Perdimos la Guerra? (Why Did We Lose the War?), directed by Diego Santillan, the son of a wartime anarchist leader, which presents a series of interviews with sympathisers of the anarchist trade union, the CNT. Fiercely critical of the British and French governments' refusal to sell arms to the beleaguered republic, the film also takes a bitter swipe at Stalin and the Spanish Communist Party (PCE).

With more than a little justification, Santillan suggests that Stalin was keener to establish a pact with fascism than to further the revolutionary uprising that had prevented Franco's immediate seizure of power. Both these documentaries marked a new stage in representations of the conflict, but the appeal of documentary cinema was relatively short-lived and Spanish film-makers mainly utilised fictional cinema to deal with the past.

In 1985, Luis Garcia Berlanga's La Vaquilla (The Little Cow) was released. Set on the Aragon front during the war, the significance of the film stems from its status as one of the first comedies set during that period. In that sense it foreshadows two of the films best known to foreign audiences: Fernando Trueba's Oscar-winning Belle Epoque (1993) and Saura's Ay, Carmela! (1990).

Set on the cusp of the establishment of the second republic and the abdication of the monarchy in April 1931, the world created in Belle Epoque is a million miles removed from the lived experience of rural life in 1930s Spain. The film creates an imaginary world where no one worries about work or money, where there is an abundance of good food and wine, and where personal freedom is closely identified with sexual liberation - a world that is in the process of shaking off the repressive force of the Catholic church and where people can begin to live their lives free from patriarchal restrictions.

As with Butterfly's Tongue, this is sugar-coated history. Republican Spain seen through rose-tinted glasses; a harsh and bitter world, magically transformed into an idyllic pre-modern utopia about to be cruelly crushed by fascism. There is a refusal to engage with a concrete historical past, and what is presented in both films is a nostalgic recreation of a republican Spain that never was. These two films highlight the fact that right-wing myths of the past are slowly being undone but they are being replaced with myths of a different kind.

If both Belle Epoque and Butterfly's Tongue recreate romanticised worlds, Ay Carmela! presents a different image of Spain altogether. Set in 1938, when the republic looked defeated, Carmela and her compatriots are performers in a republican theatre company who are captured by Franco's troops and faced with the dilemma of whether to perform before a group of fascist soldiers.

Saura uses the situation to present a meditation on questions dealing with artistic and cultural freedom: how much is it possible to compromise in the face of censorship and dictatorial control? What do you do in the face of inevitable doom? These are undoubtedly questions of specific relevance to those who struggled to make films under the dictatorship, but they also raise questions about the here and now, and indicate how the civil war is visited to comment on the concerns of the present.

It was not only Spanish films that entered the battle over Spain's past. Ken Loach's Land and Freedom was released in 1995 amidst a flurry of critical praise and political debate. Using as its starting point George Orwell's classic autobiographical account, Homage to Catalonia, Land and Freedom focuses on the bitter internal struggles within the republican movement that assisted the fascists' victory.

Like Why Did We Lose the War?, by re-examining the debates over the need for a revolutionary war to defeat Franco, Loach attempts to rehabilitate the war's revolutionary dimensions, suggesting that the conflict was more than a simple struggle between fascism and democracy. The closing slow-motion shooting of Blanca, a metaphorical representation of the betrayal of the revolution by the Spanish communists, caused bitter controversy and kick-started a reappraisal of the conflict inside Spain.

The furore provoked by Land and Freedom confirms the importance of cinematic images to contemporary audiences' understanding of the past. Like it or not, as the importance of the written word is steadily replaced by the immediacy of the visual image, cinema will increasingly become an arena for the contestation of differing versions of history.

Currently in pre-production, Antonio Banderas is preparing to direct Malaga Burning!, an adaptation of a 1937 novel set in his hometown in 1936. We wait with bated breath to see what myths will be created - or exploded - when Hollywood gets its hands on the Spanish civil war.

What do you do in the face of inevitable doom? These are undoubtedly questions of specific relevance to those who struggled to make films under the dictatorship, but they also raise questions about the here and now, and indicate how the civil war is visited to comment on the concerns of the present. It was not only Spanish films that entered the battle over Spain's past. Ken Loach's Land and Freedom was released in 1995 amidst a flurry of critical praise and political debate. Using as its starting point George Orwell's classic autobiographical account, Homage to Catalonia, Land and Freedom focuses on the bitter internal struggles within the republican movement that assisted the fascists' victory. Like Why Did We Lose the War?, by re-examining the debates over the need for a revolutionary war to defeat Franco, Loach attempts to rehabilitate the war's revolutionary dimensions, suggesting that the conflict was more than a simple struggle between fascism and democracy. The closing slow-motion shooting of Blanca, a metaphorical representation of the betrayal of the revolution by the Spanish communists, caused bitter controversy and kick-started a reappraisal of the conflict inside Spain. The furore provoked by Land and Freedom confirms the importance of cinematic images to contemporary audiences' understanding of the past. Like it or not, as the importance of the written word is steadily replaced by the immediacy of the visual image, cinema will increasingly become an arena for the contestation of differing versions of history. Currently in pre-production, Antonio Banderas is preparing to direct Malaga Burning!, an adaptation of a 1937 novel set in his hometown in 1936. We wait with bated breath to see what myths will be created - or exploded - when Hollywood gets its hands on the Spanish civil war.

webTitle: Video roundup

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: American beauty | Summer of Sam | Nosferatu
fields.trailText: American Beauty | Summer of Sam | Nosferatu
fields.body:
American Beauty
Rental
Universal Pictures Cert 18
*****

A US film so fresh, light, personal and full of ideas, you'd think you were back in the early 70s. It's a long time since anything was more deserving of its raft of Oscars - these are the people, remember, who gave six doorstops to Forrest Gump.

American Beauty is brilliantly assembled by first-time director Sam Mendes, teasingly scripted by Alan Ball (also a first after bill-paying TV work on Cybill and Grace Under Fire) and nicely acted all round; and Tim Newman's mood-changing score hasn't had as much praise as it deserves. But most of all, it features a towering performance from the sultan of sly, Kevin Spacey.

Spacey's henpecked worm turn is a thing of joy. When he falls in lust on seeing Mena Suvari's precocious cheerleader, he does the opposite of the traditional tongue-lolling approach but it works a treat; when he hits back at Annette Bening's tightly wound aspirational wife, he's quiet but sharp as a stiletto - hear the loathing behind the carefully enunciated "bloodless money-grabbing freak"; when he needs to show tenderness (to Chris Cooper's psychotic military man), he's achingly sensitive.

American Beauty is the story of a suburban community where everybody is living a lie and where truth, eventually and tragicomically, will out. It's about liberation and repression and bottled up lives coming spectacularly unravelled. It does its job so well that you could imagine its audience trying to be a little looser and more honest.

You could still nitpick a little: I thought Bening was a bit one-dimensional and the "beauty in a plastic bag" scene may remind cynical Viz fans irresistibly of the Black Bag strip. But Wes Bentley is a real find and anything that has people bonding across a generation gap (as Bentley and Spacey do) through a shared love of Re-Animator, and has the best "clean piss" scene since Withnail and I, gets my vote. You'll probably know by now that American Beauty is a kind of rose (cue petals as recurring motif) but here's a Guardian exclusive: the Dancing Spartanettes routine was choreographed by Paula Abdul.

Summer of Sam
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Pathe/MGM Cert 18
***

It's Brooklyn, 1977, and New York is being terrorised by the "Son of Sam", a sort of east coast Manson who coupled serial killings with weird poetic letters to columnist Jimmy Breslin. Spike Lee uses this backdrop to a frantic slice-of-life portrait of a set of smalltime losers living through a heatwave as in his masterpiece, Do the Right Thing.

This time, the cast is largely white, except Lee's own character, a TV interviewer with Afro and sideboards. Summer of Sam is set when the heyday of disco collided with the birth of punk, and when Ritchie (Adrien Brody) turns up in his old neighbourhood complete with spiked-up hair, a Union Jack T-shirt and a fake English accent, he's become so alien to his old friends, they wonder if he could be the avenging sicko.

Summer of Sam is occasionally very good, as in a bravura montage set to Teenage Wasteland (The Who, also starring in The Limey and American Beauty, seem bizarrely to be Hollywood band of the month). It has a nicely scruffy feel and catches the 77 hysteria well but its characters are mostly too dim or too unpleasant for you to care about them as much as you're supposed to.

Nosferatu
Retail (£12.99) and DVD (£15.99)
Eureka Cert PG
***

Before Christopher Lee, before Bela Lugosi, there was Max Schreck, cinema's first Dracula, though for copyright reasons he is called Count Orlok in this 1922 silent film directed by FW Murnau. While later actors turned him into a suavely sexy toff in a Slumberland coffin, Schreck's portrayal seems based on the look of real vampire bats - Werner Herzog re-made it in similar vein with mad Klaus Kinski in the 80s. Nosferatu creaks a bit, but it's handsomely sepia-tinted and, at its peak, like Orlok's rise from his coffin on the boat, is powerful and surreal.

webTitle: Echoes of Hitchcock

fields.headline: A faint flicker of the Fat Man
fields.trailText: A faint flicker of the Fat Man
fields.body:
It's that time of the year again: Ersatz-Hitchcock season. Will Hollywood never let the Fat Man rest easy in his spacious grave?

This week it was Robert Zemeckis's turn to rummage clumsily through the master's iconography and his compendium of narrative and technical innovations. The result, What Lies Beneath, is recklessly titled, because what lies beneath it are the cannibalised corpses of four or five Hitchcock movies and several by his more talented imitators.

A little Rear Window over here, a whole lotta Henri-Georges Clouzot's Les Diaboliques over there, plus the odd image from Psycho (the back of Mrs Bates's head, the shower curtain torn ring by ring from its rail) and half the bathroom scene from The Shining.

Zemeckis certainly has good taste when it comes to nicking stuff from other movies. It's just a pity that he and his scriptwriter Clark Gregg have brought so little inspiration of their own to the project.

What happened to Robert Zemeckis? It all looked so promising. His back catalogue fairly bulges with pleasures, from his wild Beatlemania comedy I Wanna Hold Your Hand to the wonderfully mean-spirited Used Cars. Two out of three Back to The Futures ain't bad, and the original is still fresh and vital. His semi-animated projects, Who Framed Roger Rabbit? and Death Becomes Her, were both packed with ideas and visual energy, even if the latter out-stayed its welcome.

But his disasters have been on a grand scale. He and his longtime writing partner Bob Gale were responsible for Spielberg's first box-office cropper, 1941, and although Forrest Gump won a fistful of Oscars, it still seems to me one of the most moronically revisionist and reactionary movies ever made.

When Tom Hanks kicked the crap out of a cartoonishly drawn 1960s black political activist, I couldn't help thinking of those former radicals - like one-time Ramparts editors Peter Collier and David Horowitz - who in the 1980s ran what Gerald Kaufman once witheringly termed "the four-minute mile on the road to Damascus" and then repositioned themselves on the spittle-flecked, neo-conservative right.

Gump's subtext seemed to be this: "Stay home, know your place, never question anything, dodge every issue, sleep through every national crisis, and generally live as passive and bovine a life as you can. Oh, and don't sleep around or you'll die of Aids."

Zemeckis's last movie, Contact, fairly hummed with self-righteousness, which I suppose is inevitable when insufferable goodie-two-shoes Jodie Foster is your star, and you have Matthew McConaughey's Catholic priest turning up at the drop of a hat like some dog-collared Marty Hopkirk.

I had been hoping that Zemeckis might recover some of his zest within the confines of a genre project like What Lies Beneath, but that hasn't happened. Instead, genre has defeated him. Harrison Ford and Michelle Pfeiffer are one of those upper-middle-class couples - house by the lake, Volvo and Honda in the driveway, yacht, scads of talent, brains and cash - who badly need terrorising out of their well-appointed complacency.

Ford is a professor of genetics and Pfeiffer is his second wife, the former cellist in a string quartet, now going quietly nuts in their soulless mansion. One day she starts hearing voices and strange sounds. Pictures fall to the floor. Doors open themselves, and Pfeiffer starts seeing the ghostly reflection of a young woman in mirrors and in her bath water.

The restive presence begins leading Pfeiffer towards the suspicion that she was murdered, possibly by Ford. With several important moments taking place in the bathroom, the malign spirit of Les Diaboliques looms prominently over the entire movie. Clouzot's follow-up to The Wages of Fear was not only Hitchcockian in spirit, but was written by Pierre Boileau and Thomas Narcejac, another of whose novels, D'Entre Les Morts, formed the basis for the sublimely anguished Vertigo.

Les Diaboliques has been remade several times, most recently starring Sharon Stone. The first version I saw, and still my favourite, was an excellent 1974 made-for-TV remake called Reflections of Murder, starring Tuesday Weld and Joan Hackett. The shocking bathtub finale freaked me out for weeks.

No such thing happened with What Lies Beneath, although its most memorable sequence involves Pfeiffer nearly drowning in the tub. Everything here seems third-hand and fourth-rate.

What lay beneath the surface of Hitchcock's greatest work was an ocean of turbulent emotions. What Lies Beneath has only the surface values of a middling to lesser Hitch production (Topaz? The Paradine Case?) but none of his cruel depths, no hinterland of fear and desire, no perverse presiding intelligence.

It bears all the depressing hallmarks of other movies in the recent Hitchcock-remake boom, from Christopher Reeves's Rear Window to Gus Van Sant's dreadful, pointless shot-for-shot remake of Psycho, and harks back to De Palma's Obsession (Vertigo-by-numbers), Dressed To Kill (Psycho, ditto) and Body Double (Rear Window and Vertigo again).

And let's face it, for all her strengths as an actress, Pfeiffer is no Hitchcock blonde. Years ago I met Joan Fontaine, the star of Rebecca and Suspicion, in a restaurant in Santa Cruz. She must have been in her mid-70s then but she swept across the room as if she was still the darling of the David Selznick Company in 1941: majestic, serene, beautiful.

I told her she was a goddess. She told me she wasn't, but happily signed my menu.

I heard that Kim Novak's house burned down today (her pet llamas were unhurt, but the only manuscript of her autobiography was destroyed, thus depriving us of an inside look at the Novak-Sammy Davis Jr love affair of the early 1960s), and my memory spiralled back through the list of her peers: Fontaine, Janet Leigh, Madeleine Carroll, Grace Kelly, Vera Miles, Tippi Hedren.

Compared to them Pfeiffer looks more like the winner of a Laguna Beach swimsuit contest. It isn't really fair to compare her with them, but then again, it isn't really wise to feast on Hitchcock's leavings either. And that didn't deter Zemeckis, did it?

webTitle: The Perfect Storm

fields.headline: The Perfect Storm
fields.standfirst: George Clooney's latest vehicle is full of sound and fury, says Peter Bradshaw, but it won't drown out the audience's snoring
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A pretty static story without much in the way of character development or plot complication
fields.body:
There's an unfortunate moment at the beginning of The Perfect Storm, Wolfgang Petersen's disaster movie about the weather, based on the 1997 true-life bestseller by Sebastian Junger.

George Clooney is Billy Tyne, a grizzled, jumper-wearing fisherman in the coastal town of Gloucester, Massachussetts. He is on the bridge of his craft, the Andrea Gail, explaining to fellow skipper Linda Greenlaw - played by Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio - just why he loves fishing so much. This is a longish set-piece speech, poignantly reprised in voiceover at the end, about the playful acquaintance with the gulls, the "throwing a wave to the lighthouse keeper's kid" as he rounds the point, the freedom of the ocean.

His words here are important - especially as almost all the rest of what Clooney has to say is destined to be shouted inaudibly into the driving wind and rain. They are there to reassure us that the agonies and dangers of the swordfisherman's life are not a banal matter of the risks involved in the pursuit of money, but part of the vocation and the tragic romance of the sea. Sadly, there's something in shot the entire time called a "bilge monitor". And, as the Andrea Gail fearlessly sails into the mighty, frothing heart of what meteorologists evidently considered to be the worst situation conceivable (what Junger called the perfect storm) this film's bilge monitor goes on the blink.

Sebastian Junger's book - part of the 90s publishing industry's tidal wave of user-friendly, single-issue historical books about cod, tulips, longitude-measuring chronometers, etc - was a passionate and compassionate study of seamanship and the weather, detailing a storm in October 1991 of unexampled ferocity, which claimed six lives.

There was arguably something a bit precious about Junger calling his little-known event a "perfect" storm, with an air of scientific exactitude or aesthetic connoisseurship, as we all know of other natural disasters of tempest and flood which have killed far more than six - are they supposed to be in some way "imperfect"? But Junger wins us over with compelling and meticulously researched detail, setting out not merely the human cost of the storm, but its scientific and even philosophical and geo-political dimensions. The storm is the occasion for a deeply felt meditation on humanity's relationship with the elements, what it might be like to die and, by implication, what it is like to live.

Petersen's movie chucks all these non-narrative elements overboard. It leaves us with a pretty static story without much in the way of character development or plot complication. Clooney, and not the storm, turns out to be the star, and so there is a great deal of Clooney shouting interminably while two or three guys off camera chuck buckets of water in his face. The purely descriptive burden of the picture boils down to a perpetually thunderstruck TV weatherman played by Chris McDonald (the baritone announcer from Robert Redford's Quiz Show) who is always gasping over his charts and intoning: "Oh my God! It's HAPPENING! The storms have collided! They are EXPLODING! You're headed right for the middle of the MONSTER!"

No they're not, though. Clooney and his shouting, stubbled crew are sailing right for the middle of some utterly unscary CGI effects, alternating with the miserable low-tech business of wading around in a freezing tank. There is a very strong cast here doing this, with John C Reilly and Mark Wahlberg among Clooney's shipmates, and Janet Wright, Rusty Schwimmer and Karen Allen as the womenfolk left behind to hug each other as the bad news rolls in. And their decent performances are topped off by an outstanding, and moving, funeral oration by Mastrantonio at the film's melancholy end.

But the sad fact is that though the storm sequences are long and loud, they are in danger of being drowned out by the sound of snoring from the auditorium. That image from the poster, for example, showing the Andrea Gail toiling up the side of a wave as high as a building, would be terrifying and awe-inspiring - if we didn't expect large white horses and surfers to come over it advertising Guinness. It is not frightening or convincing for a single moment. Never for one second is it possible to believe, really believe, in Clooney or Wahlberg in peril on the sea.

In drenched and windswept movies like Petersen's Das Boot, the mighty forces of the sea complicate and intensify human dramas and human conflict. But in The Perfect Storm, there is no compelling story on board; the inter-crew tensions are resolved well before the Beaufort scale cranks upwards, and in any case the focus on this blurs when the movie has to take in the situation of the other vessels and air-sea rescue crews involved.

These people are not allowed any back-story and Petersen seems unsure whether they should be given equal dramatic weight as the crew of the Andrea Gail. In Three Kings, Clooney and Wahlberg demonstrated that they could carry a picture as plausibly tough and masculine movie stars, and in the Coen Brothers' forthcoming O Brother Where Art Thou?, Clooney will show that he can cut it as the leading man of a light comedy. But in The Perfect Storm, Clooney, and everyone else, are all at sea.

But in The Perfect Storm, Clooney, and everyone else, are all at sea.

webTitle: Dance with the devil

fields.headline: Dance with the devil
fields.standfirst: Fiachra Gibbons on a Cannes winner's censorship battle
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons on a Cannes winner's censorship battle
fields.body:
Last week the Chinese Film Bureau appeared to take revenge on the acclaimed actor-director Jiang Wen. He decided to hightail it to Cannes with the print of his latest film, Devils on the Doorstep, before they could get their hands on it. Reportedly, Jiang has been banned from making films for seven years - a severe sentence given that China is attempting to open up its film industry to foreign investors.

Unfortunately, neither I nor even Jiang himself - who has previously shaken off a seven-year ban for acting in Zhang Yimou's Red Sorghum - have been able to confirm the punishment. The censors are not returning his calls - still less mine - so he doesn't know whether he is a banned person or not. "I've asked seven times for a meeting with the Film Bureau," he said, "but with no success."

Jiang, 37, who is not one to take interference lying down, knew he was asking for trouble by showing the film in its entirety at Cannes, where it won the Grand Prix. Officials from the bureau - whom he once had the cheek to cast as spies - had shadowed him on set and were demanding cuts before it was shown in the west. Two even followed him to France to try and persuade the Cannes president Gilles Jacob to drop the film. He didn't.

Jiang had similar hassle with his last film, In the Heat of the Sun, but after a delay and some minimal cuts it was passed. Why the bureau has taken so violently against him this time is unclear.

On the face of it, Devils on the Doorstep, set in Jiang's home province of Hebei during the brutal Japanese occupation, chimes perfectly with China's new nationalism. It is merciless in its depiction of Japanese wartime atrocities, yet has been bizarrely accused by the censors of being too soft on them.

Even odder are the whispers about too much time being given to the Japanese national anthem and the ease with which the Chinese military are crushed by the Japanese jackboot. "Demonstrating the power of the Japanese army this way hurts the feelings of the Chinese people," a Film Bureau official is reported to have said. There has also been tut-tutting over a shot of a naked woman, and the repeated use of a popular peasant epithet, "turtle fucker".

Jiang is bemused by this, and by the way the bureau kept shifting its objections as he struggled with the marathon five-month shoot, which used up the country's entire stock of Kodak black and white film.

Unlike Zhang Yimou, and Tian Zhuangzhuang, who was denounced for his 1993 film The Blue Kite and hasn't worked since, he is not prepared to find face-saving formulas. "The film shows that people must express their feelings frankly and openly," he said, "instead of bottling them up inside while smiling and nodding. This is the fault of most Orientals. If we wish to have genuine peace we must speak openly."

Openness, though, is in short supply. Unsurprisingly, the ban has not been much reported in mainland China. It barely merited a few paragraphs even in the English-language newspapers, and even those reports originated in LA.

More worryingly still, the ban has been extended to the film's producer Dong Ping, whose name is also being removed from Ang Lee's amazing new martial arts film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, in China.

With big Hollywood blockbusters like The Patriot and The Perfect Storm being shown this summer in China, observers believe the ban imposed on Jiang is more about the Film Bureau asserting its rapidly diminishing power than the sensitivities of Sino-Japanese relations.

Jiang, though, is not the type who wants to be anyone's political patsy. He is pressing ahead with his next project, The Story of Xu San-Guan the Blood Seller, about a man who sells his own blood to survive.

With its obvious symbolism, this may seem folly, but for Jiang it is clear that censorship is a state of mind. Xu San-Guan producer Ahn Dong-Kyu is similarly convinced that they will win out in the end: "We believe he will be released from this current ban by the end the year." Let's hope their confidence is not misplaced.

 Devils on the Doorstep screens at the Edinburgh Film Festival. Tickets: 0131-623 8030.

webTitle: Spy Blake loses book royalties

fields.headline: Spy Blake loses book royalties
fields.trailText: George Blake, the Soviet spy, yesterday failed in his attempt to recover £90,000 in royalties from his autobiography, No Other Choice, when the law lords ruled that he could not be allowed to profit "by doing the very thing he had promised not to do".
fields.body:
George Blake, the Soviet spy, yesterday failed in his attempt to recover £90,000 in royalties from his autobiography, No Other Choice, when the law lords ruled that he could not be allowed to profit "by doing the very thing he had promised not to do".

Delivering the judgment, Lord Nicholls said Blake should be deprived of his profits even though the books' contents were no longer confidential and the crown had suffered no loss needing compensation. The crown had "a legitimate interest in preventing Blake profiting from disclosure of official information, whether classified or not, while a member of the service [MI6] and thereafter", he said.

Blake's autobiography was published by Jonathan Cape in 1990 and received an initial royalty of £60,000 before the crown froze the rest.

Blake's lawyer, Richard Clayton, argued that the Official Secrets Act, which states that even non-damaging disclosures by former members of the security services are criminal, was incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

Lord Nicholls said the law lords were "not equipped" to decide the point. However: "An absolute rule against disclosure, visible to all, makes good sense." Lords Goff, Browne-Wilkinson and Steyn agreed; Lord Hobhouse dissented.

Blake, 74, escaped from Wormwood Scrubs prison in London in 1966, with the help of anti-nuclear campaigners, while serving a 42-year sentence. He lives in Moscow.

webTitle: Schoolboys drown in Thames

fields.headline: Schoolboys drown in Thames
fields.trailText: Two boys drowned yesterday after being swept away by strong currents as they swam in the River Thames.
fields.body:
Two boys drowned yesterday after being swept away by strong currents as they swam in the River Thames.

The pair, aged 11 and 16, who have not been named, were playing in the water when they apparently got into difficulties at Hurley Lock, near Maidenhead, Berkshire, police said. The alarm was raised by a worker in a nearby boatyard who had seen them in the deep water and later noticed they had disappeared.

Underwater search teams, a police helicopter and officers on foot searched for three hours before their bodies were discovered by police divers at 7pm.

Thames Valley police spokesman, Richard Goodfellow, said: "It would appear to be completely accidental. We have been in touch with the parents and obviously they are completely devastated.

"Tragically, no one witnessed the boys being sucked under water and the alarm was only raised later."

Hurley Lock, popular with swimmers, is known by locals for its dangerous currents.

Police did not reveal the exact spot where the boys were found and were expected to release further details today.

webTitle: Mowlam 'left ministerial papers unguarded'

fields.headline: Mowlam 'left ministerial papers unguarded'
fields.trailText: It is the dream of every backbencher to lay their hands on one. But Mo Mowlam appears to have grown blasé about owning a coveted ministerial red box after she owned up to leaving one unattended on a recent train journey.
fields.body:
It is the dream of every backbencher to lay their hands on one. But Mo Mowlam appears to have grown blasé about owning a coveted ministerial red box after she owned up to leaving one unattended on a recent train journey.

The large red leather box, decorated with a gold crest on the side, was spotted by a passenger on a Bristol to Paddington train in April after Ms Mowlam slipped out of her seat to go to the toilet. An official, who was travelling with her, admitted that the box was left unattended because he nipped down to the buffet for a cup of coffee at the same time.

The apparent oversight was spotted by a constituent of the Tory MP James Gray, who raised the matter with Ms Mowlam. In a letter to Mr Gray, the Cabinet Office minister admitted that she sometimes left her boxes unattended, but she denied there was any breach of security.

"Occasionally on a long train journey a visit to the toilet or buffet can mean that I and my ministerial box are not always inseparable," Ms Mowlam said.

"I have never left a red box open while I was not there. Any restricted material is always locked away and I can assure you that no breach of security guidelines has taken place."

The official, who travelled with Ms Mowlam, attempted to play down the incident.

"We did leave the box unattended briefly but there was no breach of security. The box was firmly locked. I went for coffee; Mo went to the loo."

The passenger who spotted the red box claimed that cabinet papers were left "lying all over the compartment" when he boarded the train at Chippenham, Wiltshire.

When he confronted Ms Mowlam in the buffet car, she was said to have been curt with him, a claim denied by the Cabinet Office official travelling with the minister.

"I was with her when we met this man and Mo was perfectly civil to him."

The Cabinet Office insisted last night that Ms Mowlam had followed the rules over red boxes because she had locked the box while it was left unattended.

Red boxes are craved by most MPs who see them as the ultimate symbol of ministerial power. Ministers proudly carry their boxes - or better have them carried - round the corridors of Westminster as a sign of their status. However, once they return home late at night most ministers are kept up until the early hours as they work their way through endless amounts of documents prepared for them by civil servants.

One shadow cabinet minister recently remarked how he could not wait to lay his hands on a red box. "Red boxes are what politics is all about."

webTitle: Europe 'should accept' 75m new migrants

fields.headline: Europe 'should accept' 75m new migrants
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The European Union could admit up to 75m immigrants over the next half-century and must be prepared to become a racially hybrid society, according to a paper drawn up by France.
fields.body:
The European Union could admit up to 75m immigrants over the next half-century and must be prepared to become a racially hybrid society, according to a paper drawn up by France.

Jean-Pierre Chevènement, the French interior minister, produced the document for a meeting of EU ministers in Marseille today. Citizens of the EU should be told, the paper says, that Europe will become an area of "cross-fertilisation" ( métissage ).

Diplomats expressed surprise at the blunt language of the text, which avoids any suspicion of Anglo-Saxon political correctness to argue that with declining fertility and birthrates, the issue of legal immigration into the EU must be tackled.

Mr Chevènement, an often outspoken nationalist, created controversy recently when he accused Germany of not having overcome its Nazi past.

"Public opinion must be told clearly that Europe, a land of immigration, will become a place where cross-fertilisation occurs," says the document. Métissage also translates as cross-breeding.

"Public opinion needs to be enlightened and convinced, and more so in countries of recent immigration than others."

But it adds: "To allow access is not to renounce all forms of control. Ensuring cross-fertilisation requires a careful and controlling hand, in immigration terms."

Mr Chevènement is in effect issuing a wake-up call to governments to consider resuming what demographers call "primary migration", encouraging the entry of economic job hunters who intend to stay and bring their families.

But the French minister anticipated that "a reasonable policy of integration" that brought in 50m to 75m immigrants by 2050 would leave unchanged "the percentage of the population of non-European origin".

Jack Straw, Britain's home secretary, is among those attending today's Marseille meeting, organised by France in its role as holder of the EU's rotating presidency. Illegal immigration is one of the topics.

"We need to look imaginatively at how to meet the legal desire for immigration," said a Home Office official in London last night.

But the unvarnished French analysis could fuel anti-EU sentiment in Britain, where the government has pledged to keep border controls and crack down on those it deems false asylum-seekers.

And across the continent, immigration has fuelled anti-foreigner sentiment in a range of countries including Germany, Sweden and Spain. In Austria the issue has been exploited by the far-right Freedom party led by Jörg Haider.

Fears are widespread of a new influx from Poland and Hungary once they join the EU in coming years.

Immigration is an increasing preoccupation for Brussels, but decisions are still made by member states, not the European Commission.

The French document is based partly on a recent survey by the UN Population Division. That said the population of the 15 EU countries and countries currently bidding for membership would fall in the next 50 years from 729m to 628m while the world's population would grow from 6bn to 9bn.

Immigrants, mostly from developing countries, would be needed to fill the vacuum, the UN report argued. Germany recently illustrated one approach to the problem, calling for the immigration of 20,000 IT specialists from India.

Ireland, whose economy is booming, is considering importing some 200,000 skilled workers over seven years.

webTitle: Hain steps up war on arms dealers

fields.headline: Hain steps up war on arms dealers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Britain intensified its campaign against international arms traffickers yesterday when a foreign office minister, Peter Hain, accused a former KGB officer of continuing to flout UN sanctions against rebel Unita forces in Angola.
fields.body:
Britain intensified its campaign against international arms traffickers yesterday when a foreign office minister, Peter Hain, accused a former KGB officer of continuing to flout UN sanctions against rebel Unita forces in Angola.

Using parliamentary privilege, which offers protection from libel, Mr Hain named a Ukrainian, Victor Bout, as one of the main sanctions busters.

"We have reason to believe that Victor Bout continues to supply arms to Angola in breach of the UN arms embargo," Mr Hain said, reiterating a claim he first made in January.

His decision to turn the spotlight again on the Ukrainian, a former senior KGB officer stationed in Africa, underlines Britain's frustration at the failure of other countries to act against sanctions busters.

In his parliamentary reply, Mr Hain said: "We call on all states to fulfil their international obligations to implement and enforce mandatory sanctions imposed by the security council of the United Nations. There can be no excuse for any state to provide support for Bout in his continued flouting of UN sanctions."

Mr Bout, a former Soviet air force officer who now lives in the United Arab Emirates, runs Air Cess, which uses old Soviet aircraft to fly arms to Unita. UN observers in Angola spotted one of his two aircraft landing in Unita territory on at least 10 occasions between October 1997 and January 1998.

Mr Hain also criticised the authorities in Gabon for failing to take action against the sale of diamonds by Unita in the capital, Libreville. He has in the past condemned the sale of "blood diamonds" to fuel Unita's war effort.

He said yesterday: "We will be raising these reports urgently with the Gabonese authorities and urging them to do everything in their power to prevent this illicit trade."

webTitle: From Osaka to Greenwich

fields.headline: From Osaka to Greenwich
fields.standfirst:
World leader has survived a string of scandals
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: • Tokushichi Nomura II, the son of a money changer from Osaka, founded Nomura Securities in 1925 after watching share dealing on Wall Street. The firm grew to become Japan's largest stockbroking company by the early 60s.
fields.body:
 Tokushichi Nomura II, the son of a money changer from Osaka, founded Nomura Securities in 1925 after watching share dealing on Wall Street. The firm grew to become Japan's largest stockbroking company by the early 60s.

 Nomura is now Japan's largest securities company and a leading international finance house. It was ranked in the top 10 of the world's securities firms by the Wall Street Journal last September. In 1999 it had assets of £80bn.

 At the height of the 80s stock market boom in Japan, Nomura was the biggest securities firm in the world, with share dealing accounting for up to 15% of turnover on the Tokyo exchange. Ten years ago it was described as "the world's most powerful company".

 The first Nomura office in Britain opened in 1964 and Nomura International was found in London in 1981. It became one of the first two foreign-owned members of the London Stock Exchange in 1986.

 At the end of the 1980s, when it became clear that Tokyo markets were overvalued and they began to collapse, Nomura was linked to the Recruit scandal. Five government ministers resigned after it was revealed that more than 150 politicians and officials profited from shares in a company floated in 1986.

 The firm's darkest hour came in 1991 when its president Yoshihisa Tabuchi resigned after admitting Nomura had been secretly covering favoured clients' losses on the markets. One of those clients was the head of a Yakuza crime syndicate.

 The firm was embarrassed last week when a London industrial tribunal heard an allegation of sexual harassment against the company. Isabelle Terrillon, 35, a Nomura trader, said she had been told to wear a short skirt, strip and provide a massage.

 The company has recently been known for a series of courageous deals on the London markets, largely due to its city star Guy Hands, 40, who joined in 1994. As managing director of Nomura International's principal finance group, he has overseen the dome bid.

 The firm's website reveals the company philosophy. "We have climbed many mountains, we have always looked beyond to the next," it says. "From each summit, we have been able to look back, too, and draw inspiration from the continuity of our aims and philosophy."

"From each summit, we have been able to look back, too, and draw inspiration from the continuity of our aims and philosophy."

webTitle: Boy found safe in cult forest hide-out

fields.headline: Boy found safe in cult forest hide-out
fields.trailText: Bobby Kelly, the missing teenager who ran away to join a nomadic cult called the Jesus Christians, was found safe and well yesterday living in a tent in a forest with two members of the group.
fields.body:
Bobby Kelly, the missing teenager who ran away to join a nomadic cult called the Jesus Christians, was found safe and well yesterday living in a tent in a forest with two members of the group.

The 16-year-old, who was made a ward of court after his disappearance a month ago, was yesterday discussing his future with lawyers representing the official solicitor, Laurence Oates, who is supervising his interests.

Mr Oates said the boy was in good spirits and would now be given space and time to reflect on his experiences, which, according to the cult, included a camping and sightseeing trip in southern England as well as the offer to go on holiday to Germany with them.

It was not clear when or where he would be reunited with his grandmother and legal guardian Ruth Kelly, with whom he lived in Romford, Essex, before he went missing, or with his mother Jessica.

Clare Kirby, solicitor for Bobby's grandmother, said the family was "extremely pleased and relieved" that Bobby had been found. "We are confident that the decision the court will now make for his future will be in his best interests and will take account of his opinion," she said.

The two men arrested when he was found, cult members Andrew Eagles and Reinhard Zeuner, were both released after a private hearing at the high court yesterday.

In the boy's only public statement yesterday, he pleaded for two other cult members arrested in the hunt for him to be spared prison sentences.

Susan and Roland Gianstefani were among the Jesus Christians he met on June 27, when he was shopping with his grandmother in Romford and saw members of the group handing out leaflets. That afternoon the boy packed some belongings and told his family he was "going with them".

The Gianstefanis were arrested on Tuesday and faced going to prison for contempt of court after refusing to reveal his whereabouts. At the high court, Anthony Kirk, counsel for the official solicitor, read a statement from Bobby in which the boy referred to the couple's fears that he would be "deprogramed".

Judge Mr Justice Sumner sentenced the Gianstefanis to six weeks in prison, but suspended the sentence because they had apologised to the court, Bobby had been found safe and well, and because they had eventually agreed to give information about his whereabouts to the court. Outside court, the Gianstefanis, who arrived in Britain last year, made it clear the cult would be seeking to maintain contact with Bobby. "We look forward to having a better relationship with Bobby and his family in future," Mr Gianstefani said.

webTitle: Asylum seeker from hijack plane loses appeal

fields.headline: Asylum seeker from hijack plane loses appeal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Stansted hijack
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: An Afghan former medical student who endured 30 lashes from his country's Taliban regime had his appeal for asylum in Britain turned down yesterday.
fields.body:
An Afghan former medical student who endured 30 lashes from his country's Taliban regime had his appeal for asylum in Britain turned down yesterday.

The man, 21, who has not been named, is among 31 Afghans from the hijacked plane that landed at Stansted in February who are appealing against an immigration decision not to give them asylum.

After arriving in Britain he told the authorities: "If the worst comes to the worst you will have to kill me and send my body back to Afghanistan."

An immigration appeals adjudicator was told yesterday that the man had been given 30 lashes for serving women in a tailor's shop, and had been forced to give up his medical studies. He feared he would be beaten if sent back to Kabul.

Rejecting his appeal, Judge Herbert Dunn said the man had not proved he would be persecuted on his return and had been on his way home when he boarded the internal flight.

The judge is to rule on the other 30 appeals in the next few days. So far only three people from the hijacked plane have been granted asylum.

webTitle: Dome given new £53m subsidy as bank buys site for amusement park

fields.headline: Dome given new £53m subsidy as bank buys site for amusement park
fields.standfirst:
Japanese company hopes that a ride on the Yellow Submarine can succeed where the troubled attraction failed
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome was effectively given another £53m hand-out by the government last night when it was revealed that more than half the proceeds of its sale to a Japanese bank will go towards offsetting its debts.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome was effectively given another £53m hand-out by the government last night when it was revealed that more than half the proceeds of its sale to a Japanese bank will go towards offsetting its debts.

The troubled attraction, which has already been bailed out twice by the Millennium Commission, has been making heavy losses and was only days from technical bankruptcy in late May when an extra £29m of lottery money was found to tide it over. The commission had previously poured £110m into the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, to solve a cash flow crisis. It is unlikely that these loans will ever be repaid.

Under the terms of the dome's sale to the finance house Nomura International, whose proposal for a Dome Europe theme park will keep much of the tent's controversial features, £53m of the £105m downpayment will go to NMEC.

Lord Falconer, the minister for the dome, said the commission "would agree to consider how that asset may be realised between now and the end of December", a broad hint that the money would be used to keep the attraction afloat until January when the Nomura consortium takes over.

The bank, which already runs two successful themes parks in Japan and the United States, intends to spend £400m turning the dome into an amusement park. A similar amount is likely to be spent transforming the Greenwich peninsula by surrounding it with a series of multi-storey hotels, shopping complexes and riverside restaurants.

Nomura's British boss, Guy Hands, hopes to succeed where the NMEC has failed by adding an interactive Yellow Submarine ride inspired by the Beatles film, and a further zone based on the American writer Maurice Sendak's cult book Where The Wild Things Are. Admission prices will be pegged at current levels, but Hands hopes to introduce a £30 season ticket to encourage repeat visits.

Smorgasbord

"We want to provide something for everyone," he said. "It's like a smorgasbord - when you have a good smorgasbord you choose what you eat, you don't mix it together and make baby food."

Less than a third of the 12m visitors the dome was originally supposed to attract have so far passed through its turnstiles, however, its controversial French-born chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau says it is no longer haemorrhaging cash.

Earlier this month he launched a television advertising campaign after claiming that "we have got the product right, now the public should come and make up their minds for themselves".

Only last week Mr Gerbeau vowed that he would not be going back to the Millennium Commission cap in hand to look for any more grants. Dome sources last night explained that he and the government prefer to see the money from the sale not as a loan but a return on NMEC's "investment" in the Greenwich site.

The remaining £52m will go to English Partnerships, the government agency which owned the site and paid for its costly decontamination.

English Partnerships felt it was entitled to the lion's share of the money, but a spokeswoman last night said it was "happy" coming off second best.

Last night Nomura insisted that the dome was not a white elephant and that it would turn a profit from what it called "Europe's first urban entertainment resort, through a combination of attractions, entertainment, food, retail, accommodation and hi-tech office facilities. This will provide a focal point for the creative arts and offer its visitors the best of European entertainment, culture and cuisine".

Lord Falconer had earlier told the House of Lords that the bid offered a "high quality" and "economically sustainable" long-term future for the dome. The decision meant the dome "has secured its future and it can plan and deliver the next five months with confidence".

He said that for commercial reasons he could not say how much English Partnerships would get from the sale of the site in the long run, but that an early payment of £105m would be made, of which £53m would go to NMEC and the rest would go to the agency. "They are getting a fair split of the money with the dome company. A sensible and fair split between the two has been made."

Asked about whether the Millennium Commission would be asked to provide a loan facility to enable the dome to remain open to the end of the year, he said the NMEC could now expect to receive its share of the sale and the commission "would agree to consider how that asset may be realised between now and the end of December". Further questioned if he thought the Japanese "would make a better job of running the dome than he and his friends did", Lord Falconer said the competition to purchase the dome "indicated that they thought that what had been created was a good commercial operation".

Incompetence

But Archie Norman, the shadow secretary of state for the environment, warned that the government was throwing "good money after bad" by bailing out the dome again. "We estimate that an additional £55m of public money meant for English Partnerships may be channelled to the dome by stealth.

"John Prescott pronounced in 1998 that 'if we can't make this work, we're not much of a government'. Well, the financial disaster it has become is a testimony to the managerial incompetence of the Cabinet members responsible."

The Nomura bid beat the only other shortlisted proposal by the Legacy group which wanted to turn the dome into a hi-tech business park to showcase British e-commerce and technological know-how.

Robert Bourne, Legacy's chief executive and a prominent Labour party donor, said: "We continue to believe that our proposals to build 'Knowledge City' presented the government with a real opportunity to turn the dome into a flagship for innovation and excellence."

Meanwhile the dome announced yesterday that it will allow the public in for free after 4pm if they take part in a fire drill.

webTitle: Tension rises in Fiji

fields.headline: Tension rises in Fiji
fields.standfirst:
New Zealanders taken hostage after army crackdown on coup plotters
Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: A military crackdown in Fiji against rebel supporters, and the arrest of the country's coup leader, triggered reprisals yesterday, including the kidnapping of two New Zealand civilian pilots.
fields.body:
A military crackdown in Fiji against rebel supporters, and the arrest of the country's coup leader, triggered reprisals yesterday, including the kidnapping of two New Zealand civilian pilots.

The pilots were taken hostage by rebel supporters as they landed on the island of Vanua Levu, hours after troops arrested the nationalist George Speight late on Wednesday.

In a dawn raid yesterday, dozens of armed troops stormed a school in the capital, Suva, where several hundred Speight supporters had been staying for two weeks since giving up control of parliament. One man died from suffocation caused by teargas and 39 others were injured, seven seriously. About 350 people were arrested.

A military spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said the raid was aimed at the instigators of Fiji's past 10 weeks of turmoil. He added that Mr Speight was arrested for threatening the life of the new president, Ratu Josefa Iloilo, and for refusing to hand in all weapons stolen from the army before his coup on May 19.

webTitle: Death rate nearly double for night births, researchers say

fields.headline: Death rate nearly double for night births, researchers say
fields.trailText: Babies born at night are almost twice as likely to die as those born in the daytime, researchers say.
fields.body:
Babies born at night are almost twice as likely to die as those born in the daytime, researchers say.

A study of 380,000 "low risk" babies born in hospitals in the German state of Hesse in the 1990s showed that death during labour or in the first seven days after birth was extremely rare, with only 57 children lost.

But the risk of babies dying was almost twice as high if they were born at night, defined by the researchers as being between 9pm and 6.59am.

The risk of the baby dying of asphyxia, where it is deprived of oxygen just before birth, was almost four times as high during the night.

Reporting on the research in the latest edition of the British Medical Journal, the German team, led by Günther Heller from Philipps-University of Marburg, said tiredness might be the explanation.

"It may be a result of staff's increased physical and mental fatigue during the night, when doctors in charge, at least in Germany, have usually worked through a complete day shift," they said. "Overreliance on less experienced staff may be another important reason for the higher risk."

Similar research in Scotland and Wales in the last decade produced contradictory results, and German working patterns are different to those in the NHS.

But James Drife, vice president of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, said he believed the Hesse survey was highly relevant to Britain.

"I wouldn't say: 'Oh, that's in Germany, it doesn't apply here,'" he said.

"My feeling as an individual is that it rings true, that we are all actually not nocturnal creatures, and that concentration levels are not so easy to maintain as during the day.

"When you come to look at cases sometimes you find that decision making is not as switched on at five o'clock in the morning. But, having said that, the absolute levels of risk are low."

Professor Drife said he and his colleagues were not complacent, and were pushing for consultants to be present in maternity units at all times, instead of just being on call.

"This piece of research would be relevant to that and would increase the pressure on us to say, 'well, we shouldn't just have consultants there during the day: we need consultants at night'."

At present the Royal College is recommending only that the largest units, such as those at big teaching hospitals, have 24-hour consultant cover.

When babies are being born in modern hospitals in western countries, a battery of sophisticated monitors is deployed to ensure that the baby is not being deprived of oxygen. But warning signs can still be missed, and if there is a problem, decisions need to be taken very quickly.

With the spread of induced labour and birth by caesarean section, the timing of births is no longer purely up to nature.

But Prof Drife said that were it left to biology, more babies would be born during the hours of darkness - possibly an evolutionary defence mechanism to protect mother and child at a vulnerable time.

webTitle: Tyre clue to plane's double engine failure

fields.headline: Tyre clue to plane's double engine failure
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Evidence was growing last night that the Concorde that crashed on Tuesday suffered a catastrophic failure in two engines, as accident investigators released details of radio conversations with the pilot, Christian Marty, moments before the plane crashed with the loss of 113 lives.
fields.byline: Jon Henley and David Hearst  in Paris
fields.body:
Evidence was growing last night that the Concorde that crashed on Tuesday suffered a catastrophic failure in two engines, as accident investigators released details of radio conversations with the pilot, Christian Marty, moments before the plane crashed with the loss of 113 lives.

The French accident investigation bureau last night said the remains of tyres had been found on the runway at Charles de Gaulle airport, outside Paris. Mr Marty had told the control tower he could not retract the undercarriage.

The bureau added that both engines on the port side of the aircraft were in grave difficulty. The pilot told the control tower that engine number two had "broken down" and that the adjacent engine lost power twice during the brief flight.

The bureau said the inability to retract the plane's undercarriage would have worsened stability problems. This could explain its sudden lurch to the left before it ploughed into a hotel in Gonesse. All 109 people on board killed, along with four on the ground.

The finding would appear to take the spotlight off the maintenance crew who worked on the thrust reverser at the rear of engine number two. The device has been at the centre of speculation about the crash.

Investigators yesterday decoded data from the two black boxes recovered from the crash site, but said it might be three days before they could pinpoint the cause. A criminal investigation for manslaughter, a legal requirement in France during a fatal accident inquiry, was launched and documents including papers relating to the repair on the thrust reverser have been seized.

However, industry experts rejected what they called unfounded speculation that a last-minute repair caused the disaster. They stressed that none of the elite team of Concorde mechanics had been suspended and argued that a malfunction of the thrust reverser could not have caused the engine to disintegrate and spark such a calamitous fire. The mechanics involved in the repair are said to be receiving psychiatric help.

Flight AF4590 took off more than an hour late after Mr Marty insisted on the repair after a fault had been reported on a flight from New York the previous day. The plane took off shortly before 4pm but flames began shooting from its left engines even before it had left the runway.

Raymond Auffray, an aeronautical engineer who was responsible for Concorde's certification nearly 25 years ago, said the only engine problem capable of causing such destruction would be a failure of the engine's turbine discs.

"If [a turbine disc failure] happens, everything would be destroyed in its path, including the turbine of the neighbouring engine and all the hydraulic controls," he said. "It does seem that the pilot was first and foremost having to fight with the controls."

The last of the bodies were recovered from the crash site yesterday, most are burned beyond recognition. Officials said the identification process, by DNA or dental records, was slow and laborious.

A minute's silence was observed at the three Paris airports at 5.30 pm yesterday as an ecumenical memorial service attended by the German foreign minister Joshka Fischer and senior members of the French government began at the ornate Madeleine church in the city centre.

Air France, which declined to comment on the progress of the investigation, announced it would pay an advance of £14,000 to relatives "for their immediate material needs" and also pay for funerals and any counselling required.

Bernard Maugis, a CGT union representative and Concorde mechanic, said that in 30 years he had never seen human error during an aircraft repair lead to an accident.

"Planes are repaired before take off every day, all over the world," he said. "The rules are extremely strict and do not depend on the airline concerned. Every repair is checked at several levels."

The mayor of Gonesse, Jean-Pierre Blazy, who has led the town's battle against night flights over their homes, said a silent march would be held through the streets this afternoon in remembrance of the victims. He also threatened legal action against Air France for compensation on behalf of the town.

 Additional reporting by Amy Lodge

webTitle: Tragic end of Concorde fan's dream

fields.headline: Tragic end of Concorde fan's dream
fields.standfirst:
Town grieves as families lay flowers at scene
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Klaus Frentzem was a Concorde fan who collected toy models of the aircraft. The 53-year-old secondary school teacher finally saved enough for a belated honeymoon with his wife Margaret - starting with a flight on the supersonic airliner.
fields.byline: Tony Patterson in Mönchengladbach and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Klaus Frentzem was a Concorde fan who collected toy models of the aircraft. The 53-year-old secondary school teacher finally saved enough for a belated honeymoon with his wife Margaret - starting with a flight on the supersonic airliner.

Like 11 other Mönchengladbach residents, the Frentzems' dream holiday ended in Tuesday's crash. Two adult daughters and a son survive them.

Yesterday fellow teachers at his school paid tribute to their lost colleague: "It is often assumed that Concorde passengers are luxury obsessed and always after some sort of out of the ordinary kick. Klaus Frentzem was not that kind of person," said the school's headmaster Ludwig Heisterkamp.

"He was just a fan who collected everything he could about the aircraft. His two ambitions were to fly on Concorde and go by ship through the Panama canal. They saved up for years to go on the trip, it was meant to be the honeymoon that they never had."

The Frentzems were not typical of the 96 German crash victims. Most were business people for whom supersonic air travel and luxury foreign cruises were the well-earned fruits of years building up their businesses.

Andreas Schranner, 64, and his wife Maria, 62, sold their Munich bus company two years ago to go on cruises. They were killed in the crash along with their daughter Andrea, son-in-law Christian and their two children aged 10 and 8. The Schranners had invited their family to join them on the cruise as a special treat for their grandchildren. "They were talking about it weeks before the holiday began," said one of their classmates.

Other crash victims included Werner Tellmann, 69, and his wife Margareta, 66. They spent 40 years developing their interior furnishings business in the Mönchengladbach suburb of Rheydt. They had only started going on expensive holidays in recent years.

Most of the relatives of the crash victims were in Paris yesterday where they were allowed to lay flowers at the crash site. Mönchengladbach is to hold its own memorial service on Saturday.

In New York, the cruise ship MS Deutschland on which most of the victims had been booked to sail was preparing to depart as scheduled.

In the first two-week leg of its journey to Sydney, the ship is expected to stop in Florida and Nassau before travelling through the Panama Canal to Ecuador.

Concorde incidents in the past year

January 14 2000 Maintenance reveals cracks three quarters of an inch long

January 29 2000 Engine shutdown as Concorde approached Heathrow because of a fuel shortage

February 12 2000 Bird strike at 1,800ft as Concorde left New York. Engine surged but damage was contained within engine casing

April 14 2000 Number three engine shut down due to loss of oil. Plane landed safely

July 18 2000 Recurring surge on left-hand engine. Third such incident in the space of several weeks

Source: Civil Aviation Authority

webTitle: Railtrack wins big fees increase

fields.headline: Railtrack wins big fees increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Regulator Tom Winsor yesterday allowed Railtrack a 40% rise in charges to £13bn over the next five years in return for efficiency improvements.
fields.body:
Regulator Tom Winsor yesterday allowed Railtrack a 40% rise in charges to £13bn over the next five years in return for efficiency improvements.

Mr Winsor insisted that the decision would not lead to "automatic fare increases" for passengers. To justify the money, Railtrack's efficiency would have to rise by between 3% and 5% over the same period.

The rise will be met partly by increased access charges to operating firms but mainly from grants. The government is setting aside £3.6bn for investment and £4bn in subsidies for the industry over the next three years.

It is insisting that at least a third of the investment must come from the private sector.

Railtrack reacted favourably to the plan, which must be finalised before next April when the new charges begin, although it warned that it might have to cut up to 2,000 jobs to meet the efficiency targets.

Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, described the proposals as "extremely challenging". But the company would work collaboratively with the regulator to achieve "a bigger, better railway".

Mr Winsor's announcement led to a rise in Railtrack shares by more than 60p to £10.20.

Mr Winsor said that the railway system had been privatised with a lack of vision and clarity, and the industry and the public had reaped what was then sown.

The industry was experiencing substantial growth and the system "is straining to accommodate much higher traffic".

He admitted that Railtrack had succeeded in its push for more money but there was "a very strong public demand that the money must be spent wisely, and the years of deterioration must not be repeated".

He has therefore rejected Railtrack's vague plans to update the network over the next year and asked for it to produce a detailed plan, defining precisely where the improvements will be made.

Mr Winsor said: "Incentive regulation is better than an overbearing culture of intrusion and enforcement. Command and control is not the best way to make competent companies perform to their best potential."

webTitle: Stepstone eager for autumn

fields.headline: Stepstone eager for autumn
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Stepstone, the Anglo-Norwegian online recruitment firm, expects a summer of heavy losses but hopes office workers returning from the holiday season with renewed appetites for new jobs will accelerate its drive to profitability.
fields.body:
Stepstone, the Anglo-Norwegian online recruitment firm, expects a summer of heavy losses but hopes office workers returning from the holiday season with renewed appetites for new jobs will accelerate its drive to profitability.

Giles Clark, chief executive of the rapidly expanding business, said yesterday that losses for the second quarter had widened and warned they were likely to reach a new peak during the third quarter.

However, Mr Clark believes the introduction of more user-friendly technology and increased movement in the workforce during the autumn should drive down losses. Analysts expect Stepstone to break even by the end of 2001.

Net losses for the three months to June 30 rose to €33.3m (£20.5m) from €2.6m the previous year, while revenues grew from €2.7m to €11m. On a quarterly basis revenues climbed by 51%.

The increased losses reflect heavy investment in pan-European expansion. The Oslo-based business will open centres in Austria, Finland, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain in the next six months taking the total of countries in which it operates to 11.

"We have a strong cash position of €187m at the end of June and our business plan indicates that we have more than sufficient resources until we become cash positive," Mr Clarke said. In June Stepstone registered 3m user sessions.

Web-hosting firm Telecity predicted yesterday that it, too, should turn profitable at the operating level by the end of 2001. The group raised £120m through a flotation in June to help fund the opening of as many as 42 internet services centres across Europe.

In the six months to June, it recorded sales of £4m and a pre-tax loss of £7.2m.

The shares closed up 20p at £12.32.

webTitle: Afghan leader refuses to give up Bin Laden to US

fields.headline: Afghan leader refuses to give up Bin Laden to US
fields.trailText: The Taliban launched a new magazine yesterday which styled the movement as "a simple band of rural youths" and quoted its leader as saying that despite the threat of new sanctions against Afghanistan, he would never hand over Osama bin Laden to face terrorism charges in the west.
fields.body:
The Taliban launched a new magazine yesterday which styled the movement as "a simple band of rural youths" and quoted its leader as saying that despite the threat of new sanctions against Afghanistan, he would never hand over Osama bin Laden to face terrorism charges in the west.

In another article, headlined "Confessions of an Arab spy", a Syrian man, 22, claimed to have been sent to infiltrate the Taliban in February on behalf of US and Israeli intelligence agencies.

He said he was blackmailed by a recruiter with money and sex after being "strongly affected" one night while in the United Arab Emirates watching a Sony PlayStation game.

He said he was told that his contact in Pakistan would be a woman named Florence at the US embassy in Islamabad. "She was described to me as a fat woman who wears glasses. She specialises in espionage and speaks seven languages, including Arabic," he alleged.

On the subject of Mr Bin Laden, the Taliban's reclusive leader, Mullah Omar, said he refused to give in to US pressure to surrender the suspected terrorist. The Taliban regard Mr Bin Laden as a hero for his help in bankrolling the guerrilla fight against the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the 1980s. His financial resources continue to aid Kabul's new masters; they also rather enjoy the fact that his presence aggravates the Americans. At some point they may use him as a bargaining chip.

The Saudi millionaire - long exiled by his country - is wanted by a US court for the bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania two years ago in which more than 200 people, mainly Africans, died.

"Extraditing Osama bin Laden, who made jihad (holy war) against the Communists for the duration of their occupation of Afghanistan, is tantamount to leaving a pillar of our religion," Mullah Omar said in the magazine.

If there were sufficient evidence against Mr Bin Laden, he said, the Taliban would try him in an Islamic court. He suggested that a meeting of Islamic scholars from Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia and a third country should decide how to resolve the issue.

The United States says it has already provided sufficient evidence of Mr Bin Laden's involvement in the bombings.

In November the United Nations security council imposed financial and aviation sanctions on Afghanistan for failing to turn Mr Bin Laden in. More embargo measures are now being considered.

The Taliban magazine in which the mullah's interview appeared is billed as a monthly is published in English. The publication, which is titled the Islamic Emirate, said its aim was to counter "misinformation from Zionist media" and opposition to the Taliban from the US.

With a forlorn cover picture of a half-destroyed village by the Kabul river, the magazine carried a series of articles about Islam and Afghanistan interspersed with verses from the Koran.

Giving an outline of the war-torn 1990s in Afghanistan, it described the Taliban as "a simple band of dedicated youths from rural Kandahar".

Under Mullah Omar, the Taliban have taken over most of the country in the past decade and enforced their strict interpretation of Islamic sharia law. Afghan women have become virtual prisoners in their homes, banned from employment, and public amputations and executions have been used against criminals.
