webTitle: Canada waits to welcome polite modern Vikings

fields.headline: Canada waits to welcome polite modern Vikings
fields.standfirst: Icelanders retrace the 1,000-year-old epic voyage of 'Leif the Lucky' to the New World
fields.trailText: The Vikings are coming. Nine impeccably peaceful Vikings will clamber out of a historic wooden sailing ship on to the northern tip of Newfoundland today after a voyage of nearly 2,000 miles from Iceland; their minds will probably be focused less on pillaging than on having a relaxing warm bath.
fields.body:
The Vikings are coming. Nine impeccably peaceful Vikings will clamber out of a historic wooden sailing ship on to the northern tip of Newfoundland today after a voyage of nearly 2,000 miles from Iceland; their minds will probably be focused less on pillaging than on having a relaxing warm bath.

As the Icelanders step ashore - to be welcomed by Herb Gray, the deputy prime minister of Canada - these intrepid latter-day Norsemen will rekindle memories of an era of exploration and seamanship that is only eclipsed in most people's minds by the deeds of Christopher Columbus and his contemporaries.

Although this year's 1,000th anniversary of the voyage of Leif Eriksson has spawned fewer tributes and a more human scale of commemoration than Columbus's 500th anniversary celebrations eight years ago, it has also stirred far less controversy.

Nearly 500 years before Columbus sailed the ocean blue, "Leif the Lucky" and his crew of Viking sailors became the first Europeans to set foot in north America.

The bay at L'Anse aux Meadows in northern Newfound land where the Viking voyagers are scheduled to arrive today may also be the spot where Eriksson and his crew first stood on dry land after their voyage from Greenland in AD1,000. Archaeologists have identified it as the only known Viking settlement in the new world.

To mark the event, the Viking ship, Islendingjur - the Icelander - has been retracing Eriksson's epic voyage across the northern oceans. Made from pine and oak and modelled on a Viking ship excavated in Norway in the 19th century, with a crew of nine experienced Icelandic sailors, and under the guidance of a man who claims to be related to Eriksson, the Islendingjur left Reykjavik on June 17, Iceland's national day.

"From the deck I can see only the sea, which is calm, and the sun is shining," the Islendingjur's captain, Gunnar Marel, told the Guardian by radio-telephone last weekend. "We are having a very good voyage."

Today's Viking voyagers are equipped with luxuries that their predecessors lacked; their ship has an engine for emergencies, and below deck there is electricity and modern conveniences. They talk every day to their project manager, in Reykjavik and they are shadowed across the oceans by a small modern support vessel.

But lunch still sometimes consists of fried puffin, a small, pigeon-sized seabird which is a familiar delicacy to Westman Island Icelanders like Mr Marel, as perhaps it was to Eriksson and his crew. "We are eating Icelandic food of the sort we have been eating for 1,000 years," Mr Marel said.

The most dangerous part of the voyage was the approach to Greenland, the captain said. "We were twice in serious conditions, with heavy seas, fog, icebergs and a dark night. For 10 hours it was as difficult as it gets on the seas."

In the end, though, Mr Marel brought his ship safely to southern Greenland, where it was greeted in warm sunshine by huge crowds, led by Greenland's head of state, Queen Margarethe of Denmark.

Eriksson's father, Erik the Red, established a Viking colony at Brattahlid in Greenland in the 10th century, where Viking settlements remained for more than four centuries.

The Islendingjur left Brattahlid on July 19 and made unexpectedly rapid progress south towards Newfoundland; the ship had to slow down to arrive on schedule today.

Eriksson's epic voyage was well known for many centuries from the early medieval Vinland Saga. But it was not until 1960, when the site at L'Anse aux Meadows was first excavated by Norwegian archaeologists, that the Viking's presence in North America was confirmed.

Even though L'Anse aux Meadows has become a major historical site, much mystery surrounds the extent of the Viking explorations in the region. Many Viking artifacts have been discovered north of Newfoundland, in Labrador and Baffin Island, pointing to an extensive network of trade with the indigenous people.

However, a Norse coin, thought to have been traded with American Indians, has also been found as far south as the US state of Maine, and husks of butternuts, which do not grow as far north as Newfoundland, have been dug up at L'Anse aux Meadows.

As such, there is room for speculation that Vikings may have travelled as far as southern New England - or down the St Lawrence river to, and even beyond, the Great Lakes.

Whatever else the Vikings may or may not have done in north America, the millennial commemorations of Eriksson's voyage have undoubtedly stimulated fresh American interest in the Norse voyages to the new world. Mr Marel and his crew plan to sail the Islendingjur on to the Canadian maritime province Nova Scotia, before heading for New Hampshire, Boston, Rhode Island and Connecticut in the US.

On October 5, they will become the first Vikings to sail their longship into New York harbour - assuming, contrary to Mr Marel's belief - that Leif the Lucky did not get to the Big Apple 1,000 years earlier.

webTitle: Merrill unit in spin-off

fields.headline: Merrill unit in spin-off
fields.trailText: The 30-strong team of private equity experts at Merrill Lynch Investment Management are spinning off their £650m business in a move that is expected to spark a flurry of similar deals among rival venture capital specialists.
fields.body:
The 30-strong team of private equity experts at Merrill Lynch Investment Management are spinning off their £650m business in a move that is expected to spark a flurry of similar deals among rival venture capital specialists.

Market watchers believe Charterhouse Development Capital and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Private Equity are also looking for greater independence from their parent groups.

The spun-off group from US-owned Merrill Lynch will retain its Mercury Private Equity name for the coming year.

The outfit was the former owner of the Priory, the chain of rehabilitation centres favoured by the rich and famous. The Priory was sold earlier this year to Westminster Healthcare for £94m.

Ian Armitage, chief executive of Mercury Private Equity, set the transaction against a background where similar deals had already happened and predicted other transactions would take place.

"We're dealing with entrepreneurs and we don't mind taking calculated risks," he said.

The operation will continue to manage its existing investments and future ones for Merrill Lynch, which has been promoting private equity investment among its fund management clients.

Industry sources said the transaction was taking place at a time when Merrill Lynch was also trying to set up its own private equity operation, to specialise in different areas.

Mercury's other investments include a 75% stake in vets specialist Dechra Pharmaceuticals, and a management buyout from Lloyds Chemists, which is reportedly eyeing a £100m stock market flotation.

Market watchers believe Charterhouse Development Capital and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Private Equity are also looking for greater independence from their parent groups. The spun-off group from US-owned Merrill Lynch will retain its Mercury Private Equity name for the coming year. The outfit was the former owner of the Priory, the chain of rehabilitation centres favoured by the rich and famous. The Priory was sold earlier this year to Westminster Healthcare for £94m. Ian Armitage, chief executive of Mercury Private Equity, set the transaction against a background where similar deals had already happened and predicted other transactions would take place. "We're dealing with entrepreneurs and we don't mind taking calculated risks," he said. The operation will continue to manage its existing investments and future ones for Merrill Lynch, which has been promoting private equity investment among its fund management clients. Industry sources said the transaction was taking place at a time when Merrill Lynch was also trying to set up its own private equity operation, to specialise in different areas. Mercury's other investments include a 75% stake in vets specialist Dechra Pharmaceuticals, and a management buyout from Lloyds Chemists, which is reportedly eyeing a £100m stock market flotation.

webTitle: Glaxo chief attacks health care regulators

fields.headline: Glaxo chief attacks health care regulators
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome's chairman, Sir Richard Sykes, bowed out with a savage attack on Britain's healthcare regulators yesterday as he presented the drugs group's last results before its merger with SmithKline Beecham.
fields.body:
Glaxo Wellcome's chairman, Sir Richard Sykes, bowed out with a savage attack on Britain's healthcare regulators yesterday as he presented the drugs group's last results before its merger with SmithKline Beecham.

One-off profits from the sale of assets pushed Glaxo's interim pre-tax profits up 20% to £1.59bn. However, Sir Richard blamed "confusion" over the role of the new National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) for a disappointing performance from the group's much-hyped flu drug Relenza.

Nice advised the government against prescribing Relenza on the National Health Service, saying further trials should be carried out to assess its efficacy in treating vulnerable groups such as the elderly. Sir Richard said this ruling had sent a negative message out to "all the other drugs agencies in the world".

"The healthcare system is respected here. The message went out that the drug didn't work," he said. "It had a big impact on how the drug progressed in other countries."

Half-year sales of Relenza were only £19m worldwide, well below expectations.

The shortfall was partly due to a mild winter in America, which meant flu was less prevalent, but Sir Richard said Nice's decision had aggravated the drug's bad start. He insisted he had no objection to Nice rationing drugs on economic grounds, but said other medical bodies should decide whether products worked effectively.

Glaxo's profits were aided by £144m of gains from the sale of investments, including the group's stake in the high-flying US biotech firm Affymetrix. Some analysts expressed surprise that this income had been put through the group's profit and loss account, rather than accounted for on its balance sheet.

Underlying profits rose 8% to £1.49bn, aided by booming sales of asthma drugs Flixotide and Seretide. Higher spending on direct-to-consumer advertising in America paid off with more sales, although profit margins declined.

The shares rose 65p to £19.09. Analyst Bill Blair of Nomura said: "The results are well above expectations. Sales growth was stronger than most people had thought, and the level of disposals was higher."

However, he added: "I think Relenza's going to be a very, very difficult haul back for Glaxo."

Glaxo's drugs for HIV did well, with sales up 13% to £536m. However, Lotronex, the group's new treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, generated revenue of just £19m.

Sir Richard takes a non-executive role when Glaxo's merger with SmithKline is completed in September.

He becomes rector of Imperial College next year with plans to improve links between the science world and business.

He said: "We need to make sure we bring the knowledge base closer to business."

Relenza in a nutshell

 In 1983, Australian physicist Peter Colman discovered a "soft spot" in flu viruses.

 The drug was taken on by Australian biotech firm Biota, which signed up Glaxo Wellcome in 1989 to develop it.

 Trials showed that if taken within 36 hours of flu striking, Relenza could speed recovery by up to two days, at a cost of £24 per patient.

 Relenza was first approved in Sweden in February 1999. Analysts predicted first-year sales of £100m, reaching a peak of £500m in 2005.

 In October, the national institute for clinical excellence said the drug was not cost effective. Glaxo chairman Sir Richard Sykes threatened to move the company overseas.

 Relenza has generated revenue of just £19m in its first six months.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ticketing firms' deal called off
fields.body:
Ticketing firms' deal called off

Britain's second largest ticketing company, First Call International, and Tickets.com called off their merger yesterday after a sharp fall in the US dot.com's share price.

Tickets.com had announced at end-February - just weeks ahead of a steep fall in internet shares - that it had agreed to acquire the unlisted First Call International in an all-paper offer aimed at expanding Tickets.com's overseas presence.

Since then Tickets.com's share price has plunged almost 79%. First Call International said it would look at other ways of working with Tickets.com but would also now look at other potential partners to help the British company meet its potential.

Lloyd's chief goes part time

Lloyd's Of London said the role of chairman would revert to being a part-time position from next year and said present chairman Max Taylor decided not to stand for re-election when his term ends in December.

Lloyd's said deputy chairman Sax Riley would succeed Taylor for one year until a candidate for chairmanship in the new form is found.

IBT to set up investment arm

International Biotechnology Trust, which was recently forced to reconstruct following a move initiated by a rebel shareholder, announced yesterday it would set up a separate investment vehicle.

IBT investors who were still keen to invest in the biotechnology sector would be able to invest in this vehicle, whose initial net asset value would be not less than 50% of IBT's assets.

BEUC voices merger worry

An influential consumers' group has written to the European Commission voicing concern over Time Warner's proposed merger with America Online and planned joint venture with EMI Group.

BEUC, or the European Consumers' Organisation, said yesterday it had told competition commissioner Mario Monti that the deals could hinder competition and threaten consumer choice and the right to privacy.

The two separate deals are both presently being reviewed by EU competition authorities.

BEUC said it was artificial to distinguish between them. "They are linked in fact," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Concorde may be prone to fires, report claimed

fields.headline: Concorde may be prone to fires, report claimed
fields.standfirst:
Engine trouble link to fuel tank blaze
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: A fuel-tank fire triggered by catastrophic engine failure could have caused the crash of the Air France Concorde this week and TWA flight 800, which went down over the Atlantic in 1996, American fire specialists suggested last night.
fields.byline: Keith Harper and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
A fuel-tank fire triggered by catastrophic engine failure could have caused the crash of the Air France Concorde this week and TWA flight 800, which went down over the Atlantic in 1996, American fire specialists suggested last night.

A report by Blazetech of Cambridge, Massachusetts, written nearly 25 years ago specifically mentions the vulnerability of the Concorde to fires produced by catastrophic engine failure.

An account of the report in this week's issue of New Scientist says that the risk of fire and explosion in the Concorde's fuel tanks was initially recognised in a British Aerospace report in 1976.

British Aerospace, now called BAe Systems, last night refused to release the report for "judicial reasons" surrounding the investigation into the Air France crash.

Blazetech produced its report for the US Federal Aviation Administration after the TWA flight crashed into the Atlantic in 1996.

The author of the Blazetech report, Albert Moussa, said last night that the television pictures of the doomed Concorde just before it crashed showed that "a distinct portion of the flame was quite hot".

"This suggests to me that the metal parts of the engine are burning and the engine failure was pretty severe," he said.

Mr Moussa said that any air disaster of this type usually depended on a sequence of events: Two of which he said were that the fragment of metal in any engine failure had to be large enough to puncture the fuel tank; and the plane had to be unlucky enough to be travelling in the direction of the leaking fuel supply, exposing it to elements that could ignite it.

Britain's regulatory body, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), last night released details of a list of 37 safety-related incidents, referred to as "mandatory occurrence reports" (MOR), involving British Airways fleet of seven Concordes during the past 12 months.

The CAA has to be notified by the company if an MOR has been filed by a pilot or air traffic control.

The CAA said that the number of MORs for the Concorde was slightly lower than normal for a fleet of BA's size during a 12-month period.

A spokesman said: "Most of these incidents will be relatively minor and will not directly affect the safety of the flight."

During the past 12 months, six incidents were filed after an engine had shutdown.

Several incidents involving the Concorde's airframe were also reported, including wing cracks and wing spar defects.

But officials said the frequent and stringent inspections demanded by the CAA meant that all these incidents were discovered before they affected safety.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Mask Of Zorro | Headf**k Weekend | The Negotiator | Niagara, Niagara
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Richard Vine & Rebecca Carroll
fields.body:
The Mask Of Zorro

(Martin Campbell, 1998)

1pm, 8pm, Sky Premier

More derring-dos, with Old California's own Robin Hood legend; it's overlong, but done with great verve. Antonio Banderas, a dashing hero in the Tyrone Power mould, is the rugged, buffoonish Murrieta, protegé of the now elderly Zorro (Anthony Hopkins) who trains him to fight, ride and smile wickedly, and to take on corrupt Governor Montero (Stuart Wilson). Amid the zestful action, Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Zorro's long-lost daughter, pretty sharp with a blade herself.

Headf**k Weekend

10pm, Sci-Fi

An inspired theme weekend, kicking off tonight with Peter Jackson's freaky puppet gross-out Bad Taste. Tim Burton's Frankenweenie is a warm and funny black and white gem, while Dougal And The Blue Cat, a feature-length Magic Roundabout spin-off, is a bad-vibe polemic against the evils of totalitarianism and conformity. Two episodes of The Hunger, and videos from Aphex Twin and The Prodigy, round things up.

The Negotiator

(F Gary Gray, 1998)

10.15pm, Sky Premier

Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser and a bunch of police bigwigs and admin staff hostage, and demands that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey), handles the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of US cinema's most charismatic leads gives a powerful charge to a clever drama; it's a pity the pair share so little time on screen.

Niagara, Niagara

(Bob Gosse, 1997)

10.20pm, FilmFour

Indie film-making imitates Oliver Stone in this road movie with a twist, featuring a shoplifter (Henry Thomas) and a Tourette's sufferer (Robin Tunney). Her tics and liking for guns ensure they're drawn into mayhem, mainly due to others' incomprehension of her condition. But ultimately it's a bit insincere.

webTitle: Love and money

fields.headline: Love and money
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Americans have already learned to love their national pastimes of litigation, firearms for all and dog-eat-dog economics, so why not a policy of baby-u-like adoptions with exorbitant fees payable in advance?
fields.body:
Americans have already learned to love their national pastimes of litigation, firearms for all and dog-eat-dog economics, so why not a policy of baby-u-like adoptions with exorbitant fees payable in advance? Baby Business (BBC1) probed into the US's private adoption industry, currently turning over 30,000 babies a year. It was a film which confirmed the aphorism about Britain and the States being two nations divided by a common language.

Where adoption in this country involves exhaustive vetting, and is confidential and anonymous, America's rampant free marketeers have turned it into a cash-based popularity contest. Anybody can get in on the act, from adoption agencies to attorneys to self-made entrepreneurs. Down in San Antonio, Texas, single mother Denise, six months pregnant with baby number four, was seen contacting an adoption agency with a view to fitting her forthcoming child into their promotional plans. Competition's so fierce for adoptable infants that "birth mothers" (sounds like something from an X-File about alien abductions) find themselves in the middle of a bidding war, with desperate childless couples queueing up to advertise their suitability and to bankroll them through their pregnancy.

Denise leafed through a bundle of self-promoting brochures produced by hopeful adopters. The one she liked best was a nauseous Little House On The Prairie-style publication concocted by Steve and Beth Slattery from Charlotte, North Carolina. The pages were decorated with trees and flowers, and showed pictures of the lovely Slattery home. Unctuous homilies to the "birth mother" accompanied the artwork: "You have already done a beautiful job with your first decision to choose life for your baby!"

The Slatterys are an intensely God-fearing couple. How strange, then, that their love for their fellow man doesn't extend as far as embracing the notion of adopting a black or Latin baby. "We wanted a little baby that would look like us," explained Steve. Perhaps, in a spirit of true Christian forbearance, they were just seeking to help couples less well off than themselves - in the adoption tariff, non-white babies are always available at knock-down prices.

Legally, a "birth mother" can always reverse her decision to give up her child for adoption, even if she has accepted money upfront, though fraud is allegedly rare (no consolation to Mr and Mrs Garner, who were conned out of $12,000 by a woman in Seattle who only pretended to be pregnant). The Slattery adoption ran like clockwork, the couple cooing and schmoozing shamelessly over Denise as her pregnancy advanced, then finally attending the birth itself, hovering inches away from the emerging infant like the witches' coven in Rosemary's Baby. This was stomach-turning stuff in every respect, from that great nation where people murder each other after appearing on Springer-style chat shows.

And so to some cathartic pyrotechnics, courtesy of special effects man Peter Hutchinson. Master Blasters (BBC2) followed Hutchinson on location in the Bahamas, where he was involved in setting up a holocaust of explosions, gunfire and rocketry for... Mission Impossible 3? Die Hard With A Paper Umbrella Floating In It? No, it was for a promotional film for the Royal Navy. Tax-payers and Gordon Brown will be pleased to hear the navy demanded spectacular results from a parsimonious budget.

The fact that the navy has to resort to making pocket-sized blockbusters in order to entice Britain's lethargic youth into signing up is a bizarre enough phenomenon in itself (perhaps they should reintroduce the concept of prize money, which proved such an urgent incentive in Nelson's era), so much so that the ridiculous storyline of the Hutchinson film was tactfully passed over without comment. A "warlord" in a tropical hellhole was going round kidnapping innocent Europeans. The hostages had to be rescued by the Royal Marines, while Her Majesty's frigate Montrose zapped Mr Bad Guy with Harpoon missiles. Since Harpoons cost £500,000 each, Hutchinson's crew had to build fake ones that, being unguided, kept turning round and heading straight back for the ship. Even concocting the illusion of robust peace-keeping in a fantasy world is not without risk.

webTitle: Passnotes

fields.headline: No: 1687 Dr David Hope
fields.body:
Age: 60.

Occupation: Archbishop of York.

So what's bothering the archbish? He has accused the Church of England of arrogance and a predisposition towards "rather tedious" services.

So he's one of those evangelical reformers who thinks church should be like a rock concert, is he? Not exactly. Until now, Hope has been at the more Catholic end of the C of E spectrum, despite admitting to "ambiguous" sexuality when challenged by OutRage!

Not a touchy-feely, hippy-dippy liberal like his boss, George Carey, then? No. Last year, he threatened to resign if the Church were to consecrate women bishops and he supports the Act of Synod, which allows worshippers who object to women priests to be cared for by "flying" bishops.

They would perk up a dull service. Heathen. He means locums.

It still sounds unholy. Actually, the archbishop is deeply concerned about the worship of unholy icons. After the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, he questioned whether the nation's fixation with her image might be contrary to her wishes.

Contrary to the church's wishes, more like - she was taking away customers. Hold your tongue. "We should be careful that she is not worshipped, that worship should be directed to the God who created her," he said.

Hence the need to jazz up the old church services a bit? Well, it would help arrest the decline of the congregation. Hope spoke of "a readiness to take risks and move out of the confines of our churchiness and religiosity into the territory of those of today who seem to have heard the name of Jesus Christ only as a curse rather than a blessing".

Wow. That's got me interested. Then might I refer you to the archbishop's two publications, the Leonine Sacramentary (1971) and Living the Gospel (1993)?

Do say: "Hilarious service, vicar, next week I'll bring masking tape."

Don't say: "Today's sermon will be on the meditative value of watching paint dry."

Hope spoke of "a readiness to take risks and move out of the confines of our churchiness and religiosity into the territory of those of today who seem to have heard the name of Jesus Christ only as a curse rather than a blessing". Wow. That's got me interested. Then might I refer you to the archbishop's two publications, the Leonine Sacramentary (1971) and Living the Gospel (1993)? Do say: "Hilarious service, vicar, next week I'll bring masking tape." Don't say: "Today's sermon will be on the meditative value of watching paint dry."

webTitle: Who are you? What the One2One ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the One2One ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: We open on a lively beach scene, with sun-worshippers lying on loungers and bikini-clad lovelies playing bat and ball. Suddenly we hear the irritating trill of a mobile phone and we zoom up into an apartment overlooking the beach. Three blokes are slumped together, fast asleep, on a sofa. A naked couple are in bed, comatose, while another bloke is lying on the balcony, fully clothed, sandals kicked off beside his feet. The phone is lying on a table in the living room, ringing out and being totally ignored. "One2One - the pay-as-you-go phone you can use abroad," says the voiceover.

A naked couple are in bed, comatose, while another bloke is lying on the balcony, fully clothed, sandals kicked off beside his feet. The phone is lying on a table in the living room, ringing out and being totally ignored. "One2One - the pay-as-you-go phone you can use abroad," says the voiceover.

The jargon: Owners of One2One's pay-as-you-go phones can, as of this summer, use them while on holiday somewhere foreign - the first pay-as-you-go phones that can do this, apparently. The ad is one of three that are simply aimed at raising awareness of the revolutionary new service.

Personality: You are young, probably 18-24, you use your moby for leisure rather than work and, well, you're about to go on holiday or you're in "a holiday mindset". Even if you're not young, you're a "young holidaymaker at heart" says agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

Financial status: One2One is positioned as a good value mobile phone network. It leads the market in providing bargain-basement tariffs, and people who use it are cost-conscious because they tend to make more calls than users of other, fancier-priced rival networks such as Orange.

Telling lifestyle detail: You like to holiday in Ibiza with your mates, go camping in France, or possibly go for a more adventurous holiday destination like India or Thailand. Wherever, you like fun and frolics.

Other relevant data: The spot was filmed just outside Malaga. The bloke on the balcony is in fact the account director at BBH. He denies he had a hangover for real, despite admitting it wasn't too difficult "recreating those holiday moments" on the shoot.

webTitle: Salmond bows out with an independent air

fields.headline: Salmond bows out with an independent air
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The outgoing Scottish Nationalist leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday predicted independence for Scotland before the 300th anniversary of the Act of Union with England in 2007 - but warned that Tony Blair may burn out long before then.
fields.body:
The outgoing Scottish Nationalist leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday predicted independence for Scotland before the 300th anniversary of the Act of Union with England in 2007 - but warned that Tony Blair may burn out long before then.

In a farewell Westminster press conference, the 45-year-old MP insisted he was stepping down because he was leaving the SNP in a very strong position - ahead of Labour in some polls - and 10 years was long enough for a party leader.

Mr Salmond predicted that the pace of demand for full independence from England has grown - not weakened, as Labour predicted - in the year since Scotland got its devolved parliament in Edinburgh.

But he coupled his personal optimism with a warning to the prime minister, to "chill out or get out". Unless Mr Blair "re-evaluates the way he approaches politics" and starts to ignore his pollster Philip Gould's focus groups he would not stay the course, Mr Salmond predicted.

"Tony Blair is looking dreadful, he's had just six years [as Labour leader], he won't last 10 years," he said. "The message coming back [from Mr Blair's pollsters] is that people don't like you and think you are useless. He seems to be affected by it and worried by it. He should rely on it less and look to the larger game," Mr Salmond told reporters.

His upbeat mood rests on taking a party which had three Westminster MPs and 14% of the vote when he succeeded Gordon Wilson in 1990 to 22% and six MPs in 1997 - followed by 29% and 35 MSPs elected in Edinburgh last year. "A pretty good legacy to hand over," he said.

"It's a matter of pride. If the SNP had been doing badly I would not have stood down," added Mr Salmond who refused to back either of the contestants for his post, fellow MP John Swinney and the more radical MSP Alex Neil.

But the thrust of his remarks came close to endorsing Mr Swinney whose gradualist approach is closer to his own. He noted that those who thought the Scottish parliament had done well and those who were disappointed both believe it should have greater powers.

He concluded: "Devolution has whetted the appetite for more powers and done so earlier than I would have expected".

The MP for Banff and Buchan since 1987 argued that "independence was a process not an event" and that he had made the SNP "a social democratic party in the European mainstream" with broad national appeal - one which Asian Scots, businessmen and even ex-Labour trade unionists could feel comfortable with.

"I think Scotland will become independent before the [1707] Treaty of Union celebrates its 300th anniversary. The SNP has a very good chance of winning the next [Scottish] elections [in 2003] and, if we win, of winning the referendum shortly afterwards," he predicted.

webTitle: Sykes hearkens to Imperial's echoes

fields.headline: Sykes hearkens to Imperial's echoes
fields.standfirst: College prepares for pill-monger
fields.trailText: Any sleepy dons lurking in dusty library corners at Imperial College, London, are in for a rude awakening. Sir Richard Sykes is about to descend upon them, fresh from ruling Britain's largest drugs company with a rod of iron.
fields.body:
Any sleepy dons lurking in dusty library corners at Imperial College, London, are in for a rude awakening. Sir Richard Sykes is about to descend upon them, fresh from ruling Britain's largest drugs company with a rod of iron.

Sir Richard is unlikely to be in a good mood when he arrives at Imperial in January. He will be digesting the loss of his £1.2m salary as executive chairman of Glaxo Wellcome and rubbing by on a £550,000 pension. He will also be adjusting to living full-time in Imperial's relatively modest accommodation, as the college statutes require, and to making his living room available for "regular academic functions".

It is tempting to assume that Sir Richard, 58, sees Imperial as a pleasant way of winding down to retirement. Nothing could be further from the truth. He has big plans for Imperial, which he wants to build into a commercial, business-leading institution.

For years, Sir Richard and his rivals have complained that a lack of suitably trained scientists is the biggest obstacle to Britain retaining its leading position in pharmaceuticals. He is on a crusade to change that.

So what exactly will that involve? At the moment Sir Richard is being deliberately vague. He murmured vaguely yesterday about partnership agreements, sponsorship and contract research. He did note, however, that the college had a very large medical school. He feels medical research should take into account commercial realities - concentrating on treatments which could make money.

Imperial is already a progressive college, producing some of Britain's best science. However, Sir Richard's management style may come as a shock. At one point yesterday he was crystal clear. "There will be opposition," he said. "But I'm used to dealing with that."

Oh no, not BT

There is a case for arguing that British Telecommunications plc should change its name. If nothing else, this might lessen the sense in the wider business world that the company is becoming a national embarrassment.

After yesterday's half-time figures showing profits down by a quarter, the shares, at 865p, were quite stable - but only because the City was braced for a bigger fall.

Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, is still struggling to convince anyone that he has a clear strategy, whether it be a substantial break-up of the group or a merger with another big international player.

Then again, there may be method in this outward muddle. It is widely believed that BT had extensive negotiations last year on a merger with Telefonica. It could be that, with the Spanish phone company's swashbuckling boss, Juan Villalonga, having now departed, the talks are set to resume.

Built-in comfort

You can hardly get further away from the hi-tech wizardry of the internet than concrete, cement and aggregates. But alongside a rather dull set of interim figures from Hanson yesterday came news that it is linking up with sometime rival RMC and continental competitors Lafarge of France and Heidelberger Zement of Germany to set up a new online marketplace. They see customers ranging from big construction groups to local builders getting quotations and placing orders via their planned online business-to-business marketplace. Details are due in October.

Coming together to run the site, these heavyweight rivals say, spreads the costs and the risks and will lead to lower transaction prices. But they insist they will still retain their freedom to compete against each other, with the partners offering competing products through the site.

However news of the new venture looks like another business-to-business exchange which is going to register on Mario Monti's competition radar screen at the European commission.

EC officials have already indicated they are concerned that these new internet services might have anti-competitive implications, with an inquiry threatened into the aircraft parts exchange, MyAircraft.com. US regulators are also looking at a similar partnership bringing several motor industry groups together in cyberspace.

The fear is that the groups running these sites will end up aligning their prices in comfortable cartels. Such practices have been hard to prove in the past and have usually involved dawn raids on company offices to gather quantities of documents to sift through.

But business-to-business sites will at least provide the authorities with an easy way to keep tabs on price movements by the big operators, provided they have access to the sites. Alternatively, every time Mr Monti plugs in his user name and password, the site operators will be able to monitor him.

webTitle: Boy camped with cult as hunt went on

fields.headline: Boy camped with cult as hunt went on
fields.standfirst: Teenager found: Group of three 'holidaymakers' kept low profile on busy site as searching police closed in
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago a man strolled into the reception centre of a busy campsite near Farnborough in Hampshire and booked a two night stay, signing himself into the visitors' book as Reinhard Zeuner from Erlangen in Germany.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, Sarah Hall and Stephen Bates
fields.body:
Two weeks ago a man strolled into the reception centre of a busy campsite near Farnborough in Hampshire and booked a two night stay, signing himself into the visitors' book as Reinhard Zeuner from Erlangen in Germany.

That day, Friday July 14, Bobby Kelly's face was on the front of the Express newspaper under the headline "Cult kidnap boy aged 16." He was in other newspapers too, and the cult members with him read the reports with alarm.

Their fear was that Bobby would be "deprogrammed" - forcibly made to give up the religious beliefs he had acquired since he left his grandmother's home in Romford to travel with them a month earlier.

So Zeuner and another cult member, Andrew Eagles, took Bobby to the campsite, where they kept a low profile, renewing their stay every few days.

Vanessa Sands, a hostel warden from Bristol who camped alongside, said: "To me they didn't look like lads who'd gone away camping together. They weren't like normal lads, they weren't drinking or having a laugh. They'd just sit hunched over their Primus stove, looking around, being quiet and serious."

Bobby was accompanied to a phone box where he recorded an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme. In this interview, barred from broadcast for 10 days after his family obtained an injunction, the boy admitted missing his family but denied he was being held against his will.

In the campsite at Mytchett, on the Surrey-Hampshire border, they maintained a facade of normal holidaymaking, with Zeuner enquiring about local attractions and expressing an interest in the nearby Royal Army Medical Corps museum.

But the search for the boy was intensifying, with an appeal by a high court judge, Mr Justice Munby, for Bobby to come forward and for the public to help with any information on his whereabouts.

On Tuesday, the day of the judge's appeal, Detective Constable Shaun Reardon of the Metropolitan police kidnap and special investigations unit rang the campsite and asked if a Mr Zeuner had booked in.

Visitors' services manager Susie Porter took the call. "You've just missed him," she said. Five hours earlier the group had packed up their two domed tents and headed into the woods behind the field.

Here, in a clearing in the woods at Ash Ranges, Bobby was found and the two men were arrested by plainclothes detectives at 10.30am yesterday.

On the Jesus Christians' website, the group declared that "we recognised something like this was almost inevitable".

The website reiterates their fear of "deprogramming". It states: "We regard Bobby Kelly as an adolescent... not fully adult, not fully child... 16-year-old children all over Britain do things that their parents and guardians do not agree with, but the police are not called in, a nationwide manhunt is not mounted... and certainly the whole country is not banned from hearing their side."

Founded by David McKay in 1981 and at one time - maybe still - consisting of no more than his family, friends and dropouts picked up on the group's travels, the Jesus Christians preach a fundamentalist version of Christianity, insisting that salvation can be obtained only by reverting to the precepts of the Bible.

The insistence on returning to a wandering lifestyle, not dependent on money, has not prevented the group carrying out a series of stunts with a shrewd eye to publicity, such as superglueing Australian dollar bills to pavements to illustrate the illusory nature of cash and dressing up as babies outside more orthodox religious gatherings to demonstrate the need to be childlike to accept God's message.

webTitle: Letters: Israel and Palestine

fields.headline: Building a new Jerusalem
fields.trailText: In light of the collapse of the Camp David summit (Crowds out for Arafat, daggers out for Barak, July 27), reportedly triggered by the inability to agree a permanent solution on Jerusalem - it may be in order to refer back to basics. The constitutive document of the state of Israel, as well as the state of Palestine, is UN resolution 181 of November 1947, recommending the partition of British Mandate Palestine into two democratic bi-national states, one with "Arab" trappings and one with "Jewish" (read "Hebrew") trappings, joined by an economic union, with Jerusalem neither the capital of the "Jewish state" nor the "Arab state", but under international administration.
fields.body:
In light of the collapse of the Camp David summit (Crowds out for Arafat, daggers out for Barak, July 27), reportedly triggered by the inability to agree a permanent solution on Jerusalem - it may be in order to refer back to basics. The constitutive document of the state of Israel, as well as the state of Palestine, is UN resolution 181 of November 1947, recommending the partition of British Mandate Palestine into two democratic bi-national states, one with "Arab" trappings and one with "Jewish" (read "Hebrew") trappings, joined by an economic union, with Jerusalem neither the capital of the "Jewish state" nor the "Arab state", but under international administration.

Israeli claims for sovereignty over Jerusalem represent a violation of 181 and all subsequent UN resolutions on the question of Jerusalem. Palestinian claims are also a violation of the resolution and are inconsistent with the long-established position of the Palestine National Council, of which the PLO is the executive arm, demanding a solution of the conflict within the framework of all relevant UN resolutions. By and large the international community, in its wisdom, has never recognised Jerusalem as the capital of Israel (almost all embassies are in Tel Aviv).

Rather than attempt to broker a settlement for the question of Jerusalem that is illegal, the US would be better advised to seek the support of the international community for an international administration for Jerusalem.
Dr Uri Davis
University of Exeter

 The solution is to internationalise the whole of Greater Jerusalem, with Palestine and Israel using Jerusalem as their capital. If the international Christian movement wishes to establish a base within Jerusalem, it should be welcome to do so.
Dr James Andrews
Shepperton, Middx

 The solution is a new Jerusalem. Scots-Irish Presbyterians, fleeing from English Test Acts to freethinking American colonies, took control of the Revolution, via eight generals and five co-signatories of the Declaration of Independence, and blocked High Church Boston and Quaker Philadelphia from being the capital. Their device of a neutral capital (Washington) wrung from seven years of bitter, often violent debate, side-stepped ethnic differences and avoided religious control. It has been copied with success all over the former colonies of European powers, with the visible exceptions of Israel-Palestine, Lebanon, Cyprus, Kashmir, Indonesia and nearer home, Ireland.
Paddy McGarvey
Irish Parliament Trust

 You ask (Leader, July 26) what lessons can be learned to relaunch the peace talks. President Arafat should not be castigated for insisting on basic rights backed by international law and UN resolutions. Unless these are insisted upon, the international community may continue to back an unequal negotiating process. A nuclear regional power such as Israel, fully supported by a non-neutral US, can hardly be compared with the fledgling Palestinian authority. Israel has attempted peace by coercion, in the guise of diplomacy. If Arafat had caved in to the pressure, a people with little to lose would not have forgiven him and any peace would have been both temporary and an illusion.

The European Union must step into the vacuum created by the US presidential elections and insist on a two-state solution, with a viable and sovereign Palestinian state in the entirety of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, with Jerusalem, a shared capital for two peoples.
John Austin MP
Council for the Advancement of Arab-British Understanding

webTitle: Peugeot car workers stage 'lifestyle' strike

fields.headline: Peugeot car workers stage 'lifestyle' strike
fields.trailText: A one-day strike over plans to cut the working week to continental levels and increase overtime pay yesterday halted production at Peugeot's Ryton plant near Coventry - prompting a flurry of talks to head off an all-out dispute that would cost the French car group £6.5m a day.
fields.body:
A one-day strike over plans to cut the working week to continental levels and increase overtime pay yesterday halted production at Peugeot's Ryton plant near Coventry - prompting a flurry of talks to head off an all-out dispute that would cost the French car group £6.5m a day.

Two shifts among 2,500 workers staged the 24-hour stoppage, with the third shift due to walk out on Sunday, after a ballot produced a 50.6% to 49.4% majority (of just 31 people) for an indefinite stoppage to begin on August 21 after a three-week factory shut-down. Turnout was 89%.

Negotiations resume on Monday but company executives and union leaders held emergency talks to avert a dispute seen by industry insiders as crazy and "unbelievable given the parlous state of the UK car industry."

Professor Garel Rhys, motor industry expert at Cardiff university's business school, labelled the strike and the threatened all-out action one of Britain's first industrial disputes over "lifestyle" rather than the traditional row over pay after the workers went on strike over enforced Friday night working.

Union sources said the dispute centred on Peugeot's plan for a compulsory shift one Friday night in three, and to increase the weekend shift from 29 to 36.75 hours, taking in a Monday morning.

The car group had made a series of concessions after an earlier ballot, on a smaller turnout, produced a majority for strike action over its plans to cut the working week from 39 to 36.75 hours (including breaks) to bring Ryton into line with French plants.

But a second ballot still endorsed the strikes even though union leaders had approved a package that included a 17% pay increase for the Friday night shift, plus a flat-rate extra £6 to bring total payment to nearly £100, and limited overtime paid at 1.5 times the basic rate.

"They seem hell-bent on a strike," one union official said, pointing to the continuing uncertainty at the nearby Longbridge plant of Rover, the planned closure of Ford's Dagenham plant and the threat to take the new Nissan Micra from Sunderland to France as reasons against action.

Peugeot rejected Prof Rhys' claim that it had failed to communicate the rationale behind the new work patterns, saying it had held a series of focus groups and "stopped the track" to explain the importance of them.

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
£10m 'thank you' for hospital

Staff at Cromer & District hospital in Norfolk have been stunned by a £10m "thank you" bequest from the sister of a former patient. The gift from Sagle Bernstein, who died in May aged 82, is said to be an acknowledgement of the care her sister Muriel Thoms received before dying at the hospital two years ago.

Jailed farmer can appeal

Norfolk farmer Tony Martin has won the right to appeal against his murder conviction for shooting dead a teenage burglar, his solicitor said yesterday.

Road accident figures fall

The number of people killed or seriously injured in road accidents last year in metropolitan areas was half that in the early 1980s, according to government figures.

Irving to appeal in libel case

David Irving, the historian who lost a libel action in April against an American academic who accused him of denying the Holocaust, has filed papers for an appeal against the verdict and the order that he should pay £150,000 costs to Penguin Books.

No charges over stabbing

Postmaster Richard Watkins will not face charges for fatally stabbing an armed raider during a raid on his post office in Wolverley, Worcestershire, it emerged yesterday.

webTitle: TV shows panned for third world coverage

fields.headline: TV shows panned for third world coverage
fields.trailText: A study of television coverage of the poorest nations, which cost the government £168,000, criticises Blue Peter, Newsround and the Holiday show for their "inadequate" coverage of development issues.
fields.body:
A study of television coverage of the poorest nations, which cost the government £168,000, criticises Blue Peter, Newsround and the Holiday show for their "inadequate" coverage of development issues.

Clare Short, international development secretary, ordered the study, which took 18 months, in a project to raise awareness of the developing world, but the Conservatives dismissed the 185-page report as an "absurd gimmick".

To produce the report, Viewing the World, researchers looked at coverage of developing countries in the main news programmes on the five terrestrial channels, as well as children's shows such as Blue Peter and Newsround; the holiday shows Holiday and Wish You Were Here; comedy programmes including Comic Relief and Mark Thomas Comedy Product; and cookery shows such as Ready Steady Cook and Ainsley's Big Cook Out.

Among the "key findings" were that "the agenda of most mainstream holiday shows... was dominated by an emphasis on bargain hunting", with little information about the "ethics of tourism".

Blue Peter was criticised despite its huge fundraising efforts for third world causes. The show's New Future for Mozambique appeal, in which viewers were asked to send in empty aluminium cans to help fund a new school, drew the comment: "The programme was strong on the issue of collecting but offered less in terms of understanding the nature of the country or its people."

While Newsround gave the "most positive and well-explained coverage" of third world issues, it portrayed Africa "as a place of poverty, disease and destitution".

The study, carried out by the Glasgow Media Group, was paid for out of the development awareness fund. It found that cookery programmes were "an important source of images of the developing world". News coverage, however, was "generally limited to disasters, bizarre events or visits by prominent westerners", causing viewers to perceive countries "in a negative way".

Gary Streeter, shadow international development secretary, said: "It's amazing that taxpayers' money has been spent on a report which contains the startling revelation that holiday programmes concentrate on holidays...

"Ms Short must explain how watching Ready Steady Cook is assisting her in constructing useful development aid policies. She is in danger of undermining support for aid programmes by wasting money on things like this."

Ms Short, who will address the Edinburgh television festival on the report next month, said: "There is interest in coverage of the developing world, but it's got to be done better. We need a serious debate about this."

webTitle: Afghan warrior goes to ground in suburbia

fields.headline: Afghan warrior goes to ground in suburbia
fields.standfirst: Police and Home Office launch inquiry after alleged war lord accused of murder and atrocities in the early 1990s is found in south London
fields.trailText: A notorious war lord accused of murder and torture when he controlled a vital trade route in Afghanistan has surfaced in a suburb of south London.
fields.body:
A notorious war lord accused of murder and torture when he controlled a vital trade route in Afghanistan has surfaced in a suburb of south London.

Police and Home Office officials have launched an investigation into Commander Zardad, who is living in a rented house in Mitcham under an assumed name, after a report on BBC2's Newsnight on Wednesday.

Zardad, who allegedly committed a string of atrocities in the early 1990s while his troops patrolled a key road into Kabul, confirmed his identity but denied the crimes of which he is accused.

He could face extradition or even be tried in Britain under the law that formed part of the case against the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.

Zardad is said to have controlled road blocks at Sarobi, 37 miles from Kabul. He allegedly used his powerful position to stop at gunpoint almost every vehicle that passed and to steal, rob, terrorise and murder.

One witness on the programme told how a bus packed with civilians was hijacked. "Zardad was there with approximately 10 of his men, and he stopped the bus and pulled off the women and the children." The bus was shot at, "filled with holes with 10 or 11 men inside it, unarmed".

Another witness claimed that Zardad ordered his troops to kill a group of Pakistani tourists who had driven a Datsun car past his base. "They threw them in the river. They took the car. All this was done just for the Datsun car. They were all shot dead with a Kalashnikov. They were shot dead just for the car and their watches."

Another witness spoke of one of Zardad's sidekicks, a "half-savage man" known as the human dog who lived in a hole and "attacked prisoners and those who could not pay bribes. He bit them all over their bodies and sometimes killed them".

Zardad is said to have been one of the fiercest commanders under Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, who led rebel attacks on Kabul after the Soviet Union pulled its troops out of Afghanistan in 1989.

Hekmatyar came to power in 1996, and Zardad was said to be upset that he was not given a place in the cabinet. He was censured by the government when he allegedly hijacked three German and French aid vehicles carrying money and supplies into Kabul and was ousted from his Sarobi base.

The BBC tracked him down to the Mitcham house after a tip-off from the ruling Taliban militia in Afghanistan.

When confronted Zardad said: "We never harassed anyone, and we never killed anyone. I was not the commander at Sarobi. I was a commander at Kabul. I was just an adviser at Sarobi.

"I came here to England because we have lots of trouble because the Taliban are trying to kill me and make trouble. I am not doing anything in England; I am just living my life."

It has been suggested that his alleged crimes netted him enough wealth to allow him to flee to Britain about a year ago, and he is thought to be seeking asylum. Yesterday he had disappeared from the £140,000 two-bedroom house, and a housemaid said he would not be back until next week.

Neighbours described Zardad as a slim, tall, harmless looking man who tended to keep his head bowed when he walked to the shops to pick up his groceries.

One said: "He seemed so quiet and inoffensive. It's unbelievable that someone accused of such things should be living here in this nice area."

Official inquiry

Yesterday the Home Office was making checks on Zardad and the Metropolitan police special operations unit was looking into the case. Amnesty International investigators were ploughing through their files for more information on him.

The Afghan embassy said it had known that Zardad was in London, which has a 20,000-strong Afghan community, but had not made any attempts to have him extradited. How the British authorities dealt with him was "not our business", said the spokesman, who also dismissed Zardad's claims that he had not been the commander at Sarobi.

The case has some similarities with that of Tharcisse Muvunyi, a suspected Rwandan war criminal who is to be tried in Africa for alleged genocide and human rights abuses. He was arrested earlier this year after setting up home in Lewisham, south-east London.

Though there is no extradition treaty between Afghanistan and Britain. Zardad could be extradited if there was solid evidence against him. However, it is unlikely that he would be sent back, as he could argue convincingly that he could not get a fair trial in Afghanistan.

It is possible that he could be tried here in Britain for torture under a clause of the 1988 Criminal Justice Act which formed part of the Pinochet case. The 1988 act enshrines in British law a 1984 international treaty forbidding torture.

Ann Clwyd, Labour MP for Cynon Valley, who chairs the parliamentary human rights group, said: "I think there is cause for concern. There is a public interest in seeing people accused of war crimes being brought to justice."

webTitle: Punch faces contempt action

fields.headline: Punch faces contempt action
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Punch, the magazine owned by Mohamed Al Fayed, is to be prosecuted for contempt of court after publishing an article by David Shayler, the former MI5 agent, about the IRA bombing campaign in the City of London in the 1990s.
fields.body:
Punch, the magazine owned by Mohamed Al Fayed, is to be prosecuted for contempt of court after publishing an article by David Shayler, the former MI5 agent, about the IRA bombing campaign in the City of London in the 1990s.

A spokesman for Lord Williams, the attorney general, confirmed yesterday that the magazine was being served with a writ for an article this week on the Bishopsgate bomb in 1993 under the headline: "MI5 could have stopped the bomb going off."

The magazine had breached a court injunction obtained by the government in 1997 after Mr Shayler made his first allegations about MI5, the spokesman said.

The cover of the latest issue of Punch, published on Wednesday, is dominated by a letter from Sean Martin, a treasury solicitor, saying that his "clients" - a reference to MI5 - believe the Shayler article breached the injunction and damaged national security.

James Steen, editor of Punch, said some cuts were made before the article was passed by the magazine's lawyers.

Mr Shayler is a regular contributor to Punch and he has referred previously in print to the circumstances surrounding the Bishopsgate bombing.

Profits, excluding one-off items, rose to $1.33bn (£877m), or 46 cents a share from $865m, or 31 cents a share, a year ago.

 Contest Telecoms operators in Ireland will compete for 3G mobile licences by a beauty contest system rather than auctions, the Irish Times reported yesterday.

webTitle: Misys stock surges as recovery kicks in

fields.headline: Misys stock surges as recovery kicks in
fields.trailText: Shares in Britain's leading software companies rose sharply yesterday after Misys, the software combine run by Kevin Lomax, signalled that business is finally recovering after the sharp slowdown suffered in the wake of the Y2K debacle.
fields.body:
Shares in Britain's leading software companies rose sharply yesterday after Misys, the software combine run by Kevin Lomax, signalled that business is finally recovering after the sharp slowdown suffered in the wake of the Y2K debacle.

Although Misys cautioned that it was too early to predict exactly when trading would return to normal levels in its key banking software division, its generally positive stance enabled the shares to overcome slightly weaker than expected results, and advance 9% to 660p. Fellow software companies saw their shares climb sharply in sympathy.

"It is too early to confirm that the disruption of Y2K is totally behind us - and the true picture is unlikely to emerge until later this year - but we are very confident that we will progressively return to the group's long-term growth rates of 20%," said Mr Lomax.

Misys last year became one of the first business software firms to warn that the high level of orders experienced at the start of last year as banks coped with the introduction of the euro would fall later as IT managers stopped investing in new software and concentrated on preventing potential millennium bug problems.

Mr Lomax said demand for banking software had picked up noticeably since March and by May orders were touching record levels. In the year to May 31 Misys booked pre-tax profits of £123m, down £3m on the previous year and marginally below most analyst expectations. A strong performance from healthcare and insurance offset the slowdown in banking to increase revenues from £671m to £709m.

webTitle: At this price? TeleWork

fields.headline: At this price? TeleWork
fields.trailText: Life is looking up for Ian Lenegan, who styles himself as "a simple northern guy" but is worth £130m following the successful flotation of TeleWork, his business software company.
fields.body:
Life is looking up for Ian Lenegan, who styles himself as "a simple northern guy" but is worth £130m following the successful flotation of TeleWork, his business software company.

TeleWork has attracted a price tag of £262m after a placing of shares in the business was more than seven times oversubscribed.

The business specialises in communications software, providing portable personal phone numbers, advanced voice message systems and tracking employees who spend their time on the road.

A former mathematician, Mr Lenegan co-founded the company after running a business selling garages and porches. He recognised a need for decent software to co-ordinate a business, with staff working odd hours often away from the office.

The market reckons TeleWork has great potential, given the rapid trend in business towards flexible time-keeping and to employees working from home. Among its products is a system which allows employees to clock in by dialling a phone number and pressing a particular key - useful, for example, for train operators who need to ensure their drivers are in the right place at the right time.

Other TeleWork systems include a product which turns voice messages into emails, and software which helps manage rotas and schedules for personnel departments. The company has just received an order to supply £208,500 of hardware to BT Cellnet, a relationship which could prove much more lucrative in the long term.

TeleWork has a good track record - it has made profits every year since 1986, with an average growth rate of 49% annually for the last five years. The flotation has raised £17.2m, which will be used to fund acquisitions in similar types of software and to repay debt of £2.7m incurred in a recent purchase. Going public also means that staff can be given share options.

Broker Kleinwort Benson has priced the shares at 145p, and trading starts on August 3. The price represents a multiple of 60 times next year's expected earnings - which sounds steep, but is not too bad for a software firm.

TeleWorks seems a good way to buy into the race towards the virtual office. Mr Lenegan is so confident of prospects that he is buying a new car he wants to trade in his Jag for something a little more up-market.

fields.headline: Cash point
fields.trailText: The Danish referendum campaign is not being run from Conservative central office (Report, July 24). It is a cross-party initiative to raise money from people of all political views who respect the determination of the Danes to maintain their currency - and their democracy - in the September 28 referendum. The Yes campaign, supported by multinationals, outguns financially the Nos by roughly 10 to one. Most of our donations have come in sums of £20 or less.

Lord Shore

webTitle: Digital figures hurt Telewest

fields.headline: Digital figures hurt Telewest
fields.trailText: When will it stop? Shares in cable company Telewest have now fallen for five consecutive sessions in heavy volume, and the broking community chatter is that a full-scale rerating of the company's prospects is taking place.
fields.body:
When will it stop? Shares in cable company Telewest have now fallen for five consecutive sessions in heavy volume, and the broking community chatter is that a full-scale rerating of the company's prospects is taking place.

Last night the shares closed at 179p, down a further 14p, after another session of brisk trading (31m shares changed hands). A week ago the shares were at 258p.

The trigger for the slide was of course the announcement last Friday that marketing of its digital TV service, a key weapon in the battle against arch rival BSkyB, has been suspended owing to a shortage of set-top boxes.

The delay in the rollout of Telewest's digital services could not have come at a worse time for Telewest. On Wednesday, BSkyB outlined the yawning gap between itself and the cable companies in the deployment of digital TV services. Some 80% of Sky's subscribers have turned digital and the company is targeting 7m by the end of 2003.

According to City dealers, who have so far been spectacularly unsuccessful in predicting where the stock will bottom out, Friday's news prompted an institution to liquidate its holding.

While Telewest's biggest shareholders (Microsoft and MediaOne) appear to be in for the long term, dealers are not so sure about Mercury Asset Management (6.67%), Goldman Sachs (7.69%) and Janus Capital (4.83%).

They insist that one is quite clearly selling and hint that investment bank Morgan Stanley has been selected to do the business, in a style politely described as "aggressive". Morgan Stanley will not comment.

Leading shares generally turned in another poor performance. The FTSE 100 retreated from an early rise of 60 points to settle 35 points lower at 6,352.1 points. As usual heavyweight telecom stocks called the shots. Vodafone AirTouch (down 12.5p to 291.5p) alone took 34 points off the index, as it went into reverse fol lowing a profit warning from Finnish company Nokia. British Telecom , which saw early gains, also closed lower (off 3p at 865p) as did telecoms equipment provider Marconi (58p easier at £10.30).

On the upside, engineering stocks were enjoying a renaissance. The trigger was blow-out interim figures from industrial materials group Cookson (29.5p stronger to 243), which caused broker Merrill Lynch to upgrade its rating to "buy" and increase its full year earnings forecast by 25%.

In the wake of the figures, takeover favourite Weir Group jumped 10.5p to 200p, Glynwed put on 13.75p to 213.75p and FKI advanced 12.5p to 240p.

But the real interest was in the performance of another materials group, Bodycote . Although the stock closed only 0.5p better at 187p, this was someway off the session low (179p) and turnover was strong at 3m after a sizeable sell order was completed.

On a price/earnings ratio of just 8, dealers reckon that the company, which posted pre-tax profits of £85.2m, looks vulnerable to an approach.

Contested bids have been thin on the ground lately but one looks to brewing in the Midlands.

Early in the morning session Hill & Smith (1.5p easier at 55p) issued a statement saying that it was in talks with Ash & Lacy (22p stronger at 168.5p) which could lead to an offer "at or around the current share price".

Just a few hours later rival Metnor Engineering (13p higher at 220.5p) revealed that it too had held talks with Ash & Lacy, but added that any offer it might make would be at a "significant premium".

Elsewhere, Granada Compass made a sold debut, rising 19.6p to 804.5 and dealers were bracing themselves for the return of Mike Edelson's shell company, Chelford . It is expected to come back to market today after a reverse takeover by SSI.

webTitle: AVRC on the move

fields.headline: AVRC on the move
fields.trailText: Recently launched Advance Value Realisation Company (unchanged at 100.5p) is causing a stir in the small cap world.
fields.body:
Recently launched Advance Value Realisation Company (unchanged at 100.5p) is causing a stir in the small cap world.

It has obtained sizeable stakes in about a dozen out-of-favour old economy stocks. The latest is Energy Technique (down 0.75p at 5.25p) where it yesterday appeared on the share register with a 20.48% stake. Other holdings include Havelock Europa, Kenwood Appliances and Darby Group.

But dealers warn not to get carried away with the appearance of AVRC on a register. One of its main roles is to offer institutions an exit from unwanted holdings in small companies. In return the institutions were offered units in AVRC at its recent placing.

That said, the track record of founder Duncan Duckett is sound. He was behind vulture fund Advance UK.

For now, the appearance of AVRC on a share register should encourage investors to sit tight.

webTitle: Letters: Northern Ireland

fields.headline: I have never incited terrorism
fields.trailText: Martin Gregory's prime objective (Unsavoury loyalist, July 27) appears to be promoting the republishing (by Virgin) of his book Dirty Tricks, which was discredited by successful libel action by my friend and colleague Brian Basham, a PR consultant to British Airways during my term of office. This resulted in Mr Gregory's book being withdrawn.
fields.body:
Martin Gregory's prime objective (Unsavoury loyalist, July 27) appears to be promoting the republishing (by Virgin) of his book Dirty Tricks, which was discredited by successful libel action by my friend and colleague Brian Basham, a PR consultant to British Airways during my term of office. This resulted in Mr Gregory's book being withdrawn.

Mr Gregory knows little or nothing about Northern Ireland, which is proved by the mistakes he makes in attacking my role. In 1975 I was not dismissed as a part-time private in the Ulster Defence Regiment. I have never written for the Ulster Defender. I have never incited terrorism.

I resigned and received an honourable discharge from the UDR and later received a Service Medal Northern Ireland for the duties I had carried out.

At that time I was with Bill Craig, David Trimble and colleagues in the Vanguard Unionist Party, trying to work towards peace in the Constitutional Convention and at night protecting life and property on duty with B Company 10th Battalion UDR in Belfast.

I did my job in British Airways defending the company in the battle with Mr Branson. It was tough and competitive. I never did anything illegal and we had every right in defending the interests of our company. A mythology has grown up about the dirty tricks saga which has more to do with Mr Gregory's propagandist role than reality.

As a PR practitioner, I and my companies have, as do hundreds of bankers, brokers and solicitors throughout the City, represented good and successful companies, companies with problems, personalities who have gone through personal and financial difficulties; that is the job.

I was a director of the European newspaper, then owned by Robert Maxwell. If that sort of association is damning, then it damns just about half the journalists in Fleet Street and most of the present Labour government, who knew him well. Mr Gregory and the Guardian appear to have their own Irish republican agenda for Northern Ireland. I have mine in the Ulster Unionist party and that is to create a long-term and stable peace in the province, which I have tried to do in my work for Unionism for the last 30 years.

David WB Burnside
London

webTitle: Letters: Burmese atrocities

fields.headline: Military back in the dock
fields.trailText: I was pleased to see the Guardian's coverage of the plight of the Karen people who are facing genocide at the hands of the Burmese military (The generals, G2, July 27).
fields.body:
I was pleased to see the Guardian's coverage of the plight of the Karen people who are facing genocide at the hands of the Burmese military (The generals, G2, July 27).

The late Bruce Humphrey-Taylor, a constituent of mine, first brought the atrocities to my attention. Your readers cannot imagine the appalling photographs I have seen of people maimed and tortured by the Burmese regime. I have also seen written testimony that I believe justifies my use of the word genocide.

Ethnic minority and democracy leaders have called for an end to foreign investment in Burma and it is time Premier Oil put human lives above profits and pulled out of the country. Premier's excuse that they want constructive engagement with the Burmese has been proven wrong. Since the beginning of Premier's so-called constructive engagement, atrocities against the Karen and other minorities have escalated.

My colleague, the foreign minister John Battle, has been particularly robust in his criticism of Premier and has always welcomed visits I have arranged from representatives of the Burmese ethnic minorities.

Your role in this campaign is welcome on two fronts. First, it helps raise public awareness about the Burmese regime, one that I regard as among the worst in the world. Second, I hope it will shame Premier into withdrawing from Burma until democracy is restored.

Andrew Miller MP

 Congratulations to the Guardian and to Maggie O'Kane for her excellent articles exposing the genocide against the Karen people in Burma. Jubilee Campaign has been lobbying the UN to set up a tribunal to try Burma's military regime for genocide. We are also investigating the possibility that Premier may be guilty of complicity in this genocide.

When we talk about the Burmese military junta we are not just referring to an undemocratic regime but a criminal one that has committed heinous crimes under international law and should be prosecuted.

Wilfred Wong
Jubilee Campaign

webTitle: Bulger killers may be freed by 2003

fields.headline: Bulger killers may be freed by 2003
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are likely to spend no more than 10 years in custody and could be free by 2003, the lord chief justice hinted yesterday as he revealed for the first time that judges used a starting point of 14 years in deciding how long a lifer should serve.
fields.body:
The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are likely to spend no more than 10 years in custody and could be free by 2003, the lord chief justice hinted yesterday as he revealed for the first time that judges used a starting point of 14 years in deciding how long a lifer should serve.

Lord Woolf has not yet determined the "tariff" for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, but said he would begin with the standard starting point of 14 years, with reductions for mitigating factors such as their age at the time of the crime and increases for aggravating factors.

Life rarely means life, except for the most sadistic killings such as the Moors murders. But many will be surprised to learn there is a 14 year kick-off point, and a list - not meant to be exhaustive - of 11 factors justifying a longer tariff, and eight indicating a shorter one.

The guidance was set out in a letter to judges from Lord Bingham, Lord Woolf's predecessor, in 1996, but has never been made public before.

Aggravating factors include multiple killings, terrorist or politically motivated killings, revenge killing, or evidence of sadism, gratuitous violence, or sexual maltreatment, humiliation or degradation.

Mitigating factors include mercy killing, which would justify an unusually short tariff, lack of premeditation, age or mental subnormality.

Thompson and Venables were 10 in 1993 when they abducted and killed James Bulger, just over the age of criminal responsibility, justifying a substantial deduction, perhaps to half. Evidence of remorse or contrition, exhibited by the two, would also merit a lesser sentence.

But the term would be increased by aggravating factors, including the fact that the victim was a child and evidence of gratuitous violence before the killing. The balancing exercise would probably produce a tariff of around 10 years, the term originally recommended by the former lord chief justice, Lord Taylor, after the trial judge proposed eight years.

The then home secretary, Michael Howard, increased the tariff to 15 years, more than many adult murderers serve. His decision triggered a series of legal challenges which ended in a ruling last December by the European court of human rights that judges, not politicians, must set tariffs for young murderers detained at her majesty's pleasure.
