webTitle: Leader: Doing business with Burma

fields.headline: Eyes wide shut
fields.standfirst: Scruples fade in dealings with Burma
fields.trailText: What do Dick Cheney, Slobodan Milosevic and the British company Premier Oil have in common? Answer: they all firmly believe in doing business with Burma, home to perhaps the world's most oppressive regime.
fields.body:
What do Dick Cheney, Slobodan Milosevic and the British company Premier Oil have in common? Answer: they all firmly believe in doing business with Burma, home to perhaps the world's most oppressive regime.

For Mr Cheney, who was picked this week as George W Bush's Republican running-mate and is thus quite possibly the next US vice-president, the appalling human rights record of the Rangoon military junta presents no bar to trade. As chief executive of Dallas-based Halliburton Co, the world's largest oilfield services company, he backed a lobbying group, USA Engage, opposed to the current US investment sanctions on Burma.

As a board member of another pressure group, the pro-business National Foreign Trade Council, Mr Cheney's company also recently helped persuade the supreme court to overturn a Massachusetts state law which imposed penalties on companies trading with Burma. Gulf war veteran Cheney fervently believes in making the world a safer place for America's oil industry.

Mr Milosevic's top priority is a safer world for Slobodan Milosevic. The isolated Yugoslav president and indicted war criminal will talk to almost anybody these days; hence, in recent months, closer ties with Libya and Iraq, like Serbia the target of sanctions, and China. Earlier this month, he entertained Win Aung, Burma's foreign minister, in Belgrade. Mr Milosevic said they agreed that sanctions imposed on sovereign states were "a criminal form of behaviour [and] a massive violation of human rights".

Unsurprisingly, Mr Milosevic is not troubled by the well-documented misery of child slave workers in Burma, nor by the International Labour Organisation's formal accusation that the junta has committed "an international crime", possibly amounting to "a crime against humanity" in exploiting forced labour.

Nor, apparently, are Burma's hundreds of political prisoners, its thousands of arbitrary arrests and torture cases, and the tens of thousands of ethnic Karen and other tribespeople abused, killed or driven from their land by the Burmese army over-troubling to Premier Oil. Despite pleas to quit from the government, concern from shareholders, and the withdrawal of its erstwhile partner, Texaco, Premier persists with its multi-million pound Yetagun gas pipeline. The company conceded at its AGM last May that human rights and environmental abuses had been linked to the project and that the junta's record was "inexcusable". But it steadfastly refuses to get out.

Never mind the Foreign Office view that such ventures underpin the systematic repression in Burma since 1962 and undermine international efforts to effect peaceful change. Never mind that the Nobel prizewinner Aung San Suu Kyi, leader of the National League for Democracy, and her supporters still face brutal, daily intimidation 10 years after elections in which they won 82% of the vote. Forget about the junta's looting of the country, its criminal involvement in heroin production and trafficking (second only to Afghanistan), and the dire humanitarian and refugee problems resulting from its tyranny. And ignore the fact that bigger, better companies than Premier, like Pepsi-Co, Eastman Kodak, and Best Western, have pulled out.

All that, Premier and other companies with big Burmese operations like Unocal and TotalFinaElf seem to say, is not our business. It may sound sick to you. But it makes Dick and Slobodan proud.

webTitle: International stories in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Nine injured in German bridge blast

An explosion on a footbridge leading to at a railway station in Düsseldorf injured nine people yesterday, including a heavily pregnant woman who had to have a leg amputated at the scene.

The woman, in her 20s, was later reported to have lost her unborn child in hospital. She was said to be in a critical condition, along with a man who had serious injuries to the stomach.

As appeals were broadcast for blood donors, police said the explosion had been caused by a fragmentation device. They said it was unclear whether the device used was a grenade or a homemade bomb.

A police spokesman, Andre Hartwich, said there were no early indications that the attack was politically motivated. No warning had been given before the device went off.

The DPA news agency reported that most of the victims were foreigners. But it was unclear whether they were visitors from abroad or German residents of immigrant origin.

The station chosen for the attack is a particularly busy one, with a large number of connections to bus and tram lines. The device, loaded with shrapnel, went off at the start of the afternoon rush hour, as shoppers and the first commuters were hurrying home.

A reporter from the ZDF television network said blood was spattered all around the area. "The situation at the scene was terrible", said Suzanne Freitag. Scores of police descended on the area and a helicopter was used to ferry victims to hospital.

Yesterday's blast was the second of its kind this year. In May a man was arrested after a hand grenade exploded in a Hamburg discotheque, injuring nine people, in what was believed to be a revenge attack.
John Hooper, Berlin

France to extend law on abortion

The Socialist-led government in France confronted decades of resistance from the Catholic church yesterday by proposing to extend the country's legal abortion period from the first 10 to 12 weeks of pregnancy.

The reform, which would bring France more in line with most of its neighbours, would also remove the need for girls under 18 to get parental permission before seeking an abortion or buying the morning-after pill, and it would lift a ban on "pro-abortion propaganda".

The employment and health minister, Martine Aubry, said the 10-week deadline - in force since 1975 when France finally legalised abortion after years of bitter debate - meant that about 5,000 French women left the country each year to terminate their pregnancy abroad.

She said the reform bill would be put before parliament as soon as possible and should become law by the end of the year.

Some 220,000 abortions are performed annually in France. About 10,000 girls under 18 become pregnant each year, of whom about 6,000 have abortions. The bill will allow them to buy the morning-after pill without prescription, and to seek an abortion after consulting a doctor and a counsellor.

It will also permit French secondary school nurses to distribute the morning-after pill, overruling an earlier decision by the supreme court that a highly controversial free distribution scheme launched this year by a junior education minister was in breach of French law.
Jon Henley, Paris

Calabrian Mafia 'most dangerous'

The Calabrian Mafia has conquered the Italian cocaine market and emerged as probably the most dangerous crime organisation in Europe, according to a report published yesterday by Italy's parliamentary anti-Mafia commission.

"The 'Ndrangheta [Calabrian Mafia] is a phenomenon that has been under- estimated," said Giuseppe Lumia, the president of the commission. "The cocaine trade allows people to amass huge resources and the 'Ndrangheta now has enormous capital."

Mr Lumia's 170-page report says that the organisation has achieved a dominant position in the Italian crime world without attracting public notice, and has been much less vulnerable to supergrasses than the Cosa Nostra in Sicily.

"Certain 'directors' of the 'Ndrangheta from a small village in the province of Reggio Calabria were providing lessons, guidance, one could say consultancies for Cosa Nostra in Catania, for the Camorra in Naples, for the Sacra Corona Unita in Puglia and for the Colombian Mafias," Mr Lumia said.

"From that small town they exercised a kind of strategic hegemony over the cocaine trade."

The organisation now has vigorous tentacles abroad, particularly in north America, Australia, Germany and France, Mr Lumia said. Ransoms obtained by Calabrian kidnap gangs have now been reinvested in cannabis plantations in Australia, according to the report.

Moving discreetly from the impoverished toe of Italy to the wealthy plains of Lombardy, the 'Ndrangheta has succeeded in ousting its better known Sicilian cousins from control of illegal activities in the economic heartland of northern Italy, Mr Lumia's report says. It adds that, of 37 major anti-Mafia operations mounted by police in the Milan area in recent years, 24 were directed against the 'Ndrangheta.

"The 'Ndrangheta has formed alliances with all the other criminal organisations - Italian, and more recently foreign, in particular those of Albanian and Kosovan origin - to manage enormous drug deals by constantly opening new purchasing channels and seeking new partners," the report says.

The organisation has also become extremely sophisticated in the deployment of its financial resources, securing the complicity of employees in a number of Italian and foreign banks, it says.

One of the group's specialities, according to the investigation, has been the cloning of bearer bonds. Members of the syndicate gained access to the email system of Deutsche Bank in Milan to provide authentication for bogus bonds, it adds.
Philip Willan, Rome

25 killed in Nepal plane crash

Rescuers recovered the bodies of all 25 people killed when a plane crashed just minutes before it was supposed to land in western Nepal yesterday, police said.

The bodies of the 22 passengers and three crew members, all Nepalese, were found in the wreckage of the Royal Nepal Airlines plane, which came down near Jogbudha, a village 450 miles west of the capital, Katmandu.

The Twin Otter plane, which was on a 25-minute flight, crashed in bad weather and rain after hitting pine trees and erupting into flames. Villagers rushed to the scene and tried to put out the fire. The crash site is at an altitude of 1,280 metres (4,200ft).

"Radio contact with the plane was lost just two minutes before it was scheduled to land," said the civil aviation minister, Tarini Dutta Chataut.
AP, Katmandu

Trough art installed in Reichstag

A controversial piece of art that parodies the massive nationalistic inscription above the Reichstag's entrance has been installed in the restored parliament.

The piece by the New York-based German-born artist, Hans Haacke, is a seven-metre-wide by 21-metre-long wooden trough, inscribed with "To the population". It is intended to be a more inclusive slogan than the Reichstag's "To the German people".

Parliament members opposed to the piece failed to block its installation in an April vote. They had criticised it for trying to ascribe a negative meaning to the original inscription that has adorned the Berlin landmark since 1916.

To complete the piece after its installation in an atrium of the Reichstag, MPs have been asked to bring bags of soil from their homes to fill the trough. At the beginning of July, they were each sent two bags to fill with soil, and some have said that they intend to fulfil the request.

But no dirt has yet arrived at the Reichstag and MPs opposed to the work have sent back the empty bags.
AP, Berlin

webTitle: Ex-English Heritage chief bailed out king

fields.headline: Ex-English Heritage chief bailed out king
fields.trailText: Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former head of English Heritage, was accused yesterday by David Rendel, Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury and a member of the Commons public accounts committee, of running an "old pals network" after it was revealed that he had bailed out his friend King Constantine of Greece by paying his £5,000 donation for using Kenwood House in London for a society wedding.
fields.body:
Sir Jocelyn Stevens, the former head of English Heritage, was accused yesterday by David Rendel, Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury and a member of the Commons public accounts committee, of running an "old pals network" after it was revealed that he had bailed out his friend King Constantine of Greece by paying his £5,000 donation for using Kenwood House in London for a society wedding.

The disclosure contradicts evidence given to MPs by Pam Alexander, chief executive of English Heritage, who told the Commons committee last month that the donation had been paid by the former king for his daughter's wedding.

Sir Jocelyn wrote the cheque only two days before the quango faced questioning from the committee on its stewardship of the historic buildings and sites held by the nation.

The paper submitted by English Heritage to parliament revealed that accountants at the quango had originally envisaged a possible £25,000 donation from the former king - and had spent the past six months trying to get him to hand it over.

Only the worry of having to produce annual accounts and the fear that MPs on the Commons public accounts committee might discover that no donation had been made led to the last minute action by Sir Jocelyn, it was admitted in the report.

The wedding last July, which attracted the obligatory publicity in Hello! magazine, united Princess Alexia, 34, and Carlos Morales Quintana, 28, a Spanish architect. It attracted two kings, seven queens, 26 princes, 33 princesses and a grand duchess. Among the guests were the Queen and the Prince of Wales. English Heritage admitted it had no idea nor did it ask whether the former king had a contract with Hello! magazine for a big fee for the wedding coverage - nor whether TV companies across Europe had to pay to cover the event.

The bill for the event was £34,089, of which £25,500 was paid more than three months later and the balance six months later. The event was organised by Lady Anson of Party Planners who initially said because the costs were so high there was no need for a donation. Later she wrote to English Heritage saying a £5,000 was "a most generous donation".

The paper revealed that on other events English Heritage had made a big profit for the public purse. The blockbuster film Notting Hill used the grounds of Kenwood House as a location and paid £22,254. The costs to Kenwood were around £4,000.

webTitle: Better care deal offered to elderly

fields.headline: Better care deal offered to elderly
fields.standfirst:
Ministers snub call for free care to pensioners in nursing homes

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The government promised a £1.4bn package to improve health and social services for the elderly, but rejected a key royal commission recommendation that would have extended free personal care to about 125,000 older people in residential nursing homes.
fields.body:
The government promised a £1.4bn package to improve health and social services for the elderly, but rejected a key royal commission recommendation that would have extended free personal care to about 125,000 older people in residential nursing homes.

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern, said this would cause "bitter disappointment" among all older people and "not solve the government's big problem with older voters".

Ministers said their programme was more generous than the £1.1bn envisaged in 1998 by the royal commission on long term care chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland.

It will include £900m a year for investment in "intermediate care" to help older people avoid hospitalisation or rehabilitate after treatment. This was not part of the royal commission's report and the cost was not included in its £1.1bn list of demands.

For the first time there will also be free NHS nursing care for all people in nursing homes, benefiting about 35,000 people at any one time and saving them up to £5,000 on the costs of staying in a nursing home. This will require legislation and will be implemented from October 2001.

But the government rejected the commission's proposal for free personal care, such as bathing, changing dressings and assistance with eating. These are free for older people in hospital, but are means-tested in residential homes.

"Making personal care free for everyone carries a very substantial cost, both now and in the future.

"It would consume most of the additional resources we plan to make available for older people through the NHS," the Department of Health said in its long-delayed response to the commission.

"We have not followed this recommendation because we believe our alternative proposals to improve standards of care and fair access to services will generate more important benefits of health and independence for all older people, now and in the future," the department said.

The NHS will meet the costs of the time spent by registered nurses on "providing, delegating or supervising care in any setting."

That is understood to include time spent by nurses on non-medical duties. This will mean that older people will not be charged if a nurse bathes or feeds them, but will have to pay if the same job is done by other staff.

Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners Convention, said the decision not to provide personal care free at the point of need would cause administrative chaos.

"It will be practically impossible and, quite frankly, cruel to differentiate between nursing and personal care in the way the government proposes. Residential and nursing homes will find themselves in the ridiculous position of having to start the meter running every time someone wants help to change their shoes or comb their hair."

webTitle: Prosecutors in Russia drop tycoon fraud case

fields.headline: Prosecutors in Russia drop tycoon fraud case
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Investigators have dropped fraud charges against Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, saying they have found no evidence of a crime, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Investigators have dropped fraud charges against Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, saying they have found no evidence of a crime, it emerged yesterday.

The sudden decision was the latest development in the extraordinary Media-Most affair. The case - particularly the imprisonment for three days of Mr Gusinsky and the armed police raid on his company headquarters - had prompted protests at home and abroad.

Commentators in Moscow suggested yesterday that prosecutors may have dropped the case after reaching a compromise with Mr Gusinsky - possibly even a commitment from the tycoon to soften the criticism of the Kremlin in the media outlets he controls. His newspapers and television channels have been critical of the president, Vladimir Putin, since he came to power. A spokesman for Media-Most denied that negotiations had taken place.

Last month Mr Gusinsky was charged with embezzling some $10m (£6.6m) of state funds during the takeover of a St Petersburg television company in 1997. He maintained that his arrest represented a heavy-handed attempt to intimidate him and to silence his media empire.

In a two-sentence letter sent to Mr Gusinsky late on Wednesday, the chief prosecutor on the case stated that charges had been dropped. Property belonging to the tycoon, including his country house outside Moscow confiscated by the state two weeks ago, was returned, and an injunction preventing him from leaving the country was lifted.

Sources at the prosecutor general's office said that investigations into the privatisation were continuing, but that the inquiries no longer concerned Mr Gusinsky directly.

On hearing the news, Mr Gusinsky left Moscow immediately to join his wife and three sons at his villa in Spain. A Media-Most spokesman, Dmitri Ostalsky, said the tycoon was "delighted" by the news. "It is too early to come to any conclusion about why the prosecutor decided to drop the charges now. We have always maintained that the accusation was absurd," he added. Experts in Moscow drew their own conclusions from the developments. Sergei Markov, of the Institute of Political Studies, interpreted the dropping of charges as a sign of the government's recognition that the original attack on Mr Gusinsky had been "crudely and badly" handled.

"I'm convinced that the Kremlin will continue to put pressure on Media-Most, only now they will go about it in a more intelligent fashion," he said.

The Kommersant newspaper reported yesterday that Mr Gusinsky had made a deal with the government, promising to soften criticism of the Kremlin broadcast by NTV, Russia's largest private television company, in exchange for having the charges dropped.

Sources told the newspaper - which is partly owned by Mr Gusinsky's arch rival Boris Berezovsky - that the Media-Most chief had been negotiating with representatives from the presidential administration all week, and had finally agreed to tone down the station's position "both in relation to the state and to President Putin personally".

Sergei Ryabov, a political analyst from the Carnegie Centre in Moscow, said he believed this interpretation was highly likely, and claimed that even yesterday's coverage of the news on NTV was noticeably more loyal in its tone, particularly in relation to the situation in the breakaway region of Chechnya.

But NTV's editor in chief, Vladimir Kulistikov, said he had not been asked to change the station's line. "We cover events that take place, and the position of the television company will not change in any way," he said.

Mr Gusinsky agreed to tone down coverage of the last war in Chechnya during the 1996 presidential campaign, when he joined a group of businessmen lobbying to secure Boris Yeltsin's re-election, to prevent a Communist revival.

webTitle: Oasis jeered off concert stage

fields.headline: Oasis jeered off concert stage
fields.standfirst: Swiss fans throw missiles after singer hurls insults
fields.trailText: They have fought with other bands and even each other, given the finger to the musical establishment, and told the press where to stuff it. But up until now the rock group Oasis have drawn the line at insulting their own fans.
fields.body:
They have fought with other bands and even each other, given the finger to the musical establishment, and told the press where to stuff it. But up until now the rock group Oasis have drawn the line at insulting their own fans.

The bad boys of Britpop crossed that final threshold on Wednesday night when the lead singer, Liam Gallagher, succeeded in antagonising thousands of the group's Swiss followers with some colourful insights of his own into their national characteristics.

They responded by pelting him and the band with bottles and cans. The band claim that Gallagher and drummer Alan White were hit though the organisers of the Paleo Festival insisted that only water bags and bits of rubbish were thrown. The concert in the French-speaking town of Nyon was later abandoned.

Last night the organisers, who were incensed at the band's behaviour, vowed they would never work with Oasis again and revealed there were even considering suing.

This is the latest disaster to have beset the Manchester group, which has hit the self-destruct button since taking a critical pasting for its latest album, Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants. It lost two of its original line-up last year after internal squabbles.

Last week Noel Gallagher, the group's principal songwriter and steadying influence, who had become semi-detached of late, admitted that if Liam "wasn't me brother I'd have kicked him out of the band years ago". The singer's behaviour, never predictable, has become still more erratic since his marriage to the actress Patsy Kensit collapsed last month. Crucially, Noel Gallagher was not on stage in Nyon.

Last night it was revealed that the band was so scared at what their fans might do to them that they rang the British consulate in Geneva to ensure their safe passage out of the country.

Oasis were headlining the one day festival, which included such diverse acts as the Buena Vista Social Club, Skirt and the band of the Yugoslav film director, Emir Kusturica.

Trouble started after the organisers claim Gallagher in sulted the 35,000 crowd. As objects flew towards him he walked off, and it was later announced that the band would only come back on if the crowd settled down.

After a brief break, they returned but two songs later - and after an exchange of insults between the stage and the crowd that centred on Gallagher's rival Robbie Williams - the band halted the gig.

In a statement last night Oasis blamed a small group of hooligans in the crowd. "The band had taken the stage to a roar of anticipation from the audience. Oasis have returned to Britain, where they are due to play in Edinburgh at the weekend.

But Daniel Rossellat, who runs the festival, blamed Liam Gallagher's "arrogant and provocative attitude" for stoking the trouble and lashed out at his "paranoid reaction" when the crowd reacted to his insults. "He insulted members of the audience on several occasions. As far as the Paleo Festival organisers are concerned, Oasis's decision to cut short their concert was totally irrational and the result of a paranoid reaction by the group, and not based on a calm analysis of the situation.

"By cutting short their concert in this way, Oasis not only ruined what was to be have been a much awaited musical performance for thousands of members of the audience, but also totally disregarded the public safety risk involved in depriving such a huge crowd of the band they had come to applaud."

Oasis were paid £66,000 - the largest sum received by any of the acts at the event. Mr Rossellat said he was trying to determine the exact wording of all of Gallagher's exchanges with the crowd.

webTitle: Acquittal ends student's date rape ordeal

fields.headline: Acquittal ends student's date rape ordeal
fields.trailText: A talented computer student who dropped out of university suffering from anxiety after being accused of raping a woman he met at a freshers' disco four years ago walked free from court yesterday when a jury rejected the charge against him.
fields.body:
A talented computer student who dropped out of university suffering from anxiety after being accused of raping a woman he met at a freshers' disco four years ago walked free from court yesterday when a jury rejected the charge against him.

Punching the air in celebration, Ashley Pittman, 22, said he felt as though his life was back on track after the nightmare he had lived through since the accusation was made.

According to the prosecution, the woman, then a biology undergraduate at the University of Wales, Aberystwyth, was so traumatised by the alleged attack that she waited more than two years to contact the police.

But a jury of seven women and five men took 45 minutes to reach a unanimous verdict clearing Pittman of the charge following a three day trial at Swansea crown court.

Pittman's mother, a former policewoman, said the case against her son should never have been brought.

Speaking outside the court, she said: "The cost to Ashley cannot be calculated and there is no avenue of compensation open to him. All our lives have been on hold. It is so unfair."

The woman, who graduated from Aberystwyth last year, told the court that she met Pittman at a freshers' disco in September 1996 during their first week at the university. She said they kissed and cuddled on the dance floor and that Pittman had raped her after walking her back to her room in halls of residence.

The jury was told that because of the period that elapsed between the alleged attack and the allegation being made there was no forensic evidence to support the woman's complaint.

Pittman, who was on a work placement in Ireland when the woman made her complaint against him two years later, maintained throughout the trial that the encounter had never gone further than kissing and cuddling in a communal kitchen area and that no sex took place. He told the jury that the woman, then aged 18, had given him a kiss on the cheek when he left and that he had never seen her again.

Pittman, from Warminster, Wiltshire, took up his place at Aberystwyth after gaining five A levels. He was one of the top students on his course and was chosen by his department as an "ambassador" when the computer company Digital invited a student to work at its European software centre in Galway, Ireland. He became part of the team working on a new generation computer being developed by the company.

Digital was so impressed with his work that it extended his placement and promised to sponsor his final year at university to tempt him back after he completed his studies.

But the rape allegation brought Pittman's academic progress to a halt. He told the court he should have graduated two weeks ago but had failed to complete the course because of the pressure he had been under.

He said that while he was still working in Ireland he had received a telephone call from Aberystwyth police indicating they wanted to talk to him about lost property. But when he walked into the police station he found himself charged with rape and facing the possibility of a jail sentence.

Following his acquittal yesterday Pittman said he intended to "celebrate like mad".

He said the pressure had been unbelievable. "This all happened four years ago. I never saw her again after that night and did not give her another thought. This whole thing has been a nightmare. I had the world at my feet and, within minutes of walking into that police station, I was looking at jail instead."

webTitle: Out of the Maze

fields.headline: Out of the Maze
fields.standfirst:
Today the last of Ulster's 428 political prisoners are released. The next challenge is adjusting to life on newly peaceful civvy street

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Just after 8am today, the rusting, rickety turnstile out of the Maze prison and into the visitors' car park will begin to clatter. It will fall silent only after midday, when the last of 76 men will leave jail to rejoin the world outside.
fields.body:
Just after 8am today, the rusting, rickety turnstile out of the Maze prison and into the visitors' car park will begin to clatter. It will fall silent only after midday, when the last of 76 men will leave jail to rejoin the world outside.

It is the culmination of the early release scheme of the Good Friday agreement, the two-year cut-off point at which all qualifying prisoners yet to benefit from the handsome increases in remission are free to go. Only 15 inmates will be left behind and the Maze, once home to 1,700, will close shortly.

Today marks the biggest one-day exodus from the Maze, 10 miles west of Belfast, and marks a fulcrum in the peace process. And it will be the most painful moment of all for victims' relatives as the atrocities involved are still so recent. The scheme has released 428 convicted terrorists ahead of schedule, 143 of whom were life-sentence prisoners. Those freed will include 192 loyalists and 226 republicans, such as Sean Kelly, 26, the IRA bomber who murdered nine with the Shankill Road bomb, and Torrens Knight, 30, Ulster Freedom Fighter and murderer of 11.

No one is sure exactly how many terrorists have served time. It is estimated to be between 25,000 and 30,000 during the past 30 years.

The Northern Ireland Office figures indicate little recidivism. Of 456 life-sentence prisoners released between 1983 and the start of the early release scheme, only one was recalled to jail. Only one prisoner freed under the agreement has had his licence revoked and been returned to custody for suspected terrorism. He was an IRA volunteer who served a five-year term before defecting to dissident republicans, and was held this year when police intercepted a car carrying explosives at Hillsborough, Co Down.

Ten more prisoners benefiting from the scheme, believed to be mostly loyalists, have since been charged, though none for terrorist offences - the charges include assault, drug-dealing, and driving offences and those held include three life-term prisoners.

Each prisoner leaving the Maze this morning will receive a £52.20 discharge payment, and some will qualify for a £100 clothing grant. Prisoners' groups have been in the Maze this month to ensure all will have filled out benefit forms and applications for housing. Employ- ment is the biggest single problem facing prisoners, and it worries Garnet Busby, 46, a former Ulster Volunteer Force member who now works for the Sandy Row Residents Group in south Belfast. He served 16 years of a life term for murdering an IRA member.

"Most prisoners will have no means at all to earn," Mr Busby says. "They are coming back into a much more affluent Northern Ireland, and they are going to be excluded from that. They will be bored, and some will be tempted to get involved in crime unless government takes some action to bind them in to the peace process."

Thomas Quigley, 44, jailed for the IRA attack on Chelsea Barracks in 1982, in which two were killed, was released last year after 16 years. He is now working with Tar Isteach, one of 20 republican prisoners' groups, the first of which was founded in 1995.

"Even now, prisoners are worried about their security when they come out," he says. "They are unhappy venturing close to interfaces. That cuts down on the jobs open to them, and it is not as if there is much choice in deprived areas like north Belfast."

Research in working-class republican areas suggests long-term unemployment for prisoners may be as high as nine in ten. It is likely to run around the same level within loyalist districts. Mike Ritchie, project director of Coiste na n-Iarchimi, an umbrella organisation for the republican groups, is campaigning for convictions to be wiped. (He hopes that the government may back that in a few years if political progress continues. Most employers demand details of criminal records, dismissing anyone later caught lying. All convictions above 30 months are never spent, and access to many public sector jobs is ruled out.)

According to Mr Ritchie, "Many ex-prisoners end up working on the black taxis, the favoured transport in west Belfast, or as security men on the doors of pubs and clubs. Some might get work as labourers or on building sites, but the black economy is very important. Many end up in the funded sector, mostly working as volunteers."

Prisoners' groups liaise with social services and the housing executive, and also offer retraining programmes. They are also becoming involved in counselling which was unthinkable when the Troubles were at their peak.

Former Ulster Defence Association member Billy McQuiston, 43, who spent more than 12 years at the Maze for offences including armed robbery, says: "The rate of marriage breakdown is high. Men who have married a quiet girl come out to find she rules the roost at home and they are the stranger. There is an enormous strain."

Prisoners' groups also aim to become involved in commercial activities; one republican group, in Derry, has branched out: it has opened a gym in the Creggan area.

European funding through peace and reconciliation schemes is running at £4m over five years to prisoners' groups on both sides; but there are doubts about its future. The groups say there is no government cash on top of that, and feel it is insufficient. Victims disagree. They say they get virtually nothing at all, often having to haggle hard even for their funeral expenses.

The families of the so-called disappeared - victims abducted and secretly murdered by the IRA - were enraged yesterday at news they would each receive compensation of £10,000. Nine families qualify. Willie Frazer, spokesman for Families Acting for Innocent Relatives, who has lost five family members, says: "We have people coming out of the Maze who were laughing when they were jailed last year for a total of 640 years. They knew they would be out soon.

"They will be feted as heroes and their own organisations will look after them. And what do the victims get - a cup of tea and a bun with Prince Charles? It is sickening and a new level of madness."

webTitle: Freedom for killer of 'terror' mum

fields.headline: Freedom for killer of 'terror' mum
fields.trailText: A teenager who killed his mother after years of torment walked free from a court yesterday after a judge ruled that he had been subjected to a "terrifying regime".
fields.body:
A teenager who killed his mother after years of torment walked free from a court yesterday after a judge ruled that he had been subjected to a "terrifying regime".

Robert Quilter, 17, stabbed his mother, Valerie, three times in the head with a kitchen knife before strangling her with his belt last September. He dumped her body in the garden shed at their home in Ossett, West Yorkshire, where it lay for almost three weeks.

Mr Justice Henriques, at Sheffield crown court, placed him on probation for three years, saying his mother had subjected him to a "terrifying ordeal and regime over a prolonged period".

The judge, who said the teenager had suffered "battered person's syndrome", lifted an order against his being identified, saying: "The defendant himself would be assisted by the public knowing and reading about the circumstances of this case."

Geoffrey Marson QC, prosecuting, said Quilter lived with his mother, 54. She had once been houseproud, but the deaths of her husband 10 years ago and her father in 1998 caused her to drink heavily, and her other three children, who had left home, said she became abusive and violent while drunk.

Her eldest daughter, Mandy, told police that her mother became "domineering and over-possessive" of Quilter and had twice threatened him with a knife.

Matters came to a head shortly after Quilter, then 16, received disappointing GCSE results at the end of August. He stabbed his mother and throttled her in his bedroom before hiding the body.

He told friends and relatives that his mother had gone on holiday, saying it was "cool" to have the house to himself.

The body was found 19 days later after worried relatives contacted the police.

Simon Lawler QC, defending, said Quilter was driven to his wits' end by his mother's "nigh on intolerable" behaviour. He said: "This quiet, inoffensive, immature boy was quite simply pushed to the limit of his endurance and he snapped."

webTitle: MI6 spy is jailed for 11 years

fields.headline: MI6 spy is jailed for 11 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A former Russian diplomat and author of espionage thrillers was found guilty of spying for MI6 yesterday and sentenced to 11 years in a top security prison for high treason.
fields.body:
A former Russian diplomat and author of espionage thrillers was found guilty of spying for MI6 yesterday and sentenced to 11 years in a top security prison for high treason.

The conviction closes a long and peculiar spy scandal which has deeply embarrassed the British intelligence service since Platon Obukhov's arrest in 1996.

The Moscow city court yesterday dismissed claims by Obukhov's lawyer that his client had been mentally unstable when he was recruited by British intelligence and remained too unwell to stand trial. After the hearing, Galina Krylova said she would appeal to the supreme court.

Obukhov, 30, the son of a former Soviet deputy foreign minister, was caught by the federal security service, FSB, the successor to the KGB, in April 1996 while allegedly in the act of broadcasting classified information "of a political and strategic defence" character to M16's headquarters in London. Britain has never denied the contact.

His arrest prompted the worst spy row between London and Moscow since the end of the cold war, with Britain and Russia each expelling four diplomats. Among them was the man named in the Russian press as Obukhov's controller, Norman MacSween, a counsellor in the British embassy in Moscow.

A senior FSB officer described the capture of Obukhov, a junior diplomat who had worked in Norway, as "one of the biggest blows to the world's oldest and most experienced intelligence services". But film of Obukhov confessing, shown on Russian television soon after the arrest, appeared to undermine this portrayal of him as a high-level agent.

Wearing a dunce's hat, odd socks and laceless shoes, he was shown grinning strangely, talking incoherently and rolling his eyes. He confessed to the crime, but added that he had made contact with M16 officials primarily to research his spy novels.

Before his imprisonment Obukhov had written 18 novels packed with sex and violence, bearing titles like The Sex Demon, and In the Embrace of the Spider.

His parents maintain that he has been mentally unwell since his childhood, suffering from schizophrenia. "I don't know why the British secret services recruited a sick person to work for them - they behaved like scoundrels," his mother Olga commented after an earlier hearing.

Russian officials argued that although the shock of the arrest made him temporarily unbalanced, Obukhov later simulated insanity in an attempt to mitigate his crime.

He showed no reaction yesterday to the judge's verdict. Since his arrest he has spent much of the time in prison psychiatric units. A doctor employed by the court to assess his mental state in April declared him sane.

His father, Alexei Obukhov, once an influential armament negotiator, told the Guardian last night that his son's conviction was "unjust and unfounded".

"We are talking about an extremely sick person. I was physically shaken when I saw how he looked in court today. His psychiatric condition is extremely poor," he said.

I was physically shaken when I saw how he looked in court today. His psychiatric condition is extremely poor," he said.

webTitle: ITN goes to court over news times

fields.headline: ITN goes to court over news times
fields.trailText: The protracted row over News at Ten is to be settled in court after ITV announced yesterday it is challenging an order to move its late night news programme to an earlier time.
fields.body:
The protracted row over News at Ten is to be settled in court after ITV announced yesterday it is challenging an order to move its late night news programme to an earlier time.

Executives from the commercial broadcaster decided unanimously to seek a judicial review of the Independent Television Commission's directive, issued last week.

They are furious at being forced into moving the 11pm Nightly News; the regulator, however, is alarmed at the 13% drop in viewers for ITV's news programmes since News at Ten was axed last year to make way for more films and adult drama. The shake-up, in which ITV's main evening bulletin moved to 6.30pm, angered politicians, including Tony Blair.

The court case will throw the commission's powers into the spotlight at a crucial time for the future of broadcasting - the government is considering whether to merge the existing regulators and watchdogs, including the BBC governors, into a single structure.

Both sides insist privately they are confident of their legal position. The commission has never lost a judicial review, but ITV's legal advisers maintain that the regulator has no power to dictate the time of its news programmes.

ITV's announcement means the commission's directive, also published yesterday, will almost certainly be set aside.

The regulator had ordered ITV to move its Nightly News to an earlier time from December 4. The broadcaster had to decide on the new time by August 18, but it is unlikely that a judicial review, if the application to the high court in London is accepted, would be heard before the early autumn.

ITV revealed its hand in a statement released yesterday afternoon.

The commission refused to comment on the move.

webTitle: Lords bill will ratify world court

fields.headline: Lords bill will ratify world court
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office moved yesterday to redeem its pledge to back an international criminal court.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office moved yesterday to redeem its pledge to back an international criminal court.

It announced that a draft bill will be published next month ratifying the internationally agreed treaty setting up the court in principle. The court is intended to become a permanent UN backed body to handle war crimes and genocide allegations.

The Foreign Office bill will be introduced in the House of Lords early in the new parliament.

The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, said yesterday: "We want to be one of the first countries to ratify the treaty as part of our commitment to human rights."

The aim is to get the court established by 2002. The Rome Statute setting it up was agreed in July 1998 and Britain signed the statute in November 1998.

At least 60 countries have agreed to ratify the treaty before the court comes into being. So far 98 countries have signed the statute, but only 14 countries have ratified the treaty.

The court could, in theory, prosecute serious breaches of international law wherever they might occur.

webTitle: Lima in fear of bloodshed as Fujimori takes office

fields.headline: Lima in fear of bloodshed as Fujimori takes office
fields.trailText: Up to 40,000 riot police are on standby to handle opposition protests planned for today's swearing-in of Peru's president for a controversial third term.
fields.body:
Up to 40,000 riot police are on standby to handle opposition protests planned for today's swearing-in of Peru's president for a controversial third term.

The opposition is hoping to get as many as 300,000 demonstrators out for what will be the third day of protests this week. Organisers said that tens of thousands of people were converging on the capital yesterday from around the country.

But with a strong police presence and fears of bloodshed - a concern shared by Amnesty International - news agency reports said that as of yesterday, many Lima residents seemed to be staying home.

The election victory that won Mr Fujimori his third five-year term was tainted by irregularities. It became a one-horse race when the opposition challenger, Alejandro Toledo, withdrew after doing well in the first round, claiming unfairness.

In a bid to improve his democratic credentials, Mr Fujimori on Wednesday named as his prime minister an opposition moderate, Frederico Salas, mayor of one of Peru's poorest provincial capitals and a former presidential candidate.

"We want our government to show more consensus," Mr Fujimori said. "Salas's presence proves what we have always shown: openness to people who are not members of the governing party."

But outside the presidential palace - ringed by hundreds of riot police - unionists and students protesting against the man they call "the dictator" were not convinced that the cabinet change would alter things, according to reports from the scene.

"Salas is a pawn used by Fujimori to make his election look legitimate," said Daniel, 40, a clerk, who was waving a banner supporting Mr Toledo.

Mr Toledo has been saying that a quarter of a million people will gather outside congress in Lima today when Mr Fujimori takes office, perhaps a third of these demonstrators brought in from the jungle, Andean highlands and Pacific coast in buses, open trucks and boats.

Even though Mr Fujimori has said today's demonstration would be allowed to "go ahead without incidents", there were several reports that the authorities were stopping people arriving in Lima.

The air force has declared a no-fly zone above the city, prohibiting reporters and international monitors from observing the protests in helicopters.

Mr Toledo said: "Hundreds upon hundreds of people are being detained in various parts of the country. We are practically under a state of siege."

But the Organisation of American States is putting some pressure on him for democratic reform, as is Washington. Only two countries - Ecuador and Bolivia - are sending presidents to today's ceremony.

Mr Fujimori's party won only 53 out of 120 seats in the April general election. But this week he was assured of a majority after a rush of last minute defections.

He has denied charges that bribes, intimidation and the threat of tax investigations were used to regain legislative control.

webTitle: Work in progress: Mad 4 Real, peformance artists

fields.headline: Work in progress: Mad 4 Real, peformance artists
fields.trailText: We've been very busy recently. Well we've been very busy with our art activities for the last 20 years, and we have a number of new projects in planning.
fields.body:
We've been very busy recently. Well we've been very busy with our art activities for the last 20 years, and we have a number of new projects in planning. Some are very much in the beginning stages - for example, we've heard there's a new Chinese restaurant opening in Camden soon, called New Cultural Revolution, and we want to do something about the ridiculousness of naming a restaurant after one of the main political events of the last century. We're thinking about what to do next at the Tate Modern - we were banned from there because we pissed on Marcel Duchamps' Urinal, so we're dying to go back again. In fact we've taken the ban as an open invitation for more action. And we're being filmed by Channel 4 for a programme about our lives; it's coming out in September.

We've also been commissioned to do a work for the Arts Council - probably some sort of boat structure. And we're sorting out the photos from our recent swim across the Thames because we want to do an exhibition. The idea behind our Thames swim was something very dear to us. We wrote words like "capitalism" on each other's bodies in paint, then swam in order to symbolically wash away capitalism. It was based on Chairman Mao's swim across the River Yangtze in 1966. Mao did the swim because he wanted to prove he was physically fit and mentally ready for cultural revolution. His was a great act; sadly our swim was cut short by a police boat who'd been tipped off.

Everything we do is inspired by our idea that contemporary art should be more experimental, take more risks, and shouldn't necessarily be in a gallery space. We like using the big open spaces you find in London and showing to a large public; we ignore the big commercial institutions like the Saatchi - they're dull, they have big bad art, they're getting worse. We feel in a different way to those Britart people. They're operating in a circle: we can make money, open restaurants. We think there's a need to carry on challenging the mood. In the end our art's for people; it's for everybody.

webTitle: Cheney dug the grave for star wars but didn't bury it

fields.headline: Cheney dug the grave for star wars but didn't bury it
fields.standfirst:
Bush's running-mate is a hawk who believes in military solutions
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Whether or not he emerges this autumn only a heartbeat away from the American presidency, Dick Cheney will always be remembered for one withering phrase.
fields.body:
Whether or not he emerges this autumn only a heartbeat away from the American presidency, Dick Cheney will always be remembered for one withering phrase.

The man who has just been picked as George W Bush's running mate was the grave-digger of Ronald Reagan's star wars project. He announced in March 1989 that he did not hold with the view that it would provide a complete shield capable of blocking all incoming missiles. The Reagan administration, he said with masterly understatement, "oversold the concept".

Cheney was the newly appointed defence secretary and his remarks were a powerful signal that the incoming administration led by George Bush senior, George W's father, was not going to continue with Reagan's pet project. Hundreds of critics in the American scientific community, as well as ministers in European Nato governments, already shared the Cheney assessment, but to have it come so directly from the top man in the Pentagon was damning.

As the cold war fades in people's memories and is replaced by a new set of myths, it is as well to be reminded of the Cheney decision, not just for its content but also its timing. A piece of historical nonsense has become increasingly popular as an explanation of Mikhail Gorbachev's ground-breaking reforms in Russia.

According to this complacent triumphalism, it was Ronald Reagan's decision in 1983 to up the ante in the superpower arms race by taking war-making technology into space which undermined the Soviet Union. Mikhail Gorbachev realised his country could not match America's military spending without massive economic reform. Faced with the cowboy-actor and the space gun, he and his colleagues cried uncle.

In a speech on star wars (known as the Strategic Defence Initiative) to an admiring audience in the United States, Margaret Thatcher later clothed this fantasy with her typically forceful simplicity: "I firmly believe it was the determination to embark upon the SDI programme and to continue with it that eventually convinced the Soviet Union that they could never, never, never achieve their aim by military might because they would never succeed. I believe this led to an assessment of the poverty of their own system and to require them to admit it produced neither power nor dignity and therefore led to the enormous changes in east-west relations we are seeing."

A pity about the dates. Cheney's denunciation of star wars came several months before the fall of the Berlin Wall and when Moscow was still only tinkering with economic reform. Nor were Cheney's remarks the first blow to star wars. The notion of using a colossally expensive forest of space-based mirrors and lasers to shoot down Soviet missiles had already taken a knock in the dying months of Reagan's second term in the White House.

The congressional office of technology assessment concluded in June 1988 that at its best the star wars interceptors would not hit more than 16% of incoming Soviet warheads. A sceptical Congress had long been chipping away at SDI funding and in October 1988 Cheney's predecessor as defence secretary cut star wars back by roughly half.

Far from being panicked, Gorbachev enjoyed the bureaucratic civil war in Washington in which the star wars maximalists lost out. The Soviet leader contributed to their defeat by repeatedly saying Moscow would not bother to join an arms race in space, and it was the American economy which would lose out. "I think you're wasting your money. I don't think it will work. But if that's what you want to do, go ahead," he told Reagan at the Washington summit in December 1987.

But that's the end of the good news. Star wars was not completely scrapped. It was Cheney who, recognising its impotence against a heavily armed nuclear power, launched the argument that a smaller version could be of value against lesser states. The Bush administration was to call them rogue states, though in recent months Clinton's people have diplomatically renamed them "nations of concern".

After delivering his barbed rejection of space-based missile defences against the Soviet Union, Cheney went on in his 1989 speech to say "they will become more important in the future because the possibility exists that you will have other nations with ballistic missiles, nuclear weapons, or chemical warfare capabilities that could be used against the United States". Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and the Gulf war, in which Cheney was to play a major role, were still more than a year away. Here was Cheney already anticipating a nuclear shield against third world states.

The charitable explanation might be that Cheney could not destroy star wars in one go, given the attraction to the hi-tech community of any new scientific option plus the huge subsidies which the arms industry would enjoy. So he could only reduce it and invent a new rationale.

Sadly, there is a grimmer version. Cheney's whole career shows he was always an advocate of American global interventionism, with a propensity to exaggerate both the threats America faces and its need for military rather than political means to deal with them. As a congressman in the 1980s, he backed US funding and military help for the contra rebels in Nicaragua, Jonas Savimbi in Angola, and the mojahedin in Afghanistan. In the Pentagon under George Bush senior, he master-minded the US invasion of Panama. Months before Clinton turned it into the linchpin of its European strategy, Cheney was calling for Nato's expansion into eastern Europe. So George W's choice of Cheney for vice-president is not a reassuring sign that he wants an experienced infighter who understands how the White House has to handle powerful congressional committees. It is proof that Bush's instincts on foreign policy are ultra-hawkish.

As the father of the scaled-down version of star wars which is currently known as the National Missile Defence, Cheney is not going to find it emotionally easy to renounce it. The best hope is that as a man who must by now understand the growing desire of European governments not to be taken for granted by their American super-ally he will control his unilateralist reflexes.

The current defence secretary, William Cohen, is at least moving in that direction. He said this week that Washington must take account of European views on NMD because the system could not work without European states' radars. Britain and Denmark are the key countries, and the Cohen statement in effect gives them a veto over this damaging project. They should use it, since NMD is no different from Stars Wars. It too has been dangerously "oversold".

webTitle: Private lives

fields.headline: My husband wants to tell our children about his affair. What can I do?
fields.trailText: I have been with my husband for 23 years and we have three teenage children. Ten years ago I wanted to break up as I was very unhappy, but my husband would not agree to it.
fields.body:
I have been with my husband for 23 years and we have three teenage children. Ten years ago I wanted to break up as I was very unhappy, but my husband would not agree to it.

He now has a relationship with a woman with children of her own and who is known (and liked) by me and by our children. I have no problem with this. The difficulty is that he hates having to tell lies when he visits her and plans to tell our children about her. He is determined to pursue this course.

I would welcome ideas about how I can help the children handle their responses when the time comes. This man has always been a good father and I believe that the children need loving relationships with both of us. Might it be that his honesty is the best path?

Stop living in denial

Your correspondent is concerned about deceiving her children about the relationship between her husband and another woman. It seems to me that she and her husband have been grossly deceiving their children for the past 10 years and it is this that will cause more difficulties than the extra-marital relationship.

If they had been open about the fact that their marriage was a purely practical arrangement then the revelation that her husband was satisfying his need for love and affection with a different woman would be expected and understandable.

Instead the children are likely to feel betrayed when their family is revealed to them as something quite other from what they had been led to believe. They will need to build up trust in people and their own perceptions of reality again. But I would think that this is better faced sooner rather than later.

I suspect that your correspondent doesn't want her husband to tell the children because of the likelihood that it will expose her own feelings of self-denial which she must have buried in order for her to live life how her husband wanted her to and how she thought she should for the sake of her children.

She will need to relearn how to live life, doing what she wants to do for herself rather than what she thinks she ought to do.

I have been realising how daunting this is for myself over the last two and a half years after a lifetime of being a dutiful daughter, wife, mother and citizen.

When my husband of 23 years said he wanted to develop a relationship with another woman but didn't want to break up the family I asked him to leave as I was not prepared to provide "the services of love" while his love went elsewhere. I had been unhappy and unsatisfied for some years but felt I shouldn't end something I had committed to, so at first the break-up felt like an enormous relief.

But then I found myself weeping for no obvious reason. I became quite unable to make the decisions about what to do from the trivial "Do I want tea or coffee?" to the huge "What do I want for the rest of my life now all that I had been expecting has been destroyed?".

I don't think that I had ever before made a significant decision purely for myself and I have found it a difficult skill to begin to learn.

I have used a counsellor to help me, and I think I am now slowly beginning to be able to recognise and acknowledge my feelings and act on them. I am optimistic that I will gradually develop a life of my own choosing and be better for it.

As for my children, well, it must have been difficult at first for them but I am not aware that they have any serious problems. Their academic progress has not faltered, their social lives continue to develop, they seem happy in themselves. They all accept the situation between their father and me. They choose to see him quite often but use my house as their base. They really can't understand why I have any difficulty in knowing what I want for myself.
Hilary Chivall, Peterborough

Tell the truth

My parents separated over six years ago and although at the time it was difficult for myself and my four brothers and sisters, all under 16, I believe that they did the right thing.

The most important thing is for you to be happy, so tell the truth and ultimately your children will respect you, their father and your decision, as I do my parents.
Name and address withheld

Break free now

Your husband's wish to tell your children about his lover is at odds with his refusal to agree to the break-up of your marriage for the sake of the same children.

You must question his motives. I would guess that he is planning on leaving you for the other woman but wants to make sure that the children will take his side. He probably hopes to impress them with his "honesty" and "openness"; no doubt he will also tell them that it was your attitude towards the marriage which caused him to find someone else. In no time you will be the guilty party.

You say that your children, as well as you, know and like this woman, who also has children of her own. It could be that your husband hopes to form a big happy family with them all.

You have let him dictate the rules for far too long. His affair undermines your position and you should now take the initiative.

Your children are teenagers and familiar with separation and divorce, if only in theory. Tell them what is going on, emphasise the fact that you couldn't have tried harder to keep the family together but it didn't work out. Their parents still love them and always will.

Break free from your husband and give yourself the chance to start a new life. If your husband wanted you to stay with him he should not have started an affair. He has a new life now.

Act now, before you lose everything and end up being perceived as the "bad guy". Believe me. I've been there.
Anne Webb, London
Next week

I am in my mid 40s and have recently started dating again after my divorce. So far I have been out with four men and have been surprised to find that three of them were already in relationships. These men slept with the woman and went out socially but didn't consider that they had a partner. Although I was unaware of the situation when they asked me out they did not conceal this fact. In fact, one of them actually brought his friend on the date. When I expressed my surprise that he had a partner he said she was just a friend. He now has a relationship with a woman with children of her own and who is known (and liked) by me and by our children. I have no problem with this. The difficulty is that he hates having to tell lies when he visits her and plans to tell our children about her. He is determined to pursue this course. I would welcome ideas about how I can help the children handle their responses when the time comes. This man has always been a good father and I believe that the children need loving relationships with both of us. Might it be that his honesty is the best path? If they had been open about the fact that their marriage was a purely practical arrangement then the revelation that her husband was satisfying his need for love and affection with a different woman would be expected and understandable. webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: This is the day, 250 years ago, that Johann Sebastian Bach died of a cerebral haemorrhage at the age of 65.
fields.body:
This is the day, 250 years ago, that Johann Sebastian Bach died of a cerebral haemorrhage at the age of 65. He had just completed revising The Art Of Fugue, and was buried in an unmarked grave in Leipzig. At the BBC Proms 2000 (7.0pm, Radio 3) conductor Roger Norrington and an all-star cast mark the anniversary with Bach's last choral work, the Mass in B Minor - probably the one performed at his funeral. Classic FM In Concert (9.0pm) offers an alternative mixed bag of the composer's sacred and secular works.

A more mysterious anniversary is recalled by Sue Cook in Making History (3.0pm, Radio 4). On August 2 1100, William II was killed while hunting in the New Forest. Had it happened yesterday it might have been attributed to "friendly fire". But, even after 900 years, it's still unclear if the arrow which struck one of our least-loved monarchs was really an unlucky chance.

webTitle: How will Swen, the spoof news show, fare on early evening Channel 4?

fields.headline: Strange but true
fields.standfirst: It's probably best described as The Day Today on LSD - the sort of programme you'd normally find on at 3am. So how will Swen, the bizarre spoof news show, fare on early evening Channel 4?  Matt Lucas  investigates
fields.trailText: It's probably best described as The Day Today on LSD - the sort of programme you'd normally find on at 3am. So how will Swen, the bizarre spoof news show, fare on early evening Channel 4? Matt Lucas investigates
fields.body:
Rejoice! If you thought that Channel 4 was rapidly eschewing its alternative, experimental remit in favour of big ratings-grabbing money-makers like Big Brother, Something For The Weekend and Sex Uncovered (OK, I made the last one up) - then check out Swen, tonight's ALT-TV offering.

Swen is the sort of sometimes engaging, occasionally baffling, delightfully obscure programme that might usually be found nestling in the wee hours of the morning, between a repeated double bill of Chicago Hope and a video camera documentary where ugly people fruitlessly campaign for the unnecessary right to be naked in public.

And yet here it sits proudly in primetime, preceding Brookside and Friends. It's not about gardening, or redecorating, or cooking, or arrogant, cliquey flatmates with a spare room the size of a shoe intimidating potential tenants and then ditching the gay one, the fat one and the black one in favour of a chesty northern girl who they vainly hope will look nice and tidy up a bit.

Swen - try saying it backwards - is one of those curate's eggs, a hotchpotch of a show, hidden away in the early evening summer schedules like an episode of Minipops, circa 1983, harking back to the naïve, optimistic, low-budget halcyon days of "anything goes" Channel 4 television, categorisable only by its uncategorisability.

Described by its makers as "a subversive, experimental show in which eight radical video artists reinterpret the news", Swen is a refreshingly and suitably irreverent play on how news and news reviews are brought to us by television broadcasters. Not for Swen the po-faced, authoritative, kindly John Suchet or the sensitive but no-nonsense Natasha Kaplinsky. In the preview tape I saw, which may or may not bear too much resemblance to the finished product given the programme's topical agenda, the news items are topped and tailed by an ebullient, anarchic loon with a colourful tie and a glint in his eye, an overtly friendly, unashamedly silly figure. "In tonight's show," he says, "six video artists will be spinning and turning and mucking about with the international news. But beware - this is not a real bulletin." He's not wrong, you know.

As news - in fact, even as comment - the items themselves are certainly unconventional. The first piece, lasting only a few seconds, inspired by "new evidence of Russian human atrocities in Chechnya", leads our momentarily solemn presenter to ask "Will anyone take responsibility?", before confronting us with some fingernails scraping down a blackboard. Superimposed a number of times on the screen is the question "How many fathers, mothers, sisters, brothers?"

This "story" on Russian atrocities may be introduced with a straight face, but the newscaster adopts a joyously daft northern twang as he trails a segment on racism in sport, then an absurd Northern Ireland accent for a piece on the Troubles.

The item on racism in football - inspired by Stan Collymore's apparent refusal to join Leeds United because of concerns over the fans' alleged negative attitude towards black players - is an emotive montage of images depicting the stereotype of the white English supporter, from kids kicking the ball around on the park to drunken supporters in the street celebrating for the cameras. This footage is interspersed with film of Princes Charles, William and Harry on toboggans, Buddhist monks in prayer, buildings collapsing, Blair and ex-England manager Hoddle in tracksuits sharing a joke, a foxhunt and Prince Charles again, this time playing polo, alongside pictures detailing the downfalls of Collymore himself and - why not? - poor Paul Gascoigne. All this to the strains of Oasis's Let It Out. So... what's news? In this case it's up to you to decide. Or rather, interpret.

Similarly ambiguous, though a great deal more surreal, is the piece on Northern Ireland, which is simply a ten-second shot of a man trying (and failing) to get his red Mini started. This is perhaps more successful than the whimsical "exclusive and completely made-up health report" into "another organ scandal" - that of "stolen hearts", which unfortunately comes across like a rejected sketch from The Day Today, Brass Eye or that bastard offspring, The 11 O'Clock Show.

Most impressive - and possibly more indicative of the programme's likely direction, should it run to a series - is a more accessible but no less innovative item, to be seen in tonight's programme, from distinguished director Isaac (Young Soul Rebels) Julien. To the strains of the Dead Or Alive classic You Spin Me Round, it investigates the phenomena of the spin doctor. Alongside footage of the Millennium Dome, Tony and Cherie dancing and a tie-less, tweed-jacketed William Hague, we hear from an expert telling us that "the trouble with spin is it's too much appearance over too little substance."

Swen is a worthy addition to the schedules, providing a platform for experienced and novice film-makers alike. Like all compendium shows, it's a mixed bag. At its worst, it's indulgent and amateurish like only a bad student film can be. At its best, it's honest, thought-provoking and challenging television.

ALT-TV: Swen, Channel 4, tonight, 7.30pm

webTitle: For the love of veal

fields.headline: For the love of veal
fields.standfirst: It's pale, it's tender and foodies adore it. But until now the cruelty involved has been too much for most of us to stomach.  Lucy Atkins on a new British venture to produce veal that's humane, but tastes like the real thing
fields.trailText: It's pale, it's tender and foodies adore it. But until now the cruelty involved has been too much for most of us to stomach.  Lucy Atkins on a new British venture to produce veal that's humane, but tastes like the real thing
fields.body:
Few foods have raised as many hackles as veal. Even those who don't in principle mind eating doe-eyed baby animals might balk at tucking into one that has spent its short life in a crate, deprived of light, bedding and all food but milk, unable to move or lie down properly. And yet this, the purists argue, is the whole point of veal: the meat must be pale and tender. This, says Rowley Leigh of Kensington Place restaurant, involves "a kind of infanticide". To achieve the pale look and melting texture, young milk-fed calves must be reared for maximum weight gain in ways that avoid darkening the meat.

Of course, this welfare issue isn't new. Campaigners succeeded, 10 years ago, in getting veal crates - the individual cells in which calves are raised - banned in this country. So while Dutch animals still languish in dark solitude, British ones have to be housed with other calves where they can move around. And while French ones stand still wolfing processed milk and waiting to die, British ones can at least have a good lie down on a straw bed.

This is set to change - again for the better - because by 2006 veal crates must be phased out in all EU countries. But will this mean the end of veal cutlets as we know them?

Since veal crates were outlawed here, British veal has been pinker, tougher and fattier than its foreign crate-fed counterpart. As Leigh puts it: "The more exercise and more fresh air and more access to grass the animal gets, the faster the meat will develop muscles and therefore become tougher and darker."

This is why farmers - in Britain and the rest of Europe - are trying to come up with ways to produce uncrated, "welfare-raised" veal without sacrificing the tender whiteness of the meat. And it looks like progress is being made. This month an East Sussex farm exported its first 50 humanely reared veal calves - chopped up and vacuum packed - to Europe. It is the first step in a joint scheme run by the British company Anglo Dutch Meats and the French company Serval. If it works it could be good news for veal eaters and farmers alike.

Veal is, in some ways, a by-product of the dairy industry. To keep cows producing milk, they need to give birth once a year, having their calves removed when they are a day old. But since 1996 the beef ban has stopped the export of British calves to the continent, and farmers have had to dispose of - that is, slaughter - two million unwanted male calves every year. Even now that most aspects of the ban have been lifted, calves under six months old still can't be exported. But their meat can, as long as they've been slaughtered at more than six months old and the farmer can prove that their mother is alive and well. The French are big veal eaters, so there is a huge market for British veal exports, but the problem is quality. The idea behind this new veal scheme is to produce veal that is as good as crate-raised meat, without the cruelty.

Paul Ashworth, coordinator of the joint project, says the calves have been reared on a milk-only diet and housed loosely in groups of 30 with natural light and plenty of space. However, unlike other British veal calves, they are subject to a strict computerised feeding regime, developed and overseen by French technicians who pioneered the project in response to the forthcoming European ban on veal crates.

"The old-fashioned system," explains Ashworth, "lets the calves eat as much as they want whenever they want." But this means that some of the calves - the greedy ones - get fat while others languish, and because of this the quality of the meat can vary enormously, which makes exporting it difficult.

"With this new system each calf gets an individualised feeding regime," says Ashworth. This makes the meat more reliable. Each animal has a computer chip in its ear, and when it shows up for its milk the computer identifies it and adjusts the amount accordingly. So big greedy calf might find that his milk runs dry, while little shy one will get a bellyful. The result is "peas in a pod", as Ashworth puts it: "Our calves were all a similar size and weight."

But does it really taste like crate-raised veal? "No," says Kevin Pierce, beef and sheep adviser to the National Farmers' Union, "but the growing market in Europe today is not for crated meat. Everyone has to switch to the welfare-friendly system."

The hope is that this new veal will be excellent in its own right and raised humanely. Pierce claims that "the animals are very well looked after" and Joyce D'Silva, the director of Compassion in World Farming, is cautiously optimistic: "There has never been a more cruel trade than the export of live calves, so we're glad that animals at last are going out on the hook rather than on the hoof. We're hoping that meat from high-welfare British systems will set the standard throughout the EU for veal calf rearing in future."

Leigh points out that "there is no one thing called British veal - different people are producing different sorts of veal", but this very lack of uniformity may turn out to be a strength.

Different kinds of veal already have different followings. For instance, Marc Beaujeu, the buying manager for Personal Catering, eulogises a particular kind of French veal called veaux sous la mère . "This is," says Beaujeu, "a different way of raising the animals that is far more humane." The calf suckles from its mother in the field, fully at liberty until it is slaughtered. "The meat turns out more red than crate-raised veal," says Beaujeu, "but in my opinion it has a far better flavour."

The calf in this situation will probably eat a bit of grass, but will mainly feed on its mother's milk, and the quality of this milk will far outstrip anything it could get in powdered form. "It's like the difference between free-range and battery-raised chickens," says Beaujeu. "The result is far better."

You can get veaux sous la mère from most French butchers, though you'll pay more for it. And this is perhaps the central issue: if you want to mass-produce meat cheaply, you can't have your calves running around suckling from their mothers in open fields.

Still, where there's variety there's competition, and at least animal lovers can rejoice in the fact that, in 2006, veal crates will be a thing of the past in Europe. As for our veal-loving gourmets: well, your escalope de veaux might not be as pale as it once was, but with luck it will be just as interesting.
