webTitle: Obituary: Gerry Smale

fields.headline: Gerry Smale
fields.standfirst: Energetic apostle of the management of change
fields.trailText: When Gerry Smale, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, left York University with a sociology degree in 1966, he went to work for the Ford motor company as a management trainee. This was a time of serial strife between management and unions, and he was fascinated - and frustrated - by their failure to communicate.
fields.body:
When Gerry Smale, who has died of a heart attack aged 55, left York University with a sociology degree in 1966, he went to work for the Ford motor company as a management trainee. This was a time of serial strife between management and unions, and he was fascinated - and frustrated - by their failure to communicate.

One day, when Smale was running the No 2 foundry, there was an accident and, for safety reasons, he had to evacuate the building. As his men trooped into the nearest car park, he realised that all the other workers, from all the other foundries, were doing the same; they had assumed his men were staging a lightning strike and were walking out in sympathy. Smale quit.

By the time of his death, he had made himself an expert in the resolution of such conflicts. As director of development at the National Institute For Social Work, he combined a powerful, free-thinking intellect with a practical hands-on desire to make change.

As visiting professor at Goldsmith's College, London, and then at Southampton University, he travelled across Europe and America lecturing on his holistic vision of the management of change - refusing to allow staff to be segregated by departments, looking always at the connections between people, as the source of their problems and the seed bed of potential improvement.

He leaves a legacy of these ideas in numerous academic articles and a dozen books, from Prophecy, Behaviour And Change (1977) to Social Work And Social Problems (2000), co-authored with Graham Tuson and Daphne Statham.

Gerry was a big, bright, charming, cheerful man who attacked life with the same ceaseless energy that fuelled his work. As a teenager, he fell in love with traditional jazz, and was soon playing clarinet with a band in Southend - and using the case to blag his way into London clubs.

As a student at the new University of York, he wanted to play rugby and ended up helping to found a new club. He had a friend who went fly-fishing, so he learned himself. He loved piano and, in his cups, he played the blues. When his wife, Caroline, gave him a soprano saxophone a few years ago, he taught himself to play, and was planning to go public next month with his band, the Jazz Worriers. He adored Caroline and their three children with the passion of a natural father.

As an academic, Gerry was a late developer. He disliked school at St Pierre College, in Westcliff, Essex, and scored poor results. When he left the battlefield of Ford's in 1967, he worked as a probation officer in north-east London for three years before taking his first step towards academia, by studying social work at the University of Sussex.

Although he returned to the probation service in Middlesex for three years in 1972, he had found his strength and, in 1975, he went back to Sussex as a lecturer and research fellow, setting up a new social work course for mature students. Four years later, he moved to the National Institute, where he rose to become a professor in 1990 and director of development in 1991, a post he still held at the time of his death.

He was a great lateral thinker, but his trademark was an absolute determination to deliver practical change. The director of Hackney social services, where Gerry acted as consultant in the mid-1990s, used to call him "the parrot on my shoulder, always asking difficult questions."

Gerry's ability to convert his ideas into reality was brought tragically into focus five years ago when his 16-year-old son, Tim, died. Tim had inherited from his parents a real concern with his community and had talked about opening a new meeting place for young people in Lewes, east Sussex, where they lived.

After his death, Gerry and Caroline, together with a group of Tim's friends, set about creating the Nutty Wizard Cafe, named for a cartoon character invented by Tim. For two years, they ran monthly rock concerts to raise money and enthusiasm. They spent hours in meetings, slowly working their way through the bureaucracy, with Gerry an utterly unwavering leader. When they worried about motivating young people to join, Gerry knew the answer - because he had written the book.

This was a special man, both loved and admired, who created a life in the image of his own ideas.

 Gerald Gilbert Smale, professor of social work, community activist, born September 19 1944; died July 13 2000

fields.trailText: After the Festival of Britain, the Country Wife, the mural by Constance Howard (Obituary, July 20), was presented to Denman College, the residential college of the National Federation of Women's Institutes. The centre of the mural shows a village hall with WI members busy at a variety of crafts. The miniature pieces of craftwork depicted were made by WI members to her specifications. The appliqué figures wear underclothes, and it is recorded that "Miss Howard sacrificed several pairs of her nylon stockings for their legs".

webTitle: Obituary: Marc Reisner

fields.headline: Marc Reisner
fields.standfirst: The man who blew the whistle on America's western water scandal
fields.trailText: Water has always been more important than gold or silver in the history and development of the American west, but unlike the fever over precious metals it was difficult to understand or make interesting. Marc Reisner, who has died of cancer at the age of 51, changed all that.
fields.body:
Water has always been more important than gold or silver in the history and development of the American west, but unlike the fever over precious metals it was difficult to understand or make interesting. Marc Reisner, who has died of cancer at the age of 51, changed all that.

His 1986 book, Cadillac Desert: The American West And Its Disappearing Water, did a similar job for its subject to that of Rachel Carson's seminal work on pesticides, Silent Spring (1962). Both changed the law but, more importantly, they brought the issue of a threatened environment into political prominence. Reisner's book was ranked by the Modern Library as 61st on a list of the 100 most notable English-language books of the 20th century.

As a television documentary series, often beautiful as well as revelatory, it was screened in America in 1997, and was shown abroad, including in Britain. Its black and white photographs of the men who built the massive Hoover dam, on the Colorado river near Las Vegas, were as compelling por traits of human endeavour and courage as images from the second world war.

Reisner had the remarkable ability to explain entertainingly the complex, and often numbing, deals and disputes in the "water wars" that have plagued the west, particularly California, for nearly 200 years. Tourists on their way to Death Valley today sometimes pause to look at the aqueduct that carries water from the once-fertile Owens valley more than 300 miles to Los Angeles. They have read Reisner's book, which describes how the water was stolen, how the Owens lake, which once bore paddle steamers, was turned into a dustbowl, and how the canal was bombed by local people in the 1920s.

Reisner recounted the drama of the collapse of the Saint Francis dam in a valley of shale, north-west of Los Angeles, in 1928. It had been built by the legendary William Mulholland, a self-taught hydro-engineer, who presided over the aqueduct from Owens valley and was a popular hero. When the dam crumbled, it sent a 200-ft high wall of water to the sea, killing more than 400 people and destroying 1,200 homes. It also ruined Mulholland, after whom the home of film stars, Mulholland Drive, is named.

Such follies and tragedies were only part of Reisner's argument, still debated today, that much of the west is simply too arid to permit extensive development, and that eventually nature will have her revenge. Yet only this year have developers been forced to demonstrate how they will provide water before erecting houses.

Another forecast Reisner made is still largely ignored, but irrefutable - that the massive dams across the west, such as Hoover, Parker and Glen Canyon, will one day cease to provide electricity, and turn into spectacular waterfalls as the lakes behind them fill with silt. He also reported that no irrigated community has existed for longer than 400 years. Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Phoenix and other neon-lit monuments to humanity are approaching the halfway mark.

Reisner was born in water-abundant Minneapolis, the son of a lawyer and script- writer. He earned a bachelor's degree at a private college in Indiana. Interested in environmental politics from those early days, he worked for two years in Washington on the staff of Environmental Action and the Population Institute, before moving to the Natural Resources Defence Council, in New York, from 1972 to 1979.

That year he obtained funds to research his masterpiece, and found a treasure trove in the formerly secret files of the Bureau of Reclamation, the villains of Cadillac valley (together with the Army Corps of Engineers) in their zeal to line with concrete every free- flowing river in America.

In 1990 Reisner co-wrote Overtapped Oasis: Reform Or Revolution For Western Water, following it a year later with Game Wars: The Undercover Pursuit Of Wildlife Poachers, a study of 200 federal agents and their fight against illegal seizure of wildlife in the south.

In his later years, environmentalists criticised Reisner for his association with two private companies, one storing water underground for profit - still better than dams, he said - and the other promoting the use of rice fibre. He had changed his mind about rice paddies in the west, he said, because they provided wetlands for birds that had otherwise been deprived of habitat. But the dispute was silly in comparison with his achievement.

Reisner is survived by his wife Lawrie Mott, a biochemist, and their daughters, Ruthie and Margot.

 Marc Reisner, environmentalist and writer, born Sept-ember 14 1948; died July 21 2000

webTitle: Vodafone gets the message

fields.headline: Vodafone gets the message
fields.standfirst: Board credibility rescue goes awry at annual meeting
fields.trailText: "Can we have our £10m back, please?" It is not what chairman Lord MacLaurin expected as he began his speech to Vodafone AirTouch's shareholders at the company's annual meeting, but that is what one irritated investor shouted.
fields.body:
"Can we have our £10m back, please?" It is not what chairman Lord MacLaurin expected as he began his speech to Vodafone AirTouch's shareholders at the company's annual meeting, but that is what one irritated investor shouted.

For the disgruntled, the one-off bonus to be given to the company's chief executive, Chris Gent, was the sort of tooth-and-claw capitalism that had no place in British boardrooms - and those aggrieved enough to turn up to QE2 conference centre in London made sure they aired their discontent.

One shareholder accused Vodafone of blackmail when Lord MacLaurin, who is also head of Vodafone's executive remuneration committee, explained that the payments were also a "catch-up", as Vodafone's board members were not paid at internationally competitive rates.

The urbane chairman, a Square Mile veteran, tried to smooth any ruffled feathers with an apology and went on to say that Vodafone AirTouch needed to adjust its remuneration policy in order to ensure that its executives were not lured to other competitors offering bigger and more attractive pay deals.

Despite the company's astonishing rise and its dramatic takeover of Mannesmann, the company's annual meeting was dominated by questions about executive salaries and the decision to pay Chris Gent a £10m bonus after the successful takeover of the German industrial group.

The company attempted to nip in the bud any shareholder revolt at yesterday's meeting by saying that Mr Gent would invest most of the cash part of his bonus in Vodafone shares. However, this did little to quell the shareholders, both large and small, who felt that the Vodafone board had ignored them. "That was only done because of the the terrible publicity you got," said one shareholder.

Many large shareholders registered their displeasure regarding the chief executive's bonus payment by voting against or abstaining on the issue of the reappointment of Lord MacLaurin and a new corporate remuneration policy.

The remuneration policy was approved by 17.6bn votes, but a huge 3.5bn voted against it and 3.7bn abstained.

The re-election of Lord MacLaurin drew 1.8bn votes against and 1.1bn abstentions, compared with 21.6bn votes in favour.

There were also more than four billion votes against the appointment of the former Mannesmann director, Thomas Geitner, to the board by shareholders unhappy about the length of his contract. Another 2.7bn abstained, but 18bn voted for him.

Stuart Bell, the research director at Pensions and Investments Research Consultants, told the meeting that the disclosure of Vodafone's new pay policy was "sparse", with little detail on performance targets.

He said there were big questions regarding whether the shareholders could have confidence in Vodafone's remuneration committee and in its rigour in setting high performance targets. Mr Gent told Reuters news agency before the company's annual meeting that he had been unfairly criticised by the press over his £10m bonus - but he agreed that Vodafone could have explained it better.

"Maybe the first letter to shareholders could have been better drafted," he said. Subsequent communications made it clear that the £5m cash element of the bonus was to bring his pay into line with the company's enlarged size, he added.

But some shareholders questioned that argument. "Ten million seems to me to be the robber barons of old," said Vanda Renton, a private shareholder, to the meeting.

Another likened Mr Gent to his former housekeeper who, he said, kept asking for top-ups to her salary whenever she was asked to do something. Lord MacLaurin added, however, that shareholders must appreciate the fact that Vodafone was "a world class company".

He said: "We are in the top 10 in the world, and the people who have done that are sitting at this table."

Chris Baldry, manager of voting issues at the National Association of Pension Funds and Associations, said shareholders had succeeded in driving home their message to Vodafone.

"The level of abstentions and votes against the resolution to approve the new remuneration policy - which was about 29% - sends quite a strong message to the remuneration committee and in general that special bonus payments of this nature will be resisted by shareholders."

Nokia profits rise 62%

The booming global sales of mobile telephones boosted profits for one of Europe's best known "new economy" companies.

Nokia, the world's biggest manufacturer of mobile handsets, yesterday reported second-quarter pre-tax profits had soared 62% to €1.4bn (£870m).

But the Finnish company was quick to warn that next quarter's earnings were likely to be much lower because of seasonality and the timing of new product introductions.

Jorma Ollila, Nokia's chief executive, said: "Strong growth in the global mobile communications market continued during the second quarter.

"Overall, the growth prospects for Nokia in the later part of the year, as well as for the long term, remain unchanged."

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The Diary is overjoyed to announce the centrepiece of Gerald Kaufman Month.
fields.body:
 The Diary is overjoyed to announce the centrepiece of Gerald Kaufman Month. To recap briefly, in an unwontedly scabrous attack my old friend and companion to the musicals (we were once thrown out of Camelot for trying to dance on our chairs) cited my persecution of defenceless victims such as the prime minister and chancellor as a primary reason why he no longer takes the Guardian.

Hoping to entice him back, we have contacted the Spitting Image genius Roger Law, who recently auctioned some puppets. Confirming that Gerald was not among these, Roger has agreed to lend us the puppet if he can find it - and the plan is this. The minute we collect up the £250,000 Corniche convertible (RR1) being lent to us by Rolls-Royce, rubber Gerald will be erected on a pole and, with the roof down, be driven on a special memory lane tour, after the style of a standard being carried into battle.

The tour will begin in his home town of Leeds and end outside parliament, and the full itinerary will be published as soon it is finalised. Moreover, should we plug Roger's forthcoming exhibition of his paintings so grotesquely that he feels obliged to give us the puppet, details of a competition to win your own latex Gerald will also follow.

 By way of a refreshing change, rumour is rife at the BBC. People in news and current affairs are absolutely convinced that Greg Dyke will choose his speech to the Edinburgh television festival to announce that he is moving the BBC's Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, freeing the evening schedules for movies and making ITN look sillier than ever. If this does come to pass, remember you read it here first. If not, forget all about it - and if you can't do that, for God's sake please don't write to the editor.

 Speaking of ITN, concern mounts for political editor John Igor ("What shall I do with the bodies master?") Sergeant. On the plane back from the G8 summit in Okinawa, you will recall, that self-effacing chairman of the lobby declared that Mr Tony need not chat further to the hacks because he (Igor) was watching Erin Brockovich. Heroic Robin Oakley intervened, and Mr T eventually did his rounds.

Do not believe that spin is the politician's preserve, for the new "approved version" from ITN describes confusion over whether it would be Mr T or Ali C who did the walkabout, Igor saying if it was Ali, could he please wait until after the film and dinner. This is complete cobblers, of course, and feelings run so high that there is talk of "an unprecedented mid-term challenge" to his chairmanship of the lobby.

 On Monday night that same lobby held a drinks party at Westminster for William Hague, and all shadow cabinet members were there under orders from central office. All except one. Polly Portillo couldn't make it, although he was available the next night, we gather, for a little party of his own. A very private one, too. None of the Hague clique had a clue about it, and one or two seemed amazed when they heard. Not that you could put a cigarette paper between them, of course.

 After his long disappearance, I am unsure whether to be relieved that he is safe or dismayed at his treachery on finding the Diary vicar moonlighting elsewhere. Under the byline Steve Chalke, with no mention of his reverence, the baptist takes two pages of Woman's Weekly to explain How To Rekindle Romance In Your Man. It's intriguing stuff, but I'm not here to plug so-called rival publications on behalf of treacherous employees. So I think we'll leave it there before anyone mentions 30 pieces of silver.

 Readers should now clear their schedules in preparation for Roger Law's painting and sculpture exhibition at the Rebecca Hossack Gallery in November. More details - many more - to follow.
fields.bodyText:  The Diary is overjoyed to announce the centrepiece of Gerald Kaufman Month. To recap briefly, in an unwontedly scabrous attack my old friend and companion to the musicals (we were once thrown out of Camelot for trying to dance on our chairs) cited my persecution of defenceless victims such as the prime minister and chancellor as a primary reason why he no longer takes the Guardian. Hoping to entice him back, we have contacted the Spitting Image genius Roger Law, who recently auctioned some puppets. Confirming that Gerald was not among these, Roger has agreed to lend us the puppet if he can find it - and the plan is this. The minute we collect up the £250,000 Corniche convertible (RR1) being lent to us by Rolls-Royce, rubber Gerald will be erected on a pole and, with the roof down, be driven on a special memory lane tour, after the style of a standard being carried into battle. The tour will begin in his home town of Leeds and end outside parliament, and the full itinerary will be published as soon it is finalised. Moreover, should we plug Roger's forthcoming exhibition of his paintings so grotesquely that he feels obliged to give us the puppet, details of a competition to win your own latex Gerald will also follow.  By way of a refreshing change, rumour is rife at the BBC. People in news and current affairs are absolutely convinced that Greg Dyke will choose his speech to the Edinburgh television festival to announce that he is moving the BBC's Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, freeing the evening schedules for movies and making ITN look sillier than ever. If this does come to pass, remember you read it here first. If not, forget all about it - and if you can't do that, for God's sake please don't write to the editor.  Speaking of ITN, concern mounts for political editor John Igor ("What shall I do with the bodies master?") Sergeant. On the plane back from the G8 summit in Okinawa, you will recall, that self-effacing chairman of the lobby declared that Mr Tony need not chat further to the hacks because he (Igor) was watching Erin Brockovich. Heroic Robin Oakley intervened, and Mr T eventually did his rounds. Do not believe that spin is the politician's preserve, for the new "approved version" from ITN describes confusion over whether it would be Mr T or Ali C who did the walkabout, Igor saying if it was Ali, could he please wait until after the film and dinner. This is complete cobblers, of course, and feelings run so high that there is talk of "an unprecedented mid-term challenge" to his chairmanship of the lobby.  On Monday night that same lobby held a drinks party at Westminster for William Hague, and all shadow cabinet members were there under orders from central office. All except one. Polly Portillo couldn't make it, although he was available the next night, we gather, for a little party of his own. A very private one, too. None of the Hague clique had a clue about it, and one or two seemed amazed when they heard. Not that you could put a cigarette paper between them, of course.  After his long disappearance, I am unsure whether to be relieved that he is safe or dismayed at his treachery on finding the Diary vicar moonlighting elsewhere. Under the byline Steve Chalke, with no mention of his reverence, the baptist takes two pages of Woman's Weekly to explain How To Rekindle Romance In Your Man. It's intriguing stuff, but I'm not here to plug so-called rival publications on behalf of treacherous employees. So I think we'll leave it there before anyone mentions 30 pieces of silver.  Readers should now clear their schedules in preparation for Roger Law's painting and sculpture exhibition at the Rebecca Hossack Gallery in November. webTitle: Bach to Iona for the soul's sake

fields.headline: Bach to Iona for the soul's sake
fields.standfirst: Hebridean island concert celebrates composer's life
fields.trailText: At 10am today, Sir John Eliot Gardiner will stride in his tails into the abbey on Columba's holy island of Iona to conduct a concert marking the 250th anniversary of the death of Johann Sebastian Bach.
fields.body:
At 10am today, Sir John Eliot Gardiner will stride in his tails into the abbey on Columba's holy island of Iona to conduct a concert marking the 250th anniversary of the death of Johann Sebastian Bach.

Unlike Samuel Johnson, John Keats or Felix Mendelssohn, the composer never crossed on the ferry from Mull to visit an outpost of Celtic Christianity on the chilly edge of Europe. He spent his last 27 years as cantor in the Lutheran church of St Thomas in Leipzig, which will be the focus of much of today's anniversary homage.

But Sir John has brought his Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists to Iona because it felt "fundamentally, profoundly right to be here". Fifteen singers and 20 instrumentalists, plus fixers, managers, 25 music stands, and a chamber organ borrowed from St John's church in Westminster, have made the trip.

As the musicians came off the ferry in bright sunshine on a perfect still day, they gazed about them, like Miranda discovering the brave new world on her island.

"I felt moved, especially when the sun came out," said the orchestra leader, Alison Bury. "It was so beautiful, and it had been such a long journey."

The Hebridean odyssey is part of the Bach Pilgrimage, Sir John's millennial journey through the 198 surviving Bach cantatas: 14 countries, 50 or so concerts, which began around the font where Bach was baptised in Eisenach in Germany and will end in New York on New Year's Eve.

Bach died shortly after 8.15pm on July 28, 1750, and much of the Iona programme (seven pieces: a funeral aria, three cantatas, two motets, one chorale) concerns death and the pious soul's hope of eternal salvation.

Before rehearsals, Sir John addressed his forces assembled around another font beneath Iona Abbey's five-light west window through which unaccustomed sun would later stream.

"We have a day and half to connect with this place," he said. "I hope we can make the best use of this building, pick up what is in this wall and return it. It's a way of giving thanks for what we have been able to do so far this year."

Soon they were into the cantata known as Actus Tragicus (BWV 106), which lasts 18 minutes and sets just 145 words. In the central section, the chorus repeats the stern Old Testament prophecies of human mortality while soprano Joanne Lunn weaves an ecstatic arioso expressing fervent hope for the promise of salvation through Christ's sacrifice.

"Come, Jesus, come!" she sings 15 times, with almost erotic desire.

"This longing for death is not a death wish in the modern sense," explained Sir John during a rehearsal break beneath the high cross of St John. "It's the concept that life is a journey, often a very painful one. And the thing that consoles you through life is the prospect that there is an end to it. The hope is of being in Jesus's arms; and so the terminology is often very sexy.

"People can be frightened of it now, but it wasn't something that bothered Lutherans at all."

On Wednesday night, most players and singers piled on to a ship, the MB Iolaire, for a sunset cruise. They saw the beach where Columba landed to bring Christianity to the heathens, and the hill where he sat to meditate. As dusk fell, the boat sailed softly past the abbey whose great stone walls had amplified Bach's sounds. At the jetty, Sir John chatted to the boatman in a skipper-to-skipper kind of way.

There will be only 200 people in the abbey for today's concert, and none of them will be charged for their tickets. But an imaginative response to the anniversary of a genius demanded that something special had to be done.

"What would Bach have made of it?" Ms Bury asked herself. "What would Bach have thought of being performed in 2000?

"He was not one of the wildly successful composers of his time. But he must have had great belief in his own music, and he knew that it was written to the glory of God. He would have been completely amazed to know his work was still being heard - and pleased too."

"Come O sweet hour of death... Do not delay O my last light" sang the soloist in cantata 161, as the musicians returned to the life to come.

"This music of Bach, particularly a programme like this, makes you aware of the measuring out of time and a realisation that, when death strikes, its timing will not be in our hands," added Sir John. "Bach prepares you for this in an extraordinary way."

webTitle: Hunt for children from incest farm

fields.headline: Hunt for children from incest farm
fields.trailText: South African police are trying to find the remains of seven missing children born to a brother and sister who have been arrested for incest. The 40-year-old white man and his sister, 32, are expected to appear in court today.
fields.body:
South African police are trying to find the remains of seven missing children born to a brother and sister who have been arrested for incest. The 40-year-old white man and his sister, 32, are expected to appear in court today.

The two were detained on Wednesday with their elderly parents, with whom they shared a remote farm, 60 miles east of Johannesburg. The police said the brother and sister "lived as husband and wife" and had at least nine children.

But only two boys, aged 14 and seven, are accounted for. They have been taken into care. Police forensic experts and sniffer dogs were yesterday searching two farms near Delmas where the remains of at least three babies were believed to be buried.

Police sources said that one of the detained suspects had offered to lead them to the graves of some of the children, but was uncertain exactly where they were buried.

Inspector Olga Marais said the police had information that some of the missing children may have died of natural causes shortly after birth, but others allegedly were killed.

The case has bizarre echoes of an award-winning South African novel, Triomf, by Marlene van Niekerk, about incest in a poor Afrikaans-speaking family and the child that results.

The brother and sister, who have not been named, were arrested by the police child protection unit after a tip-off from a social worker who had been approached by another member of the family.

The region's deputy police commissioner, Dimo Moraba, alleged that the two had been sexually involved since 1984, and that the woman was believed to have been pregnant at least 10 times. She is said to have told police that she is expecting another child soon.

Neighbours described the woman as appearing to be "almost continually pregnant", but few of them seemed to have been alarmed by the lack of children.

One resident, Elize de Klerk, said she had complained to a local Christian organisation that the couple's 14-year-old son seemed never to go to school, but to her knowledge nothing was done.

webTitle: Hungary's choice: 'build schools or prisons'

fields.headline: Hungary's choice: 'build schools or prisons'
fields.trailText: By September, one in three children starting school in Hungary will be a Romany, according to the education minister, Zoltan Pokorni.
fields.body:
By September, one in three children starting school in Hungary will be a Romany, according to the education minister, Zoltan Pokorni.

The numbers of Roma are hotly disputed, roughly 600,000 - 6% or 7% of the overall population - say the sociologists. With Hungarian couples reluctant to have even one child, and most Romany families producing five or six, the implications for the whole country are clear.

Few adult Roma have work. Almost every family survives off state benefit. The problems of the Roma are rapidly becoming the problems of the whole society. "The government has a simple choice: to build schools or prisons," said Aladar Horvath, the head of the Roma Civil Rights Foundation.

It is breakfast time in the primary and nursery school in Edeleny, in north-east Hungary, which was set up as a charitable foundation seven years ago. In this mining town there are no mines left, and jobs are almost impossible to find.

"If we don't feed the children first, they won't be able to concentrate on their lessons," said Maria Volopik, the headmistress and founder of the school, smiling amid the din. She and the children, and most of the teachers, are Roma. Very few have eaten before they arrive.

"I asked the children one morning - are you Gypsies?" said one teacher. "No! they shouted, "Gypsies are dirty, Gypsies steal."

"Well, I'm a Gypsy," she told them.

"There are three problem areas in Roma education: the general quality of education, discrimination and ethnic identity," said Peter Rado, the author of a special report commissioned by the previous government.

He accuses a succession of governments in the last decade of dealing only with different fragments of these problems, rather than finding an approach that deals with the whole.

In the other three primary schools in Edeleny, Roma children are treated as they are almost everywhere in Hungary - put in remedial classes for the disabled.

Some 39% of Hungarian Roma over the age of 14 are illiterate, according to government figures. Their families' crowded rooms leave little space for homework.

Less than a third of Roma children get beyond primary school. Aware that the European Union is watching, the government insists that it is tackling the problem.

A "medium-term action plan" exists and a new interministerial council for Roma issues has been established with Roma participation.

EU funding is also focusing on education, including teacher training. Roma women are to be trained to become kindergarten nannies. Schemes will encourage children not to drop out of primary school and help them to catch up at secondary school.

From September, general textbooks will mention the Romas' culture for the first time.

But the government has long said it is devoting money to such Roma problems: Brussels funding will now mean that EU representatives can check how contributions are spent.

webTitle: Europe's Gypsies lobby for nation status

fields.headline: Europe's Gypsies lobby for nation status
fields.trailText: The main body representing Europe's 12m Gypsies wants the Roma people to be given recognition as a non-territorial nation, and says it will back this up with its own "floating" parliament and embassies in various countries.
fields.body:
The main body representing Europe's 12m Gypsies wants the Roma people to be given recognition as a non-territorial nation, and says it will back this up with its own "floating" parliament and embassies in various countries.

It is the first time that the International Union Romani has made such a demand for international recognition since it was founded in London three decades ago.

The organisation's fifth world congress concludes in Prague today with the presentation of a wide-reaching plan aimed at creating better living conditions for Europe's fastest-growing ethnic minority and increasing the Roma's power to lobby governments which discriminate against them.

In 1993 the International Union Romani was granted the status of an advisory committee at the UN, greatly increasingly its lobbying power, but the congress document is its most significant political statement so far.

It recommends the establishment of a floating parliament that would meet every three months, a network of embassies and an anti-racist committee to be linked to an international Roma court. A poll tax in the Roma community should be levied to finance the structure, the document says.

It foresees the court putting racists on trial and putting pressure on governments that discriminate against Roma - but it is unclear what recognition such a tribunal would have.

Sean Nazerali, one of the conference organisers said the time was long overdue to address one of the main Roma problems of the last 1,000 years - non-recognition of its nationhood by an international system geared to recognising states only.

"The Roma are a modern nation like all the rest, so we are seeking recognition as a modern nation... enabling us to play a political role at the national and international level," he said. He suggested that, contrary to viewing the Roma as a problem, they could be an archetype for the perfect European nation. "It's everywhere, it has a collective identity at the European level and its people are connected throughout the entire continent."

But progress means quashing stereotypes, he added. "The sort of exotic but very common romantic notion of the wandering nomadic Gypsy who leads a wonderfully carefree, barefoot life, is roughly as accurate as the Indian running round on horseback, shooting bison with a bow and arrow."

During often heated and passionate debate the conference tackled numerous issues.

The migration of Roma to the west, the plight of Gypsies in Kosovo, the rise in race-related attacks against Roma and improving education have dominated the agenda.

Compensation for Roma victims of the Nazi Holocaust was one of the more emotive issues. Plans were announced to set up a fund, to be financed by Roma personalities, which would establish a university as a living memorial to the half a million Roma who died.

The irony of setting the conference in Prague was not lost on delegates. The Czech Republic, like several of its neighbours, has been fiercely criticised for its treatment of Roma. Of the more than 30 documented race-related killings in the region since the fall of communism - not including those in the former Yugoslavia - more than a third have been in the Czech Republic.

Members of the British Gypsy Council said they had considered boycotting the conference, as had most western groups. "We are suspicious that the Czech government put the money up for this to show how nice they're being to Gypsies, when in fact they get so poorly treated here," said the council's president, Josie Lee.

But in his speech to the conference, President Vaclav Havel promised to "do my best to ensure a happier life for the Roma of the Czech Republic".

webTitle: 'Bullied' PC wins chance to sue

fields.headline: 'Bullied' PC wins chance to sue
fields.trailText: A former police constable who claims she was subjected to years of hostility and victimisation after accusing a colleague of rape and buggery won a six year battle yesterday to sue the Metropolitan police for compensation.
fields.body:
A former police constable who claims she was subjected to years of hostility and victimisation after accusing a colleague of rape and buggery won a six year battle yesterday to sue the Metropolitan police for compensation.

Eileen Waters, 32, had been trying to sue the chief constable for negligence since 1994 for failing to stop the victimisation. But judges in the high court and court of appeal ruled that investigating her claims would distract the Met from its primary task of combating crime.

However in a ruling yesterday, law lords decided that her claim could go ahead. The judgment also gives employees generally the right to be protected against harassment and bullying.

Ms Waters, who joined the Met in 1987, alleges that in February the following year she was raped and buggered by an officer in her police residential accommodation in Marylebone, central London, when they were off duty.

She says she told her reporting sergeant and other officers about the attack but no action was taken. She alleges that she was subjected to more than four years' victimisation, including poison pen letters, offensive cartoons, and a blood-stained truncheon planted in her locker.

In July 1992 she took sick leave and retired in May 1998 on medical grounds. She issued a writ for negligence against the chief constable in 1994 after loosing a sex discrimination and victimisation claim at an industrial tribunal because her alleged attacker was off duty.
